column1: How did the Babylonian period relations influence the tooth counts of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism, specifically for Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn?
column2: The Babylonian period relations influenced the tooth counts of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism by providing the basis for the mathematical calculations used to determine the gear sizes and ratios for the mechanisms. For Mercury, Venus, Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn, specific period relations were chosen based on their accuracy and suitability for creating the gear systems needed for the planetary mechanisms. These period relations were selected to ensure that the gear sizes and ratios matched the planetary motions accurately. The tooth counts of the gears were determined based on these period relations to create functional and accurate mechanisms for tracking the movements of the planets. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The tooth counts of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism directly reflect the Babylonian period relations, according to Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones in "The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism". For Mars, a period relation of (37, -79) was chosen due to its accuracy, resulting in suitable tooth counts for the gears. For Jupiter, the most accurate period relation was chosen, while for Saturn, a 59-year period was selected for its greater accuracy compared to a 29-year period. For Venus, the mechanism uses an 8-year cycle with 5 synodic periods, referred to as (5, 8), which is scaled up to (40, 64) to make the tooth counts reasonable. The text does not provide specific information on the period relation or tooth counts for Mercury.

column1: What is the significance of the design simplicity and economy in the new mechanisms for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism, and how do they differ from previous models based on deferent and epicycle theories?
column2: The significance of the design simplicity and economy in the new mechanisms for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism is that they provide an elegant solution to a long-standing problem. These new mechanisms are unlike previous models based on deferent and epicycle theories because they are based closely on the lunar anomaly mechanism. This design is surprising and unexpected because it works for both the lunar anomaly and the planets, even though the causes of the anomalies are different. The unity in design between the lunar anomaly and the planets reflects a unified solution, providing an economical and elegant way to model the motions of the superior planets. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The new mechanisms for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism, as proposed by Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones, are significant due to their simplicity and economy. Unlike previous models that directly modeled the deferent and epicycle theories, these new mechanisms are based closely on the lunar anomaly mechanism. They consist of just four gears, including an epicyclic gear with a pin on its face and a second epicyclic gear, which rotates on an eccentric epicyclic axis and has a slot in its face that engages with the pin. This design simplicity and economy align with the overall design of the Antikythera Mechanism, which is believed to be a mathematician's instrument based on arithmetic cycles and the geometric theories of its time.

column1: How were the superior planet mechanisms integrated into the Antikythera Mechanism, and what challenges did the design face in terms of interference and mechanical constraints?
column2: The superior planet mechanisms were integrated into the Antikythera Mechanism using a pin-and-slot device. This design faced challenges in terms of interference and mechanical constraints due to the complexity of the planetary movements and the need to accurately represent them within the mechanism. The pin-and-slot device allowed for the necessary movements to be replicated mechanically, but the design had to be carefully implemented to avoid issues with interference and ensure the proper functioning of the mechanism. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The integration of superior planet mechanisms into the Antikythera Mechanism presented significant challenges, as described by Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones in "The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism." Unlike the inferior planets, the superior planets are not restricted to a fixed number of degrees from the Sun, creating difficulties when attempting to model these planets with slotted followers on the central axis. The addition of the inferior planet mechanisms to the main drive wheel (b1) also created more difficulties in arranging for both the 0-input and the 1-input to the superior planet mechanisms, as the inferior planet mechanisms interfered with the design. Despite these challenges, Freeth and Jones proposed a model that provided an elegant solution to these problems, based closely on the lunar anomaly mechanism.

column1: In what ways did the new model for the superior planet mechanisms align with the astronomical knowledge of the era and the surviving evidence from the Antikythera Mechanism?
column2: The new model for the superior planet mechanisms proposed in the study aligns with the astronomical knowledge of the era by using mechanisms based on ancient Greek models of planetary motion, such as the "deferent-and-epicycle" and "eccentre" models. These models were used to explain the nonuniform motion of the planets, which was observed in antiquity. The proposed mechanisms for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism are based on the known mechanization of the lunar anomaly at the back of the device. Surprisingly, these models for the superior planets look exactly the same as the lunar anomaly mechanism, indicating a consistent design approach in the Mechanism. Despite the lack of physical evidence due to the loss of material in the fragments, the new model provides an elegant and harmonious solution that fits with the existing gear trains and the design virtuosity of the Antikythera Mechanism. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The new model for the superior planet mechanisms proposed by Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones in their paper "The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism" aligns with the astronomical knowledge of the era and the surviving evidence from the Antikythera Mechanism in several ways. The model is based on the known mechanization of the lunar anomaly at the back of the Antikythera Mechanism and is designed to mimic the geometrical models of the time. It provides an explanation for the existence of bearings and fittings on the Main Drive Wheel, as well as the mysterious pillars attached to its circumference. The model also accounts for the dimensions of the pillars. Furthermore, it is designed to show how all five planets can be included in the Antikythera Mechanism in a way that conforms to the observed data and explains several previously unresolved pieces of evidence. The model's superior planet mechanisms are based closely on the lunar anomaly mechanism, providing an economical and elegant solution that is in harmony with the design virtuosity of the existing gear trains.

column1: How did the tooth counts and gear sizes of the fixed input gears for the superior planets reflect the period relations from Babylonian astronomy, and how were these gears arranged in size order for assembly in the Antikythera Mechanism?
column2: The tooth counts and gear sizes of the fixed input gears for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism were chosen to reflect the period relations from Babylonian astronomy. The fixed input gears were arranged in size order for assembly based on the chosen period relations. For example, the largest fixed gear for Jupiter was selected based on a specific period relation, such as (76, -83), to ensure accuracy. The order of the fixed inputs, from the front of the Mechanism to the back, was arranged to match the planetary order of the pointers. In this case, the order was Jupiter, Saturn, Mars. The output gears were arranged in a different order, reflecting the ordering of the pointers from front to back: Saturn, Jupiter, Mars. This arrangement was necessary to ensure the proper functioning of the gear system within the Antikythera Mechanism. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The tooth counts and gear sizes of the fixed input gears for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism directly reflected the period relations from Babylonian astronomy, according to Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones in "The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism". For example, the mechanism for Mars contained four gears: the fixed input gear G1, the pin gear G2, the slot gear G3, and the output gear G4. The tooth counts of G1 and G2 represented a Babylonian period relation for Mars. The surviving gears in the mechanism had tooth counts ranging from 15 to 225 teeth, limiting the consideration of period relations to numbers within this range. The exact arrangement of these gears in size order for assembly in the Antikythera Mechanism is not specified in the provided context.

column1: What tools and formats are used for editing, building, integrating, and publishing data in the homer multitex project?
column2:
The tools and formats used for editing, building, integrating, and publishing data in the Homer Multitext project are as follows:

1. **Editing:**
   - Texts: TEI-XML format edited using tools like Oxygen.
   - Collections: Plain text, comma- or tab-delimited format edited using tools like Google Fusion Tables, Git Online Editor, etc.
   - Validation: TEI-XML files validated using RelaxNG Schema.

2. **Building & Integrating:**
   - Testing Validity of Texts: Flattened, tabular data format.
   - Integrating Texts, Data, and Images: RDF triples.
   - Tools: Gradle build-system and custom scripts.

3. **Publishing:**
   - Serving Data: RDF triples using Fuseki SPARQL endpoint.
   - Discovery, Query, Retrieval: RDF triples converted to XML using CITE Servlet.
   - End-user display: Citations converted to XML Fragments and then to HTML using CITEKit.

These tools and formats are used to manage the workflow and architecture of the Homer Multitext project efficiently.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: The Homer Multitext project uses a variety of tools and formats for editing, building, integrating, and publishing data. For editing texts, TEI-XML is used as a valid archival data format, with tools like Oxygen being used for validation (Blackwell and Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014). The Gradle build system, citemgr, is used to process XML texts, tab-delimited and comma-delimited collections and indices, and their catalogues (Blackwell and Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014). For integrating texts, data, and images, RDF triples are used, with custom scripts and the Perseus Morphological Service being used for testing the validity of texts (Blackwell and Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014). For publishing and serving data, RDF triples are used again, with a Fuseki SPARQL endpoint being used for serving data (Blackwell and Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014). Additionally, UNIX utilities and applications such as cat, tab, nl, and vim are used for editorial work (Koentges et al., ISAW Papers 20.8, 2021).

column1: How does the homer multitex project validate and test its data at build-time?
column2: The project uses Gradle to build its .ttl file, compiling XML texts, collections, and indices saved as .csv or .tsv files. The build-scripts perform validation on XML files and other domain-specific tests. Additionally, the project has a system called HMT-MOM (Mandatory Ongoing Maintenance) that enforces a canon of legitimate Unicode characters for Greek texts, ensures referential integrity of URN values in indices and CITE Collection data structures, and supports manual review by providing visualizations of the state of completion for each folio edited by collaborators. HMT-MOM also conducts linguistic checking by matching each word-token against the Morpheus morphological parser. Words that fail to match are identified as non-standard forms present on a manuscript, non-lexical strings, or new Greek vocabulary to be added to a new lexicon of the language.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: The Homer Multitext project uses a Gradle build system called citemgr to validate and test its data at build-time. This system processes XML texts, tab-delimited and comma-delimited collections and indices, and their catalogues, and makes explicit at build-time every relationship necessary to capture the model of a text or collection-object. The build-scripts perform validation on XML files as well as other domain-specific tests. HMT-MOM (for Mandatory Ongoing Maintenance) includes scripts that enforce a specified canon of legitimate Unicode characters for Greek texts, ensure the referential integrity of URN values in indices and CITE Collection data structures, and support further manual review by providing visualizations of the state of completion for each folio their collaborators edit. HMT-MOM also does linguistic checking, matching each word-token against the Morpheus morphological parser (Christopher W. Blackwell and D. Neel Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014).

column1: What was the role of the Front Sub-Plate in holding the fixed gears for the superior planets, and how did its design and attachment to the Sub-Frame contribute to the overall functionality of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism?
column2: The Front Sub-Plate in the Antikythera Mechanism held the fixed gears for the superior planets, specifically Mars, Jupiter, and Saturn. The design and attachment of the Front Sub-Plate to the Sub-Frame were crucial for the overall functionality of the planetary mechanisms. The fixed gears on the Front Sub-Plate were essential for the accurate calculation of the planetary positions. The attachment to the Sub-Frame ensured stability and alignment, allowing the gears to mesh correctly and transmit motion accurately through the gear trains. This precise alignment and stability were necessary for the proper functioning of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The Front Sub-Plate in the Antikythera Mechanism played a crucial role in holding the fixed gears for the superior planets. According to Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones in "The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism" (ISAW Papers 4, February 2012), the fixed inputs to the planetary mechanisms were all attached to this Front Sub-Plate, which was fixed to the wooden Sub-Frame. This arrangement provided the 0-input to the mechanisms. The input gears were stacked in size order, with the largest being closest to the plate, and they all had a hole of 14.4 mm diameter to allow the planetary outputs to pass through on their way to the Front Dials. This design and attachment to the Sub-Frame contributed to the overall functionality of the planetary mechanisms by enabling them to be set at any angle for calibration, thus enhancing the versatility and accuracy of the Antikythera Mechanism.

column1: How does the Geolat project plan to utilize crowdsourcing for continual evolution of knowledge?
column2: The project plans to utilize crowdsourcing for the continual evolution of knowledge by allowing contributions from the research team and its collaborators, as well as from the public. This approach ensures that the system can evolve over time with input from a wide range of individuals, not just limited to the core team. Maurizio Lana 2014,"Geolat: Geography for Latin Literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.11, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/lana/.
column3: The Geolat project plans to utilize crowdsourcing for the continual evolution of its knowledge base. According to Maurizio Lana in "Geolat: Geography for Latin Literature" (ISAW Papers 7.11, 2014), the system is designed to allow for contributions beyond just the research team and its collaborators. This is facilitated by user-management tools provided by Github, which help to build a community of contributors to the gazetteer. The project is open access, meaning it is freely accessible to everyone, and it encourages the use of Creative Commons licenses to protect both creators and users.

column1: How did the integration of the new superior planet mechanisms, along with the inferior planet mechanisms and solar anomaly mechanism, contribute to the overall complexity and accuracy of the planetary motion representation in the Antikythera Mechanism?
column2: The integration of the new superior planet mechanisms, along with the inferior planet mechanisms and solar anomaly mechanism, contributed to the overall complexity and accuracy of the planetary motion representation in the Antikythera Mechanism by providing a more comprehensive and detailed model of the movements of the planets. The inclusion of mechanisms for the superior planets, which were more challenging to model due to their varying distances from the Earth, added a layer of sophistication to the representation. By incorporating these mechanisms, the Antikythera Mechanism was able to more accurately depict the nonuniform motions of the planets, including prograde and retrograde movements, enhancing the overall accuracy and complexity of the planetary motion representation. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The integration of the superior planet mechanisms, along with the inferior planet mechanisms and solar anomaly mechanism, added complexity to the Antikythera Mechanism but also increased its accuracy in representing planetary motion. The superior planets were not restricted to a fixed number of degrees from the Sun, which created difficulties when trying to model these planets with slotted followers on the central axis. However, the inclusion of these mechanisms provided an elegant solution to the problem of how the superior planets might have been shown in the Antikythera Mechanism. Wright demonstrated the feasibility of including all five planets in the Antikythera Mechanism using the same technology and engineering found in the surviving fragments. The study by Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones concluded that the Antikythera Mechanism almost certainly calculated the motions of all five planets known in ancient times. The front display incorporated revolving pointers bearing little spheres to represent all five planets making their apparent motions around the Earth. The gearwork of the mechanism mimicked the geometrical model that could account for the varying apparent speeds of the Sun and Moon, the limits of Venus' and Mercury's elongation from the Sun, and the retrogradations of all the planets.

column1: How did the design and assembly of the planet module, including the superior planet mechanisms, the SPP, and the Front Sub-Plate, contribute to the overall functionality and accuracy of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism?
column2: The design and assembly of the planet module, including the superior planet mechanisms, the SPP, and the Front Sub-Plate, contributed to the overall functionality and accuracy of the planetary mechanisms in the Antikythera Mechanism by allowing for calibration and maintenance. The ability to disassemble and calibrate each superior planet individually ensured that the gears could be set to the correct phase for each planet on specific dates. This calibration process, although limited by the gear tooth accuracy, was crucial for aligning the output gears correctly to reflect the planetary order of the pointers. The design also accommodated the coaxial outputs on the Zodiac Dial, enabling the accurate prediction of celestial phenomena despite the inherent inaccuracies of the era. The inclusion of spacer rings, concentric tubes, and precise measurements in the assembly contributed to the mechanical accuracy and functionality of the planetary mechanisms within the Antikythera Mechanism. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The design and assembly of the planet module, including the superior planet mechanisms, the Superior Planet Plate (SPP), and the Front Sub-Plate, in the Antikythera Mechanism contributed to the overall functionality and accuracy of the planetary mechanisms by providing a logical framework for the inclusion of the superior planets, which are not restricted to a fixed number of degrees from the Sun. According to Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones in "The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism," the superior planet mechanisms were attached to the back of the SPP, and the fixed gears for the superior planets were attached to the Front Sub-Plate in size order. This arrangement allowed the Sub-Plate to be inserted into the Mechanism properly and held the static gears in the superior planetary mechanisms sufficiently firmly. The authors' model also explains the existence of bearings and fittings on the Main Drive Wheel, b1, as well as the mysterious pillars attached to its circumference.

column1: What was the unit of analysis in Rouech 's study, and how did the researchers label each item?
column2: The unit of analysis in the study was a 'saying', as identified and presented by the scribe of a particular manuscript. The researchers labeled each item by working closely with the CTS project over the last 18 months to generate unique ids for each saying.  2014,"Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.25, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/roueche-lawrence-lawrence/.
column3: In the study by Roueché, Lawrence, and Lawrence titled "Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" (ISAW Papers 7.25, 2014), the unit of analysis was a 'saying', as identified and presented by the scribe of a particular manuscript. The researchers faced the challenge of labeling each of these items. They worked closely with the CTS project over a period of 18 months to generate unique identifiers for each item, a process they found slow but beneficial.

column1: What is the main focus of the article regarding the Pillars of Hercules?
column2: The main focus of the article regarding the Pillars of Hercules is on a Syriac fragment from "The Cause of All Causes" that describes the Pillars of Hercules as being three in number, which is unique compared to the usual understanding of them being two. The article discusses this specific passage and its significance as a witness to Syriac interest in Greek natural philosophy. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The main focus of the article by A. McCollum (2012) is a passage from the Syriac Cause of All Causes that describes the Pillars of Hercules as being three in number rather than two. This passage is studied in the context of a recently cataloged manuscript from Dayr Al-Zau2018faru0101n. The article also discusses the understanding of the Pillars of Hercules in Syriac scholarship and Greek natural philosophy, and how this knowledge was translated and incorporated into Syriac texts. The northern Pillar is identified as the Rock of Gibraltar, while the identity of the southern Pillar is disputed. The article also mentions a unique reference to three, not two, Pillars of Hercules in a short fragment.

column1: How does the Syriac text in question differ from the traditional understanding of the Pillars of Hercules?
column2: The Syriac text in question describes the Pillars of Hercules as being three in number rather than two, which is different from the traditional understanding that there are only two Pillars of Hercules. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The Syriac text in question, from the Syriac Cause of All Causes, differs from the traditional understanding of the Pillars of Hercules by describing them as being three in number rather than two. This is noted in A. McCollum's 2012 paper, "A Syriac Fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes on the Pillars of Hercules". The traditional understanding is that the Pillars of Hercules are two promontories at the western end of the Mediterranean, with the northern pillar being the Rock of Gibraltar and the southern pillar being in northwest Africa.

column1: Who were some of the prominent Syriac scholars who incorporated Greek knowledge into their works?
column2: Some of the prominent Syriac scholars who incorporated Greek knowledge into their works include Sergius of Reshaina, Jacob of Edessa, and Gregory bar ‘Ebrāyā (Barhebraeus). They translated and integrated Greek wisdom on natural philosophy into their writings, contributing to the development of Syriac scholarship in these fields. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: Two prominent Syriac scholars who incorporated Greek knowledge into their works were Sergius of Reš ʿAinā and Jacob of Edessa. Sergius of Reš ʿAinā (d. 536) translated parts of the pseudo-Aristotelian De Mundo, which served as a handbook for Syriac readers interested in Greek wisdom on the natural world. Jacob of Edessa (c. 630-708) incorporated Greek knowledge on the natural world into his Hexaemeron commentary. These details are mentioned in the ISAW Paper by A. McCollum titled "A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes on the Pillars of Hercules".

column1: What is the significance of the Syriac fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes' in relation to Syriac interest in Greek philosophy?
column2: The Syriac fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes' is significant because it describes the Pillars of Hercules, a topic of geographical knowledge in ancient Greek philosophy. This shows how Syriac scholars incorporated Greek wisdom and natural philosophy into their own language and culture. The fragment highlights the translation and adaptation of Greek knowledge into Syriac texts, reflecting the broader interest of Syriac scholars in Greek philosophy and natural world studies. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The Syriac fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes' is significant as it demonstrates the Syriac interest in Greek philosophy, particularly in the field of natural philosophy. This fragment, which refers to the Pillars of Hercules, is unique because it mentions three pillars instead of the traditionally known two. This shows that Syriac scholars incorporated Greek knowledge into their works, and also adapted it in their own ways. The fragment is also a testament to the transmission of ancient Greek philosophy to the Syriac world, as noted by A. McCollum in his 2012 paper, "A Syriac Fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes on the Pillars of Hercules".

column1: What is the main focus of the preliminary report discussed in the article Preliminary Report on Early Byzantine Pottery from a Building Complex at Kenchreai ?
column2: The main focus of the preliminary report discussed in the article is the Early Byzantine pottery found in a large building near the waterfront at Kenchreai in southern Greece. The report presents the results of the study of this pottery, including Late Roman Amphora 2 rims, stoppers, funnels, lamps, glass vessels, and other small finds. The pottery indicates the building's role in the distribution of regional agricultural products during the late sixth or early seventh centuries A.D. S. Heath, J.L. Rife, J.J. Bravo III, and G. Blasdel. (2015). Preliminary Report on Early Byzantine Pottery from a Building Complex at Kenchreai (Greece). ISAW Papers, 10.
column3: The main focus of the preliminary report discussed in the article "Preliminary Report on Early Byzantine Pottery from a Building Complex at Kenchreai" by S. Heath, J.L. Rife, J.J. Bravo III, and G. Blasdel (ISAW Papers 10, 2015) is the study of Early Byzantine pottery discovered in a large building near the waterfront at Kenchreai in southern Greece. The report presents the results of the preliminary study of this pottery, and also includes a variety of small finds, such as Late Roman to Early Byzantine glass. The report suggests that the building complex played a role in the movement of regional agricultural products and possibly consumer goods during the late sixth to early seventh centuries.

column1: What is the context in which the Syriac fragment on the Pillars of Hercules was found in the manuscript from Dayr Al-Za‘farān?
column2: The Syriac fragment on the Pillars of Hercules was found in a recently cataloged manuscript from Dayr Al-Za‘farān. This manuscript is described as somewhat motley and disarranged, making it very difficult to date. The fragment was found on a single page of this manuscript, and it is completely divorced from its original context in The Cause of All Causes. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The Syriac fragment on the Pillars of Hercules was found in a manuscript from Dayr Al-Za‘farān, which is described as somewhat motley and disarranged, making it difficult to date. The fragment was found on a single folio (70r) and is completely isolated from its original context. There is no reference to The Cause of All Causes as a whole or to its title in the manuscript. The fragment describes the Pillars of Hercules as being three in number rather than two, a detail that has drawn attention and commentary (A. McCollum, 2012).

column1: How does the Syriac text describe the Pillars of Hercules and the island of Gadeira?
column2: The Syriac text describes the Pillars of Hercules as being three in number, rather than the commonly known two. It mentions an island called Gadeira where Hercules, referred to as a hero and prophet of the pagans, set up these three famous columns to ensure his memory would be remembered for generations. The text also describes the location of the columns at the border of the inhabited world, where ships would be unable to return if they were propelled there by the force of the winds. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The Syriac text describes the Pillars of Hercules as three in number, rather than the traditionally recognized two. This is mentioned in a passage from the Syriac "Cause of All Causes". The island of Gadeira is described as being at the edge of the world, where Hercules, a hero and prophet of the pagans, set up the three columns or pillars. These pillars were meant to serve as a commemoration of Hercules, ensuring his memory would be passed down through generations. This information is found in A. McCollum's 2012 paper, "A Syriac Fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes on the Pillars of Hercules".

column1: What is the significance of the reference to three Pillars of Hercules in the Syriac text?
column2: The significance of the reference to three Pillars of Hercules in the Syriac text is that it deviates from the commonly known concept of the Pillars of Hercules being two in number. This unique reference raises questions about the interpretation and understanding of geographical knowledge in the Syriac tradition, particularly in relation to Greek natural philosophy. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The reference to three Pillars of Hercules in the Syriac text is significant because it is a unique deviation from the traditional Greek concept of the Pillars of Hercules, which are typically described as being two in number. The northern Pillar is identified as the Rock of Gibraltar, while the identity of the southern Pillar in northwest Africa is disputed. This Syriac text, published in 1889, is noted for its reference to a third pillar, a detail that is not found in other accounts. This has sparked interest and commentary, particularly in relation to the Syriac interest in Greek natural philosophy. (A. McCollum. (2012). A Syriac Fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes on the Pillars of Hercules. ISAW Papers 5.)

column1: How did the urbanization of Delos expand during the period of the second Athenian dominion, and what were the key moments in the history of Delos relevant to the discussion of urban growth on the island?
column2:
During the period of the second Athenian dominion, the urbanization of Delos expanded significantly. The urbanization expanded from the area of the old sanctuary center outwards, with new markets, agoras, port facilities, storage facilities, and residential neighborhoods developing around the sanctuary center. The residential neighborhoods were mixed, with residences, manufacturing activities, shops, and storage facilities, along with cultural activity areas like gymnasia.

Key moments in the history of Delos relevant to the discussion of urban growth on the island include:
1. The first Athenian dominion, which saw the creation of a maritime confederacy with Delos as its seat.
2. The period of independence, when Delos gained its independence and became a commercial center of the Cyclades.
3. The second Athenian dominion, during which the urbanization of Delos expanded rapidly, turning it into a boomtown.
4. The decision of the Roman Senate to make Delos a "duty-free" port in 167 BCE, which significantly impacted the commercial and urban development of the island. Mantha Zarmakoupi (2013). The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization (fieldwork seasons 2009-2010). ISAW Papers, 6.
column3: During the second Athenian dominion, the urbanization of Delos expanded from the area of the old sanctuary center outwards. New markets such as the Agora of the Hermaistai or the Competaliastai, the Agora of Theophrastos, and the Agora of the Delians were established at the borders of the sanctuary. The main port facilities expanded to the south and large storage facilities and shopping malls were created next to them. Residential neighborhoods developed around the sanctuary center and where good natural ports were created to complement the activities of the main port. The character of the neighborhoods was mixed with residences mingling with manufacturing activities, shops, storage facilities, and cultural activity loci such as the gymnasia (Zarmakoupi, 2013). The key moments in the history of Delos relevant to the discussion of urban growth on the island are the first Athenian dominion, the period of independence, and the second Athenian dominion (Zarmakoupi, 2013).

column1: How did the decision of the Roman Senate to make Delos a duty-free port in 167 BCE impact the commercial importance of the island, and what were the characteristics of the Quartier du Stade on Delos, including the structures located in this neighborhood?
column2:
The decision of the Roman Senate to make Delos a duty-free port in 167 BCE significantly impacted the commercial importance of the island. This decision prohibited the Athenians from levying import and export duties on trade passing through the harbor, attracting merchants and traders from various regions. Delos became a hub for trade between the East and the West, leading to a rapid economic development and demographic growth on the island.

The Quartier du Stade on Delos was a newly-formed neighborhood after 167 BCE, characterized by rapid urbanization and redevelopment. This neighborhood saw the construction of new houses, docksides, warehouses, and markets to accommodate the growing commercial activities on the island. The structures in this neighborhood, such as Houses IC and ID, were built reactively to fit the needs of the inhabitants and their commercial activities. The construction techniques, like mud brick walls, suggest that changes were implemented quickly without prior planning. The Quartier du Stade exemplifies the forces that shaped the city of Delos in this period, including economy, politics, and ideology. Mantha Zarmakoupi (2013). The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization (fieldwork seasons 2009-2010). ISAW Papers, 6.
column3: The decision of the Roman Senate to make Delos a duty-free port in 167 BCE led to a significant increase in the island's commercial importance. The island became an intermediary in Rome's commercial relations with the Hellenistic east, leading to rapid urbanization and unprecedented demographic growth. This is evidenced by the formation of new neighborhoods and massive constructions of docksides, warehouses, and markets (Zarmakoupi, 2013). One of the newly-formed neighborhoods during this period was the Quartier du Stade. This neighborhood was characterized by smaller port facilities that accommodated smaller boats and traded lighter goods such as perfumes, unguents, incense, gems, and dyes. Manufacturing facilities for dye and perfume have been identified in this neighborhood. The neighborhood also had storage facilities that responded to the needs of the commercial activities of Delos (Zarmakoupi, 2013).

column1: How did the architectural changes in Houses IC and ID on Delos reflect the integration of commercial needs into the domestic sphere, and what evidence suggests that the inhabitants of House ID may have used some rooms for commercial activities or rentals?
column2: The architectural changes in Houses IC and ID on Delos reflected the integration of commercial needs into the domestic sphere by creating spaces that could operate independently as workshops, businesses, storage places, or sleeping rooms, and potentially be rented out for such functions. The modifications included breaking down larger rooms into smaller ones or adding extra small rooms to accommodate commercial activities. In House ID, evidence suggests that some rooms were used for commercial activities or rentals, as certain rooms were grouped together and accessible through one entrance, potentially operating independently from the rest of the house. These rooms could have served as stores, workshops, or spaces for other commercial activities, indicating a blend of domestic and commercial functions within the household. Mantha Zarmakoupi (2013). The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization (fieldwork seasons 2009-2010). ISAW Papers, 6.
column3: The architectural changes in Houses IC and ID on Delos reflected the integration of commercial needs into the domestic sphere by creating spaces that could accommodate the commercial activities of the city. Owners made the most of the available space by adding small rooms outside the original plan of the houses, taking over part of the street, to create spaces for service, storage, and workshops. Evidence suggesting that the inhabitants of House ID may have used some rooms for commercial activities or rentals includes the modifications conducted at a later phase in House ID, which created groups of rooms that could operate independently as workshops, businesses, storage places, or sleeping rooms, and presumably could be rented out for such functions (M. Zarmakoupi, 2013).

column1: How did the modifications in Houses IC and ID on Delos compare to changes made in other houses in the Quartier de Skardhana, such as the Maison des Tritons and the Maison des Comédiens, in relation to the economic and social dynamics of the late Hellenistic period?
column2: The modifications in Houses IC and ID on Delos, as well as in other houses like the Maison des Tritons and the Maison des Comédiens in the Quartier de Skardhana, were made to create spaces that integrated commercial needs within the domestic sphere. Owners aimed to make profit without altering the spacious layout of the ground floor of their houses. These modifications included adding small rooms for service, storage, workshops, and even renting out spaces. The changes were reactive to the economic dynamics of late Hellenistic Delos, where individual needs shaped the available space within the houses to accommodate commercial activities. Mantha Zarmakoupi (2013). The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization (fieldwork seasons 2009-2010). ISAW Papers, 6.
column3: The modifications in Houses IC and ID on Delos, as described by M. Zarmakoupi in "The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization," were similar to changes made in other houses in the Quartier de Skardhana, such as the Maison des Tritons and the Maison des Comédiens. These changes were driven by the need to integrate commercial activities within the domestic sphere due to the dynamic economic microclimate of late Hellenistic Delos. In both cases, owners created new spatial arrangements to maximize the use of available space and to accommodate their commercial needs. This included the addition of small rooms outside the original plan of the houses, which were used for service, storage, and workshops. However, while the owners of the Maison des Tritons and the Maison des Comédiens sought to profit from their properties without altering the spacious layout of their houses, the owners of Houses IC and ID also changed the layout of their houses, such as breaking down larger rooms to form smaller ones.

column1: What does the archaeological evidence from Delos suggest about the diversity of economic activities and uses within residential neighborhoods during the late Hellenistic period, and how did the rapid urbanization of Delos impact the demographic growth and cultural diversity of the island's population?
column2: The archaeological evidence from Delos suggests that there was a diversity of economic activities within residential neighborhoods during the late Hellenistic period. The island experienced rapid urbanization, leading to significant demographic growth and cultural diversity in its population. The influx of traders and dealers from various regions, including Greece, Macedonia, the Hellenistic East, and Rome, contributed to the cosmopolitan character of the island. The urbanization expanded from the old sanctuary center outwards, creating new neighborhoods like the Quartier du Stade. This growth was fueled by economic development, political changes, and the unprecedented demographic increase on the island. The architecture of the houses in these neighborhoods reflected a mix of local building techniques with distinct religious and ethnic influences, showcasing a unique architectural koine. The urbanization of Delos during this period can be compared to boomtowns, with a sudden surge in population and economic activities. Mantha Zarmakoupi (2013). The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization (fieldwork seasons 2009-2010). ISAW Papers, 6.
column3: Archaeological evidence from Delos suggests a variety of economic activities within residential neighborhoods during the late Hellenistic period, including the production of perfume, purple dye, glass jewelry, sculpture, and terracotta figurines (Zarmakoupi, 2013). The rapid urbanization of Delos, which occurred between 167 BCE and the sacks of 88 and 69 BCE, resulted in significant demographic growth and cultural diversity. The island's population increased from about 1,500 to 2,000 during the period of independence to an estimated 15,000 during the period of the second Athenian dominion. The new residents were primarily from the eastern Mediterranean and the Italian peninsula, with some coming from as far away as south Yemen, contributing to the island's cosmopolitan character (Zarmakoupi, 2013).

column1: In what ways did the architectural layout and design of houses in the Quartier du Stade on Delos reflect the economic and social dynamics of the late Hellenistic period, and how were private initiatives and public benefactions involved in shaping the city of Delos during this time?
column2:
The architectural layout and design of houses in the Quartier du Stade on Delos reflected the economic and social dynamics of the late Hellenistic period by accommodating and complementing the commercial activities of the port. The smaller capacity of these houses catered to a different kind of commerce than that of the main port, focusing on goods like perfumes, unguents, incense, gems, and dyes. The smaller storage facilities integrated within the residences and next to manufacturing installations responded to the needs of the commercial activities of Delos and were closely related to the activities of the ports.

Private initiatives and public benefactions played a significant role in shaping the city of Delos during this time. Private initiatives financed public constructions that shaped the city, while public benefactions ignited development in the city. The hastiness in construction, as seen in the use of mud brick walls, suggests that changes were implemented reactively to fit the needs of the inhabitants and their commercial activities, rather than being planned in advance. This combination of private and public influences contributed to the rapid urbanization and development of Delos during the late Hellenistic period. Mantha Zarmakoupi (2013). The Quartier du Stade on late Hellenistic Delos: a case study of rapid urbanization (fieldwork seasons 2009-2010). ISAW Papers, 6.
column3: The architectural layout and design of houses in the Quartier du Stade on Delos reflected the economic and social dynamics of the late Hellenistic period in several ways. The provision for storage within the neighborhood was closely tied to the commercial activities of Delos, suggesting that the houses were designed to accommodate and complement these activities. The development of the area was driven by two main forces: the need for spaces that could support the commercial activities of the port, and private initiatives that financed public constructions. These private initiatives, along with public benefactions, played a significant role in shaping the city of Delos. Benefactions were a means of self-representation and promotion and contributed to the development of the sanctuary and city of Delos from early on. These benefactions must be understood in the context of competing claims over the growing importance of the international commerce of Delos (M. Zarmakoupi, 2013).

column1: What does Linked Open Data (LOD) encompass in the study of the ancient world?
column2: Linked Open Data (LOD) in the study of the ancient world encompasses approaches to the publication of digital resources that emphasize stability, relatively fine-grained access to intellectual content via public URIs, and re-usability. This is defined by the publication of machine-readable data and by publication under licenses that permit further copying of available materials. The focus is on making data accessible, reusable, and interconnected for research and study purposes.  ,"Current Practice in Linked Open Data for the Ancient World" ISAW Papers, vol. 7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/.
column3: Linked Open Data (LOD) in the study of the ancient world encompasses the creation of digital models for specific types of ancient and medieval data such as chronology, prosopography, geography, numismatics, text corpora, codicology, and 3D environments. It involves the use of LOD to digitally model the history of particular communities and their cultural heritage information. Projects like Syriaca.org use LOD to aggregate, relate, and publish historical data drawn from specific sources, integrating this data with the growing Web of Data. The LOD ancient studies community is constantly evolving as more projects link their data to one another, offering ever-expanding ways for a project to discover and contribute insights into the ancient world (David A. Michelson, ISAW Papers 20.10, 2021; Ryan Horne, ISAW Papers 20.2, 2021).

column1: How is the concept of Linked Open Data being applied in the study of ancient texts, literature, and artifacts?
column2: The concept of Linked Open Data is being applied in the study of ancient texts, literature, and artifacts through various projects and initiatives. These projects focus on making digital resources available with stability, fine-grained access via public URIs, and reusability through machine-readable data and licenses permitting further copying. Examples include the Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies, Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library, the Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration, and many others listed in the ISAW Papers publication. These projects aim to move from concept to implementation, showcasing results achieved by the mid-2013 to early 2014 timeframe.  ,"Current Practice in Linked Open Data for the Ancient World" ISAW Papers, vol. 7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/.
column3: The concept of Linked Open Data (LOD) is being applied in the study of ancient texts, literature, and artifacts through projects like Syriaca.org. As described by David A. Michelson in "Using Linked Open Data to Model Cultural Heritage Information," Syriaca.org uses LOD to aggregate, relate, and publish historical data drawn from Syriac sources, integrating this data with the growing Web of Data. The project structures its data around six classes of historical entities: persons, places, primary source texts, scholarly bibliographic citations, manuscripts, and keyword classifications. The Linked Data structure of the Syriaca.org knowledge graph is designed to facilitate searches across the graph which may not have been anticipated by the scholars who encoded any individual point of data. This approach allows for the modeling of historical information related to a particular group of cultural heritage communities.

column1: How are digital resources being made more accessible and reusable through the implementation of Linked Open Data practices?
column2: Digital resources are being made more accessible and reusable through the implementation of Linked Open Data (LOD) practices by emphasizing stability, providing fine-grained access to intellectual content via public URIs, and enabling reusability through the publication of machine-readable data and under licenses that permit further copying of available materials. By utilizing LOD, digital resources can be interconnected, allowing for easier discovery, integration, and reuse of data across various disciplines and projects in the study of the ancient world.  ,"Current Practice in Linked Open Data for the Ancient World" ISAW Papers, vol. 7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/.
column3: Linked Open Data (LOD) practices are being used to make digital resources more accessible and reusable by structuring and linking data in a way that allows for more comprehensive searches and analyses. For instance, the Syriaca.org project, as described by David A. Michelson in "Using Linked Open Data to Model Cultural Heritage Information", uses LOD to aggregate, relate, and publish historical data from Syriac sources, creating a digital knowledge graph that can be used for research in Syriac Studies. This graph can be queried and analyzed, and its structure facilitates searches across the graph. Similarly, Hannah Scates Kettler in "Linked Open Data for 3D Models and Environments" discusses how LOD can free 3D research from its 2D constraints, allowing for a more refined, transparent, and robust scholastic product. LOD also allows for the integration of 3D research data into other projects, contributing to the broader field of 3D research.

column1: How is the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World (ISAW) involved in the publication and distribution of the articles discussed in the text?
column2: The Institute for the Study of the Ancient World (ISAW) is involved in the publication and distribution of the articles discussed in the text by hosting the Ancient World Digital Library in partnership with the NYU Library. ISAW Papers, which is a publication of ISAW, includes articles that were considered for publication by ISAW staff and faculty members like Tom Elliott and Sebastian Heath. The articles are distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution License.  ,"Current Practice in Linked Open Data for the Ancient World" ISAW Papers, vol. 7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/.
column3: The Institute for the Study of the Ancient World (ISAW) is involved in the publication and distribution of articles through its digital scholarly journal, ISAW Papers. The journal publishes anonymously peer-reviewed articles as well as articles read and forwarded for publication by members of the ISAW faculty (ISAW Papers: Towards a Journal as Linked Open Data. Sebastian Heath. ISAW Papers 7.8 (2014)). It also serves as a venue for the publication of datasets related to ancient material evidence (P. Davoli and C. Miks. (2015). A New Roman Sword from Soknopaiou Nesos (El-Fayyum, Egypt). ISAW Papers 9 (2015)). Additionally, ISAW supports the distribution of information on digital and digitized antiquity through AWOL: The Ancient World Online, a project launched by Chuck Jones (Moving the Ancient World Online Forward. Tom Elliott and Chuck Jones. ISAW Papers 7.6 (2014)).

column1: What were the two meetings that led to the articles published in ISAW Papers 7, and who organized them?
column2: The two meetings that led to the articles published in ISAW Papers 7 were called the "Linked Ancient World Data Institute" (LAWDI). They were held at New York University's Institute for the Study of the Ancient World and at Drew University in early summer of 2012 and 2013, respectively. The meetings were organized by Tom Elliott, Sebastian Heath, and John Muccigrosso.  2014,"Prologue and Introduction" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.1, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-heath-muccigrosso/.
column3: The two meetings that led to the articles published in ISAW Papers 7 were held at New York University's Institute for the Study of the Ancient World and at Drew University in the early summers of 2012 and 2013. These meetings were titled "Linked Ancient World Data Institute" and were known by the acronym LAWDI. The context does not provide information on who organized these meetings. (Source: Prologue and Introduction. Tom Elliott, Sebastian Heath and John Muccigrosso ISAW Papers 7.1 (2014))

column1: What is Linked Open Data and what are some foundational texts that helped define and promote its principles?
column2:
Linked Open Data (LOD) is a set of best practices for sharing digital resources. It involves making data available on the public internet in a way that is structured, linked, and easily accessible for both humans and machines. Some foundational texts that helped define and promote the principles of LOD include:

1. Tim Berners-Lee's "Linked Data" of 2006, available at http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/LinkedData.html.
2. Tim Berners-Lee's "Cool URIs Don't Change," available at http://www.w3.org/Provider/Style/URI.
3. Sauerman et al. (2008) W3C Interest Group Note entitled "Cool URIs for the Semantic Web," available at http://www.w3.org/TR/cooluris/.
4. Tom Heath and Christian Bizer's book "Linked Data: Evolving the Web into a Global Data Space," available online at http://linkeddatabook.com/.

These texts provide insights into the principles and practices of LOD, emphasizing the importance of stable URIs, common vocabularies, and the use of RDF Triples to enable interoperability and data sharing.  2014,"Prologue and Introduction" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.1, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-heath-muccigrosso/.
column3: Linked Open Data (LOD) is a set of best practices for sharing digital resources, particularly open-licensed data in formats that computers can read, manipulate, and render. It encourages the sharing of data in a standard way using the Resource Description Framework (RDF), making it easy to share with others and refer to or link to others' datasets from within your own. Foundational texts that helped define and promote LOD's principles include Tim Berners-Lee's "Linked Data" (2006) and "Cool URIs Don't Change", as well as Sauerman et al.'s (2008) W3C Interest Group Note "Cool URIs for the Semantic Web". Tom Heath and Christian Bizer's 2011 book "Linked Data: Evolving the Web into a Global Data Space" also provides a detailed description of these ideas.

column1: Why is stability of published URIs emphasized in the context of Linked Open Data?
column2: The stability of published URIs is emphasized in the context of Linked Open Data because it ensures that the digital resources remain accessible and usable over time. By maintaining stable URIs, users can rely on the links to access specific information consistently, even as the web evolves. This practice is crucial for preserving the integrity and reliability of data shared through Linked Open Data principles.  2014,"Prologue and Introduction" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.1, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-heath-muccigrosso/.
column3: Stability of published URIs is emphasized in the context of Linked Open Data because it ensures that the resources remain accessible and reliable over time. This is particularly important for projects that publish individual URIs for all discrete resources, as endorsed at LAWDI (Elliott, Heath, and Muccigrosso, ISAW Papers 7.1). Stable URIs also facilitate the use of common vocabularies and machine readability, which are key for linking and harvesting data across different resources (Elliott, Heath, and Muccigrosso, ISAW Papers 7.1). Furthermore, the use of stable URIs in content management systems can significantly impact digital scholarship (McMichael, ISAW Papers 7.14).

column1: What is a "RDF Triple" and how is it used in the context of sharing digital resources?
column2: A triple is a statement of information in three parts: the subject, the predicate, and the object. In the context of sharing digital resources, RDF Triples are used to represent data in a machine-readable format using URIs for each element of the triple. This allows for the information to be linked and easily consumed by both humans and automated systems. RDF Triples play a crucial role in Linked Open Data (LOD) by providing a common format for representing diverse concepts published on the public internet, enabling greater compatibility between resources and facilitating data linking and analysis by third parties.  2014,"Prologue and Introduction" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.1, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-heath-muccigrosso/.
column3: An RDF Triple, part of the Resource Description Framework (RDF), is a statement of information in three parts: a subject, a predicate, and an object. The subject is the resource being described, the predicate describes the relationship, and the object is what the subject is referencing (Applying Linked Open Data Standards, Ryan Horne, ISAW Papers 20.2). This format is used to represent information about web resources and is a fundamental concept in the publication of reusable data on the public internet (Prologue and Introduction, Tom Elliott, Sebastian Heath and John Muccigrosso, ISAW Papers 7.1). In the context of sharing digital resources, RDF triples are used to encourage interoperability and are particularly efficient for serving, querying, and sharing archival material in an RDF triplestore (The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration, Christopher W. Blackwell and D. Neel Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5). The use of RDF triples is leading to greater compatibility between resources that generate them (Prologue and Introduction, Tom Elliott, Sebastian Heath and John Muccigrosso, ISAW Papers 7.1).

column1: How do triples play a role in providing a common format for representing diverse concepts published on the public Internet?
column2: Triples play a role in providing a common format for representing diverse concepts published on the public Internet by structuring information in three parts: the subject, the predicate, and the object. By using URIs for all three elements of a triple, information can be linked and shared across different resources. This allows for interoperability and compatibility between various datasets, enabling easier consumption and analysis by both humans and automated systems. The use of triples helps in creating a standardized format for representing information, making it more accessible and usable for a wider audience on the public Internet.  2014,"Prologue and Introduction" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.1, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-heath-muccigrosso/.
column3: Triples, specifically RDF triples, play a crucial role in providing a common format for representing diverse concepts published on the public Internet. They are fundamental to the publication of reusable data online, as they allow for the representation of information in three parts: subject, predicate, and object. This structure enables the linking of complex series of information and the representation of definitions distributed across the Internet (Tom Elliott, Sebastian Heath and John Muccigrosso, ISAW Papers 7.1). Furthermore, Syriaca.org uses RDF triples to define and disambiguate URIs for users, and the Linked Ancient World Data Initiative (LAWDI) uses them in creating a data ontology for the ancient world (David A. Michelson, ISAW Papers 20.10; Ryan Horne, ISAW Papers 20.2).

column1: How does Ptolemy's description of the Milky Way in Centaurus compare to modern images and charts of the region, and what discrepancies or accuracies can be identified?
column2: Ptolemy's description of the Milky Way in Centaurus includes details about specific stars and the density of the milk in that region. He mentions the positions of stars in relation to the milk and describes the milk as somewhat denser near the hind legs. When comparing Ptolemy's description to modern images and charts, discrepancies can be identified due to differences in the understanding of the Milky Way over time. For example, Ptolemy's description may not align perfectly with the actual positions of stars or the density of the Milky Way as we know it today. However, Ptolemy's general structure of the Milky Way and some of its fine details can still be recognized in modern images, showing some level of accuracy in his observations. Gonzalo L. Recio (2024). “The Almagest’s description of the Milky Way.” ISAW Papers 27.
column3: Ptolemy's description of the Milky Way in Centaurus, as detailed in Gonzalo L. Recio's ISAW Paper, is largely accurate when compared to modern images and charts of the region. He describes the Milky Way as passing through the legs of Centaurus and indicates that the "milk" is denser near the hind legs. However, he also notes that the region is dimmer than other parts of the Milky Way. The paper suggests that Ptolemy's use of stars to determine the limits of the Milky Way and areas of particular interest are generally very accurate, although there are some exceptions. For instance, there are discrepancies in the positions Ptolemy indicated for certain stars in other regions of the Milky Way.

column1: What are some key works cited in the text that provide further information on Linked Open Data and related concepts?
column2:
Some key works cited in the text that provide further information on Linked Open Data and related concepts are:

1. Tim Berners-Lee's "Linked Data" from 2006, available at http://www.w3.org/DesignIssues/LinkedData.html
2. Tim Berners-Lee's "Cool URIs Don't Change," available at http://www.w3.org/Provider/Style/URI
3. Sauerman et al. (2008) W3C Interest Group Note entitled "Cool URIs for the Semantic Web," available at http://www.w3.org/TR/cooluris/
4. Tom Heath and Christian Bizer's book "Linked Data: Evolving the Web into a Global Data Space," available online at http://linkeddatabook.com/

These works provide foundational texts and discussions that helped define and promote the principles of Linked Open Data.  2014,"Prologue and Introduction" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.1, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-heath-muccigrosso/.
column3: The text mentions the book "Linked Data: Evolving the Web into a Global Data Space" by Tom Heath and Christian Bizer as a detailed resource on Linked Open Data. It also refers to the work of Sebastian Heath on incorporating Linked Data into editorial work for the ISAW Papers publications. Another resource mentioned is the website http://linkeddata.org. The paper "Open Context and Linked Data" by Eric C. Kansa is also cited, discussing the use of Linked Data to annotate datasets using shared controlled vocabularies.

column1: What was one of the main takeaways from the 2012 Linked Ancient World Data Institute mentioned in the article?
column2: One of the main takeaways from the 2012 Linked Ancient World Data Institute, as mentioned in the article, was the need for a comprehensive bibliography of scholarly literature in the field of ancient studies that is both open and follows the principles of linked data. Phoebe Acheson 2013,"Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.2, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/acheson/.
column3: One of the main takeaways from the 2012 Linked Ancient World Data Institute, as mentioned by Phoebe Acheson in "Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies" (ISAW Papers 7.2, 2014), was the need for a comprehensive bibliography of scholarly literature in the field of ancient studies that is both open and follows the principles of linked data. This resource could facilitate scholarly work across many related sub-disciplines and increase discoverability of academic studies that mention specific subjects.

column1: How could a comprehensive bibliography of scholarly literature in ancient studies benefit scholarly work across various sub-disciplines?
column2: A comprehensive bibliography of scholarly literature in ancient studies that is open and follows the principles of linked data could benefit scholarly work across various sub-disciplines by facilitating scholarly research, increasing discoverability of academic studies, providing a robust controlled vocabulary, allowing for tagging citations with stable identifiers for various categories, enabling more comprehensive identification of bibliographic items on a topic, and facilitating the automatic feeding of scholarly citations into websites discussing topics. This resource could enhance collaboration, knowledge sharing, and interdisciplinary research within the field of ancient studies. Phoebe Acheson 2013,"Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.2, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/acheson/.
column3: A comprehensive bibliography of scholarly literature in ancient studies could facilitate scholarly work across various sub-disciplines by increasing the discoverability of academic studies that mention specific subjects. It could also provide a bridge between popular discussions of topics on the web and the more formal publications of the academic world, thereby making the field more relevant and accessible. The bibliography could include a robust controlled vocabulary, allowing for more comprehensive identification of bibliographic items on a topic and facilitating the automatic feeding of scholarly citations into websites discussing those topics. This could be particularly beneficial for scholars and students at smaller or less wealthy institutions which do not subscribe to indexes (Acheson, ISAW Papers 7.2, 2014).

column1: What was the rationale behind the placement and order of the outputs for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism, and how did this influence the design and assembly of the planetary mechanisms on the Superior Planet Plate?
column2: The rationale behind the placement and order of the outputs for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism was based on achieving accuracy in representing the planetary positions. The order of the outputs was determined by the period relations chosen for each planet, with the largest fixed gear for Jupiter, followed by Saturn and Mars. The output gears were arranged in the order Saturn, Jupiter, Mars to reflect the planetary order of the pointers on the mechanism. This influenced the design and assembly of the planetary mechanisms on the Superior Planet Plate by ensuring that the gears and tubes were arranged in a specific order to accurately represent the planetary positions as observed from Earth. Tony Freeth and Alexander Jones. 2012. The Cosmos in the Antikythera Mechanism. ISAW Papers, 4.
column3: The placement and order of the outputs for the superior planets in the Antikythera Mechanism were influenced by the need to fit the mechanisms into the available space and to avoid mechanical interference between the different planetary mechanisms. According to Freeth and Jones, the output gear for Saturn, the superior planet with the slowest motion, was closest to the front of the Mechanism, followed by Jupiter and then Mars. This arrangement resulted in bridges for the superior planet mechanisms that varied in height, with Saturn being the lowest, followed by Jupiter and Mars. This design allowed the superior planet mechanisms to fit into the remaining space between the Date Plate and the Superior Planet Plate. The authors also note that the angles of the planetary mechanisms relative to each other were immaterial, so long as they did not interfere with each other mechanically.

column1: What are some of the building blocks in place for bibliographic uses that could facilitate the construction of a comprehensive linked open bibliography for ancient studies?
column2: Some of the building blocks in place for bibliographic uses that could facilitate the construction of a comprehensive linked open bibliography for ancient studies include unique identifiers and controlled vocabularies from libraries, such as the Virtual International Authority File (OCLC) for names, the DOI for scholarly articles, the Library of Congress Subject Headings, and the Getty Center's controlled vocabularies for art and archaeology. These elements provide a foundation for creating a linked open bibliography for ancient studies. Phoebe Acheson 2013,"Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.2, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/acheson/.
column3: The building blocks for bibliographic uses that could facilitate the construction of a comprehensive linked open bibliography for ancient studies include standard numbers for monographs such as the OCLC number, which is linked open data friendly and provided by the open WorldCat database. The DOI is also a useful control number for scholarly articles and other publications. For controlled subject vocabularies, the Library of Congress Subject Headings are available as linked open data, and the Getty Center has plans to open access to its controlled vocabularies for art and archaeology. These building blocks are relevant to bibliographic citations as a whole, with no special focus on ancient world studies (Phoebe Acheson. ISAW Papers 7.2 (2014)).

column1: How does the article suggest individual scholars can contribute towards a linked open bibliography for ancient studies?
column2: The article suggests that individual scholars can contribute towards a linked open bibliography for ancient studies by exposing bibliographic citations on the open web in a format friendly towards linked data. Scholars can use tools like Zotero to export citations in BIBO format, create open-access bibliographies in Zotero, and include links to stable URIs for people, monographs, or journal articles when posting bibliographic citations in web environments. Additionally, scholars can follow good linking practices for bibliographic citations and embrace the semantic web to contribute to the creation of a comprehensive linked open bibliography for ancient studies. Phoebe Acheson 2013,"Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.2, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/acheson/.
column3: The article suggests that individual scholars can contribute towards a linked open bibliography for ancient studies by exposing their bibliographic citations on the open web, ideally in a format that is friendly towards linked data, especially if they are developing a scholarly internet-based project or publication. They can also use Zotero as a storage location for a bibliography that is presented as part of a digital project, following the model of the online bibliography on Evagrius Ponticus by Joel Kalvesmaki. Scholars are also encouraged to include links to the stable URIs for people, monographs, or journal articles if they are posting bibliographic citations in web environments (Acheson, ISAW Papers 7.2, 2014).

column1: In what way could a linked open bibliographic citation database for ancient studies benefit scholars and the broader public according to the article?
column2: A linked open bibliographic citation database for ancient studies could benefit scholars by facilitating scholarly work across various sub-disciplines, increasing the discoverability of academic studies, and providing a robust controlled vocabulary. It would allow for tagging citations with stable identifiers for various subjects, authors, historical figures, artifacts, and themes, making it easier to identify and access relevant bibliographic items. Additionally, it could serve as a bridge between popular discussions of ancient topics online and formal academic publications, thus enhancing outreach to the broader public and making academic research more accessible and relevant. Phoebe Acheson 2013,"Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.2, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/acheson/.
column3: According to Phoebe Acheson in "Linked Open Bibliographies in Ancient Studies," a linked open bibliographic citation database for ancient studies could benefit scholars and the broader public in several ways. It would provide a comprehensive resource for scholarly literature in the field of ancient studies, facilitating work across many related sub-disciplines and increasing discoverability of academic studies that mention specific subjects. It could also serve as a bridge between popular discussions of topics on the web and more formal academic publications. The database would include a robust controlled vocabulary, allowing for more comprehensive identification of bibliographic items on a topic and facilitating the automatic feeding of scholarly citations into websites discussing topics. This would be particularly beneficial for scholars at smaller or less wealthy institutions which do not subscribe to indexes. Furthermore, it would serve as a form of outreach to the broader public.

column1: What is the main goal of the Perseus Digital Library in terms of making its data available?
column2: The main goal of the Perseus Digital Library is to make all of its data available according to the best practices outlined by Heath and Bizer (2011) and to ensure that the URIs are stable and properly dereferenceable. They are working towards publishing stable URIs for various resources in the library and altering the representation of resource content to advertise its linkable features via RDF-A.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The main goal of the Perseus Digital Library, as outlined by Bridget Almas, Alison Babeu, and Anna Krohn in "Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" (ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014), is to make all of its data available according to the best practices of linked data. This involves careful consideration of the URIs used to name and address the Perseus texts, catalog metadata, and other data objects, ensuring these URIs are stable and properly dereferenceable. The library is also working towards full compliance with linked data best practices and plans to make its authority record data for classical authors available to the Virtual International Authority File.

column1: How does the Syriac text portray Hercules and his actions in relation to the Pillars of Hercules?
column2: The Syriac text mentions Hercules in relation to the Pillars of Hercules, specifically referring to the great labor, monetary expense, and effort he put into setting up these columns to ensure his memory would not be forgotten. The text describes how boats rush at the whirlpool of the sea near the Pillars and cannot return, highlighting the challenges Hercules faced. It also mentions Hercules' enduring of great labor and the humiliation of a great people. The text emphasizes the importance of leaving a memory through effort and action. A. McCollum. (2012). “A Syriac Fragment from ‘The Cause of All Causes’ on the Pillars of Hercules.” ISAW Papers 5.
column3: The Syriac text, specifically the passage from "The Cause of All Causes," portrays Hercules as a hero and prophet of the pagans who set up three columns or pillars, instead of the traditionally recognized two, at the edge of the world on an island called Gadeira. These pillars were intended to serve as a commemoration of Hercules, ensuring his memory would be carried into all generations of the world (A. McCollum, 2012, "A Syriac Fragment from 'The Cause of All Causes on the Pillars of Hercules," ISAW Papers 5).

column1: How are URIs structured in the Perseus Digital Library, and what is the significance of defining these URIs?
column2: URIs in the Perseus Digital Library are structured under the http://data.perseus.org URI prefix, followed by path components indicating the resource type and a unique identifier for the resource. The significance of defining these URIs lies in ensuring stability, proper dereferenceability, and adherence to Linked Data standards. By defining these URIs, the Perseus Digital Library can make its data linkable and discoverable, enhancing accessibility and interoperability within the digital classics community.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: In the Perseus Digital Library, URIs are structured with a prefix (http://data.perseus.org), followed by one or more path components indicating the resource type, and then a unique identifier for the resources, with an optional path component identifying a specific output format for the resource (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3). The library has released URIs for texts, citations, and bibliographic catalog records. The significance of defining these URIs is to ensure their stability and proper dereferencing, which is crucial for the library's goal of making all of its data available according to best practices.
