This approach also allows the library to publish URIs incrementally, given the large volume of resources and limited manpower, which benefits both their work and their community of users.

column1: What types of resources currently have published URIs in the Perseus Digital Library, and what formats are supported for citations and texts?
column2: In the Perseus Digital Library, currently published URIs are available for texts, citations, and bibliographic catalog records. The supported formats for citations are HTML and XML, while for full texts, only HTML is currently supported, with XML format becoming available soon.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The Perseus Digital Library has published URIs for texts, citations, and bibliographic catalog records (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014). The stable URIs for citations and texts leverage Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs. The currently supported data formats for citations are HTML and XML, while for full text URIs, HTML is the only currently supported format, but XML will be available soon (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014).

column1: How has the library of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World integrated digital resources into its collections?
column2: The library of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World has integrated digital resources into its collections by developing digital resources as a fundamental component of its collections. They have partnered with the NYU Library's Digital Library Technology Services team and ISAW's own Digital Programs department to acquire, describe, catalog, and make accessible a growing global corpus of digital scholarly resources. They have also launched initiatives like AWOL (The Ancient World Online) to index and describe digital and digitized antiquity, making these resources available to a wide audience through various publication channels. Additionally, they are seeking to enhance their current processes by using tools like Zotero to capture, annotate, and synchronize web resources for publication, thereby creating new dissemination channels for a broader set of audience use cases.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The library of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World (ISAW) has integrated digital resources into its collections by developing digital resources as a fundamental component of its collections. This includes the acquisition of traditional paper-based scholarship and the development of digital resources that integrate the world's oldest languages, scripts, and cultures with the newest technologies. ISAW has pursued this agenda in partnership with NYU Library's Digital Library Technology Services team and ISAW's own Digital Programs department. A key concern in this process has been the identification, description, cataloging, and accessibility of the growing global corpus of digital scholarly resources for the widest possible audiences. This is addressed by capturing and describing digital resources anywhere on the open web that integrates smoothly with existing and emerging library systems, with standard scholarly research management software, and with ISAW and NYU's public facing websites and digital publications (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014).

column1: How does the Perseus Digital Library combine Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs with URI standards to create meaningful URIs for texts and citations?
column2: The Perseus Digital Library combines Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs with URI standards by using semantically meaningful URIs for texts and citations. They create URIs that identify specific resources by appending identifiers to the CTS URNs. For example, they use URNs to specify the notional work, such as Homer's Iliad, and then add an edition identifier to specify the unique resource in the Perseus CTS inventory. By prefixing these URNs with the http://data.perseus.org URI prefix and path components, they create stable URIs that can be resolved to access the desired resources. This approach allows for precise identification and retrieval of texts and citations within the Perseus Digital Library.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The Perseus Digital Library combines Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs with URI standards to create semantically meaningful URIs for texts and citations. This is achieved by publishing all Perseus data URIs under the http://data.perseus.org URI prefix, followed by one or more path components indicating the resource type, then a unique identifier for the resources, and an optional path component identifying a specific output format for the resource. The Perseus stable URIs for citations and texts leverage CTS URNs, enabling the library to take advantage of the CTS data model while still supporting Linked Data standards. Individual passage citations can be retrieved at URIs which adhere to a specific syntax (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3 (2014)).

column1: How are catalog records distinguished from texts in terms of URIs in the Perseus Digital Library?
column2: Catalog records in the Perseus Digital Library are distinguished from texts in terms of URIs by including the 'catalog' path element in the URI. For example, the URI for a catalog record would look like: http://data.perseus.org/catalog/<textgroup urn>[/format], while the URI for a text itself would not include the 'catalog' path element.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: In the Perseus Digital Library, catalog records are distinguished from texts by the use of a 'catalog' path element in their URIs. This is explained in the paper "Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" by Bridget Almas, Alison Babeu, and Anna Krohn. The URI for a catalog record can be distinguished from that of the text itself by the 'catalog' path element. For example, the canonical URIs for objects in the CTS hierarchy for Homer's Iliad include 'catalog' in their path: http://data.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012, http://data.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001, http://data.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-grc1, and http://data.perseus.org/catalog/urn:cts:greekLit:tlg0012.tlg001.perseus-eng1.

column1: What are the works cited in the article, and how do they relate to the content discussed in the Perseus Digital Library?
column2:
The works cited in the article are:

1. Blackwell, Christopher and Neel Smith (2012). An overview of the CTS URN notation.
2. Heath, Tom and Christian Bizer (2011). Linked Data: Evolving the Web into a Global Data Space.

These works are related to the content discussed in the Perseus Digital Library as they provide foundational information and standards for the implementation of Linked Data practices, specifically in relation to the use of Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs and the broader concept of Linked Data. The Perseus Digital Library is working towards making its data available according to the best practices outlined in these works, ensuring stable URIs, proper dereferencing, and compliance with Linked Data standards.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The works cited in the article are "Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" by Bridget Almas, Alison Babeu, and Anna Krohn, and "Linked Open Data for Greek and Latin Authors and Works" by Babeu and Dilley. These works discuss the efforts of the Perseus Digital Library to make its data available according to best practices, including the use of stable and properly dereferenceable URIs. They also discuss the library's use of Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs to leverage the CTS data model while still supporting Linked Data standards. The articles further detail the ongoing work on authors, names, place entities, Greek and Latin lexical entities, and artifacts and images. The papers also mention the library's plans for future efforts, including a variety of annotation types.

column1: How has the Geolat project been funded and what are the future funding plans?
column2: The project was initially funded by Fondazione Compagnia di San Paolo, a bank foundation, in 2013. Moving forward, the Geolat research group planned to search for new EU calls under the EU research framework "Horizon 2020" starting in January 2014. Private funding was also going to be sought. Maurizio Lana 2014,"Geolat: Geography for Latin Literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.11, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/lana/.
column3: The Geolat project initially received funding in 2013 from the Fondazione Compagnia di San Paolo, a bank foundation, after a blind peer evaluation by the European Science Foundation. This grant allowed for a prototypical and investigating phase of the project. In 2012 and 2013, the project also sought funds by submitting proposals to EU ERC Synergy calls, and while it was awarded a B score indicating 'top scientific level', the funding went to other projects deemed more appealing. Looking ahead, with the start of the EU research framework Horizon 2020 in January 2014, the Geolat research group planned to search for new EU calls and also seek private funding (Geolat: Geography for Latin Literature. Maurizio Lana. ISAW Papers 7.11 (2014)).

column1: How are URIs currently published in the user interfaces of the Perseus Digital Library for texts, citations, and catalog records?
column2: URIs for texts and citations are included in the "Data Identifiers" widget that appears on any text display in the Perseus Digital Library. For catalog records, the URIs are displayed at the top of each catalog display.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: In the Perseus Digital Library, URIs for texts and citations are included in the Data Identifiers widget which appears on any text display. For the catalog records, the URIs appear on the top of each catalog display. The URIs themselves are currently published in the user interfaces of the Perseus Digital Library (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, "Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library", ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014).

column1: What is the default response for URI requests in the Perseus Digital Library, and how are requests for specific formats handled?
column2: The default response for any URI request in the Perseus Digital Library, when the HTTP Headers indicate that the calling client accepts text/html, is a redirect to the HTML display for the page of the requested resource in the Perseus user interface. Requests for specific supported formats, such as XML for citations or ATOM for catalog records, can be made by appending a path element for the format to the resource URI. The response for these requests will typically be the resource contents in the requested format, along with an HTTP 200 response code.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The default response for any URI request in the Perseus Digital Library is a redirect, specifying the HTTP 302 response code, to the HTML display for the page for the requested resource in the corresponding Perseus user interface (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014). Requests for specific supported formats, such as xml for citations and atom for catalog records, can be made by appending a path element for the format to the resource URI. The response for these requests will typically be the resource contents in the requested format, along with an HTTP 200 response code (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014).

column1: What are the future plans for enabling data sharing initiatives and compliance with linked data best practices in the Perseus Digital Library?
column2: The future plans for enabling data sharing initiatives and compliance with linked data best practices in the Perseus Digital Library include expanding the authority record data for classical authors to the Virtual International Authority File (VIAF). This expansion will contribute to VIAF's name clusters, adding different forms of authors' names and aiding in building international authorities useful to libraries and scholars. Additionally, the Perseus Digital Library aims to provide links to VIAF clusters to make more author information available and further develop the Semantic Web.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The Perseus Digital Library is working towards making all of its data available according to the best practices outlined by Heath and Bizer (2011). This includes careful consideration of the URIs used to name and address the Perseus texts, catalog metadata, and other data objects to ensure stability and proper dereferencing. Future plans also involve more extensive use of data structured by the work creator author triplet, and further integration with other forms of linked data, such as geographical and prosopographical data. The Perseus Digital Library team also hopes that the knowledge base might allow fellow librarians and scholars to update and correct the catalog metadata and link to it more easily (Almas, Babeu, and Krohn, ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014; Babeu and Dilley, ISAW Papers 20.9, 2021).

column1: How does the Perseus Digital Library contribute to the Virtual International Authority File and what is the significance of this contribution for libraries and scholars?
column2: The Perseus Digital Library contributes its authority record data for classical authors to the Virtual International Authority File (VIAF). This contribution helps expand the VIAF name clusters by adding different forms of a given author’s name, enhancing the international authorities useful to libraries and scholars. It also assists in providing links to VIAF clusters, making more information about an author available and supporting the further development of the Semantic Web.  2014,"Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.3, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/almas-babeu-krohn/.
column3: The Perseus Digital Library has made their authority record data for classical authors available to the Virtual International Authority File (VIAF), as mentioned in "Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" by Bridget Almas, Alison Babeu, and Anna Krohn (ISAW Papers 7.3, 2014). This contribution is significant for libraries and scholars as it allows for the updating and correction of catalog metadata and facilitates easier linking to it. This is particularly beneficial in the context of global library services like VIAF, which combines multiple authority files into a single, internationally accessible name authority service.

column1: What formats will the data be published in to ensure accessibility and interoperability with other linked data on the web?
column2: The data from the Ur of the Chaldees Project will be published in stable URIs and RDF/XML, JSON, and/or other machine-readable references. It will be connected to some version of ArchaeoML and/or CIDOC-CRM wherever possible. The goal is to emulate the format used by Open Context. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The data can be published in various formats to ensure accessibility and interoperability with other linked data on the web. For instance, Rebecca M. Seifried in "Linked Open Data for the Uninitiated" mentions the importance of using the proper file format and determining which specific types of data will be relevant to a broader audience. Daniel E.J. Pett in "Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" mentions the use of JSON, XML, CSV, or KML representations. In "The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration," Christopher W. Blackwell and D. Neel Smith suggest the use of an RDF triplestore for serving, querying, and sharing the archival material, and a combination of XML, XSLT, and CSS for data presentation. Hannah Scates Kettler in "Linked Open Data for 3D Models and Environments" suggests saving the 3D data and the associated metadata as a spreadsheet, Comma Separated Value text file, JSON, or XML file. Bridget Almas, Alison Babeu, and Anna Krohn in "Linked Data in the Perseus Digital Library" mention the use of RDF/XML and JSON-LD formats.

column1: What are the main aims of the Herculaneum Graffiti Project?
column2: The main aims of the Herculaneum Graffiti Project are to digitize handwritten wall-inscriptions from the first century AD found in Herculaneum and to provide a resource for studying these graffiti in the context of their location within the ancient city.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project, led by Rebecca Benefiel and Sara Sprenkle, has two main objectives. The first is to digitize hundreds of handwritten wall-inscriptions from the first century AD. The second is to provide a resource that will allow these graffiti to be studied in the context of their location in the ancient city of Herculaneum. The project aims to understand these inscriptions as textual artifacts within a larger social framework for communication, rather than simply brief texts or isolated markings. The project also seeks to record and highlight the presence of figural graffiti, which were drawings incised into wall-plaster in the same manner as textual messages (The Herculaneum Graffiti Project. ISAW Papers 7.4, 2014).

column1: How many texts were preserved at the archaeological site of Herculaneum, and what kind of content do they feature?
column2: Roughly 250 texts were preserved at the archaeological site of Herculaneum. These texts feature a variety of content, including greetings to friends, grocery lists, drawings of gladiators, comments on philosophers, and more.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The archaeological site at Herculaneum preserved roughly 250 texts, according to Benefiel and Sprenkle's Herculaneum Graffiti Project (ISAW Papers 7.4, 2014). These texts, written on the walls of various types of buildings, feature a wide range of content. They include everything from greetings to friends and grocery lists to drawings of gladiators and comments on philosophers.

column1: How does EAGLE plan to make connections within its Best Practice Network (BPN) and with other projects like Wikidata and Wikisource?
column2: EAGLE plans to make connections within its Best Practice Network (BPN) and with other projects like Wikidata and Wikisource by linking its data to the Linked Ancient World Data to enrich the possibility of discovering scholarly significant connections among scientific databases. Additionally, EAGLE aims to provide stable Trismegistos URIs to each inscription for clear and univocal references that can be used in printed publications, linking outside the web. Furthermore, EAGLE intends to converge all geographical information to Trismegistos Places and link them following the Pelagios Cookbook to Pleiades, expanding the richness of possible links to geographical information exponentially. Pietro Maria Liuzzo 2014,"The Europeana Network of Ancient Greek and Latin Epigraphy (EAGLE)" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.12, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/liuzzo.
column3: EAGLE plans to make connections within its Best Practice Network (BPN) and with other projects like Wikidata and Wikisource by developing a platform to search and browse inscriptions and by setting up a Wikibase MediaWiki for the enrichment and curation of epigraphic images and texts. The project aims to link its data to the Linked Ancient World Data to discover scholarly significant connections among scientific databases. EAGLE also plans to provide a stable Trismegistos URI to each inscription and have all geographical information converge to Trismegistos Places. Furthermore, EAGLE is developing a mobile application to enable users to get metadata about inscriptions they find on location by sending in a picture to the EAGLE portal. This information is according to Pietro Maria Liuzzo in "The Europeana Network of Ancient Greek and Latin Epigraphy (EAGLE)" (ISAW Papers 7.12, 2014).

column1: How does the Herculaneum Graffiti Project aim to move away from viewing graffiti as simply brief texts or isolated markings?
column2: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project aims to move away from viewing graffiti as simply brief texts or isolated markings by understanding these messages as textual artifacts within a larger social framework for communication. They aim to provide a resource that enables the graffiti to be studied in the context of their location in the ancient city of Herculaneum. Additionally, the project aims to record and highlight the presence of figural graffiti, which were drawings incised into wall-plaster in the same manner as textual messages but were not systematically recorded.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project aims to move away from viewing graffiti as simply brief texts or isolated markings by understanding these messages as textual artifacts within a larger social framework for communication. The project seeks to digitize hundreds of handwritten wall-inscriptions from the first century AD and provide a resource that enables these graffiti to be studied in the context of their location in the ancient city of Herculaneum. The project also includes the recording and highlighting of figural graffiti, drawings incised into wall-plaster in the same manner as textual messages. The project's search engine allows researchers to search for graffiti in multiple ways, including by location, class of drawing, or text/keyword, providing a more comprehensive understanding of these inscriptions (The Herculaneum Graffiti Project. ISAW Papers 7.4, 2014).

column1: What is the potential benefit of publishing schema.org data for BMCR?
column2: The potential benefit of publishing schema.org data for BMCR is to enable linking to all formats of a particular book reviewed in BMCR. By using WorldCat identities for books and incorporating them into the schema.org data, it may increase the utility of BMCR's data, allowing for easier access to reviews regardless of the format of the book. Camilla MacKay 2014,"Bryn Mawr Classical Review" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.13, .
column3: The potential benefit of publishing schema.org data for Bryn Mawr Classical Review (BMCR) is not clearly defined, but it is suggested that it could enable the automatic linking of BMCR reviews to relevant books in a library catalog, regardless of the format of the book. This could be achieved by using the WorldCat ID number that BMCR has been using for several years to pull citations from WorldCat. The cost of implementing this is low, but the exact benefits for BMCR, its readers, or searchers are unclear (Bryn Mawr Classical Review. Camilla MacKay. ISAW Papers 7.13 (2014)).

column1: Who suggested the publication of this article in ISAW Papers, and under what license is the article distributed?
column2: The article was suggested for publication by Alexander Jones as a member of the ISAW faculty. The article is distributed under the terms of the Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International license. Tables of Synodic Events from -800 to 1650 Using Modern and Almagest Models
column3: The authors of the article, Alexander Jones and John Steele, likely suggested its publication in ISAW Papers, as the journal publishes anonymously peer-reviewed articles as well as articles read and forwarded for publication by members of the ISAW faculty. The article is distributed under a Creative Commons Attribution (CC-BY) license, as stated in "ISAW Papers: Towards a Journal as Linked Open Data" by Sebastian Heath.

column1: How does the Herculaneum Graffiti Project collaborate with EAGLE, and what contributions will be made to EAGLE through this collaboration?
column2: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project collaborates with EAGLE, a federation of epigraphic databases, to make all Greek and Latin inscriptions through the sixth century CE available and publicly accessible online. The fieldwork and analysis conducted by the Herculaneum Graffiti Project will allow for detailed contributions to EAGLE, where a comprehensive set of metadata for each inscription will be available. The HGP website will provide a complementary way to search for graffiti and will display basic information for these inscriptions, each with a link to the respective entry in EAGLE.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project (HGP) collaborates with EAGLE, the Electronic Archive of Greek and Latin Epigraphy, by contributing detailed metadata for each inscription found during their fieldwork and analysis in Herculaneum. This information will be made available on EAGLE's platform, which aims to make all Greek and Latin inscriptions through the sixth century CE accessible online. The HGP website will also provide a complementary way to search for graffiti and will display basic information for these inscriptions, each with a link to the respective entry in EAGLE. This collaboration is part of HGP's objectives to reexamine inscriptions, record their physical data, and make these inscriptions widely accessible via digital publication online (The Herculaneum Graffiti Project. ISAW Papers 7.4, 2014).

column1: How does the Herculaneum Graffiti Project plan to provide a solution for organizing, storing, and retrieving non-textual inscriptions?
column2: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project plans to provide a solution for organizing, storing, and retrieving non-textual inscriptions by creating a search engine that allows researchers to search for graffiti in multiple ways. Researchers will have the ability to search for figural graffiti by location, class of property, type of drawing, or by text or keyword. Additionally, the project will offer clickable hotspots at locations where ancient graffiti are present, providing all graffiti in that location, both textual and figural.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project plans to provide a solution for organizing, storing, and retrieving non-textual inscriptions by digitizing hundreds of handwritten wall-inscriptions from the first century AD and creating a resource that allows these graffiti to be studied in their original location context. The project also aims to record and highlight the presence of figural graffiti, which are drawings incised into wall-plaster in the same manner as textual messages. The project's search engine will allow researchers to search for graffiti in multiple ways, including by location and by class of drawing. The project works in collaboration with EAGLE, a federation of epigraphic databases, to make all Greek and Latin inscriptions through the sixth century CE available and publicly accessible online (The Herculaneum Graffiti Project. ISAW Papers 7.4, 2014).

column1: Who are some of the authors contributing to ISAW Papers 18, and what are their areas of expertise?
column2:
Some of the authors contributing to ISAW Papers 18 and their areas of expertise are:

1. Gina Konstantopoulos - Expertise in Old Babylonian Literary Texts, focusing on wise women and benevolent magic.
2. Rita Lucarelli - Expertise in Ancient Egyptian Texts, specifically focusing on the magician as a literary figure.
3. Ainsley Hawthorn - Expertise in analyzing sexual and celestial symbolism in ancient texts, specifically in "Lugalbanda and the Anzu Bird."
4. Edward Love - Expertise in comparing the narration of magical practices in Setne I and II with the so-called Demotic and Greek Magical Papyri.
5. Mark Roblee - Expertise in the ancient Egyptian pḥ-nṯr oracle and its connection to the "Mithras Liturgy" in Late Roman Egypt.
6. Philippe Matthey - Expertise in deciphering the "Lecanomancy" in the Alexander Romance, transitioning from cult practice to magical ritual.
7. Gil Renberg - Expertise in Incubation in Demotic Literature.
8. Elena Chepel - Expertise in exploring oracles and post-truth politics in Aristophanes.
9. Lucas Livingston - Expertise in the magical aspects of alcohol in antiquity, focusing on fermentation, intoxication, metamorphosis, and madness.
10. Meredith Warren - Expertise in sensory analysis of divine interaction in Revelation 10:8–10. Franziska Naether. 2020. Cult Practices in Ancient Literatures: Egyptian, Near Eastern and Graeco-Roman Narratives in a Cross-Cultural Perspective. Proceedings of a Workshop at the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World, New York, May 16-17, 2016. ISAW Papers 18.
column3: Franziska Naether, from Leipzig University/Stellenbosch University, is an author who contributed to ISAW Papers 18. Her area of expertise is not explicitly mentioned in the context, but she edited a collection titled "Cult Practices in Ancient Literatures: Egyptian, Near Eastern and Graeco-Roman Narratives in a Cross-Cultural Perspective." This suggests her expertise might be in the study of ancient cultures and their literature, particularly in relation to cult practices.

column1: What search capabilities have been designed by the Herculaneum Graffiti Project for researchers to search for graffiti in multiple ways?
column2:
The search capabilities designed by the Herculaneum Graffiti Project for researchers to search for graffiti in multiple ways include:

1. Searching by location: Researchers can search for graffiti by clicking on one or more properties directly on a map of the site or selecting a property from a pull-down menu.
2. Searching by class of property: Researchers can search for graffiti by class of property (house, tavern, shop, or workshop) to find examples in that particular category of space.
3. Searching by type of drawing: Researchers can search for graffiti by type of drawing, such as human motifs, animal motifs, boats, etc. Results will list appropriate examples and provide a map of their locations.
4. Traditional search by text or keyword: Researchers can execute a search by text or keyword to find examples that match the search terms, with a map displaying the locations of all results.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project has designed a search engine that allows researchers to search for graffiti in multiple ways. Researchers can search for graffiti by location, either by clicking on a map of the site or selecting a property from a pull-down menu. They can also search by class of property (house, tavern, shop, or workshop), which will return all examples found in that category of space. Additionally, researchers can search for all figural graffiti or by class of drawing (human motifs, animal motifs, boats, etc.). Finally, there is the traditional search by text or keyword. The search results will provide a list of examples that match the search terms, as well as a map that displays the locations of all results (The Herculaneum Graffiti Project. ISAW Papers 7.4, 2014).

column1: What is the current status of the Herculaneum Graffiti Project, and what prototype is currently available for researchers to access?
column2: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project was under construction in 2014, with its first field season planned for the summer of that year. At that time, a working prototype limited to one city-block or insula in Pompeii, specifically Insula I.8, was available for researchers to access. This prototype showcased the search capabilities and the format in which results would be displayed, drawing on the graffiti of Pompeii, Insula I.8. The Herculaneum portion of the project was expected to be available soon after the initial work in Pompeii.  2014,"The Herculaneum Graffiti Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.4, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/benefiel-sprenkle/.
column3: The Herculaneum Graffiti Project, led by Rebecca Benefiel and Sara Sprenkle, was under construction and was set to have its first field season in summer 2014, according to ISAW Papers 7.4 (2014). The project aims to digitize hundreds of handwritten wall-inscriptions from the first century AD and provide a resource for studying these graffiti in the context of their location in the ancient city of Herculaneum. A prototype of graffiti within Insula 8 at Pompeii is available for researchers to access. The project also works in collaboration with EAGLE, a federation of epigraphic databases, to make all Greek and Latin inscriptions through the sixth century CE available and publicly accessible online.

column1: What is the Homer Multitext project and what is its main goal?
column2: The Homer Multitext (HMT) project is an international collaboration focused on recovering and documenting the history of Greek epic poetry. The project primarily works with primary source documents such as fragmentary papyri from late Antiquity and annotated Byzantine codices of the Homeric Iliad. The main goal of the project is to generate and manage data including image files, transcriptions, translations of Greek and Latin texts, commentary texts, and their relationships. The project aims to integrate RDF triples into its workflow to link projects, capture and integrate data, and enhance internal use of the data.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: The Homer Multitext (HMT) project is an international collaboration aimed at recovering and documenting the history of Greek epic poetry based on primary source documents, particularly the fragmentary papyri from late Antiquity and the annotated Byzantine codices of the Homeric Iliad. The main goal of the project is to generate data consisting of image files, transcriptions and translations of Greek and Latin texts in poetry and prose, commentary texts, and relationships among these. The project has developed a digital library architecture called CITE for managing this work. The project was initiated by Christopher Blackwell and Neel Smith, who are among the project architects (ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014).

column1: How does the article suggest integrating different data from various web resources in the field of archaeology?
column2: The article suggests integrating different data from various web resources in the field of archaeology by using the 'Virtual International Authority File' (VIAF) and the 'FOAF Vocabulary' (Friend of a Friend) as basic building blocks. These tools focus on persons as primary entities in virtual communication, allowing for the transversal of disciplinary boundaries and the linking of various resources. Additionally, the integration involves organizing data into graphic representations (area feature types in GIS) and synchronizing different data through foreign-key mapping to correspond with GIS features. This approach aims to create geo-referenced web-resources that allow users to access and work with different types of data simultaneously. Tsoni Tsonev 2014,"Integrating Historical-Geographic Web-resources" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.29, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/tsonev/.
column3: The articles suggest that integrating different data from various web resources in the field of archaeology could be achieved through the use of Linked Open Data standards and practices, as well as the organization of data into geo-referenced web resources (Tsonev, ISAW Papers 7.29, 2014). This would allow users to retrieve and work with data from different sources simultaneously. However, the articles also highlight the challenges of this approach, such as the highly specialized nature of excavation data (Kansa, ISAW Papers 7.10, 2014) and the fact that many digital resources and databases relevant to archaeology are not well-integrated with one another (Chen and Folsom, ISAW Papers 20.12, 2021).

column1: How does the Homer multitex project manage its data and what digital library architecture has it developed?
column2: The project manages its data using a digital library architecture called CITE for Collections, Indices, Texts, and Extensions. This architecture is designed to handle image files, transcriptions, translations of Greek and Latin texts, commentary texts, and relationships among these data types. The project has integrated RDF triples into its workflow and architecture to link projects, capture and integrate data, and manage internal use efficiently. The separation of concerns is a key aspect of managing the diverse and evolving data, with different archival data formats used for editing, building, integrating, and publishing the data. The project uses tools like Gradle build-system, custom scripts, and RDF triples for various tasks such as editing, testing, integrating, and serving data. The CITE architecture ensures a clean separation of concerns between archival data, served data, network services, and end-user applications.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: The project manages its data by planning for the data creation, curating the data by selecting appropriate file formats, and archiving the data. It also collects and maintains 3D archaeological data. The digital library architecture that the project has developed is called CITE, which stands for Collections, Indices, Texts and Extensions. This information was developed to manage the work since 2001 (Christopher W. Blackwell and D. Neel Smith. ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014). Additionally, the project uses Linked Open Data to support the Semantic Web and the specific requirements for 3D data curation and data linking (Hannah Scates Kettler. ISAW Papers 20.5, 2021).

column1: How has the integration of RDF triples benefited the Homer Multitext project?
column2: The integration of RDF triples has benefited the Homer Multitext project by providing a means of linking between projects, capturing and integrating the project's data for internal use, and enabling efficient management of the large, diverse, and evolving body of data generated by the project. RDF triples have allowed for a clean separation of concerns, making it easier to manage scholarly activities, archival data formats, and presentation formats. Additionally, RDF triples have facilitated the publication, serving, querying, and sharing of data, making it more efficient and broadly useful. The use of RDF has also enabled the project to avoid complex processing and clever solutions, leading to a more straightforward and forward-looking approach to data management.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: The integration of RDF triples into the Homer Multitext project has significantly improved the management and integration of the project's diverse and evolving body of data, according to Christopher W. Blackwell and D. Neel Smith in their paper "The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration". The simplicity and flexibility of RDF, along with its freely available tools and widespread support, have allowed the project to effectively handle data from a wide range of contributors, from first-year Greek students to tenured professors at major universities. The use of RDF has also facilitated the creation of a test-driven environment for a publication cycle of edit, test, integrate, compile, serve, and format. Furthermore, the use of RDF triples has enabled the efficient serving, querying, and sharing of archival material through an RDF triplestore.

column1: Why is separation of concerns important in integrating a large body of data in the project?
column2: Separation of concerns is important in integrating a large body of data in the project because it allows for a clean and organized division of different scholarly activities. By separating activities cleanly and associating each with an appropriate archival data format, such as TEI-XML for editing texts, tabular formats for analysis, and RDF triples for serving and sharing data, the project can efficiently manage the diverse and evolving data generated by a widely distributed group of scholars. This approach ensures that each aspect of the project can be handled independently, leading to better organization, easier maintenance, and improved collaboration among scholars at different stages of their careers.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: Separation of concerns is important in integrating a large body of data in a project because it allows for the management of a diverse and evolving dataset, which may be under development by a widely distributed group of scholars at various stages of their careers. This approach ensures that each aspect of the project is handled independently, allowing for more efficient and effective data integration. This is particularly important when dealing with complex projects that involve multiple contributors and different types of data (Blackwell and Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5, 2014).

column1: How is a "text" defined in the context of the project, and how does the OHCO2 model play a role in this definition?
column2: In the context of the project, a "text" is defined as an "ordered hierarchy of citation objects." This definition follows the OHCO2 model, which prioritizes units of citation over any other hierarchy. The OHCO2 model ensures the most important scholarly activity, which is citation and retrieval. This model allows for accommodating any other content elements or orthogonal views of a text to a greater or lesser degree of granularity, depending on editorial decisions about citation.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: A "text" in the context of the project is defined as a work that has been assigned identifiers for its work-group, work, and version, and has a unique identifier for each of its parts, which may or may not be in a hierarchy. The contents of these parts are not expected to change, making the text canonically citable (Koentges et al., ISAW Papers 20.8). The OHCO2 model is implemented in the CITE architecture through the Canonical Text Services protocol, which defines a structure for a catalog, a small number of valid requests for discovery and retrieval, and the format of responses to those requests (Blackwell and Smith, ISAW Papers 7.5).

column1: How does the project use inferencing and RDF to capture relationships between data objects?
column2: The project uses RDF (Resource Description Framework) to capture relationships between data objects by representing the data as RDF triples. These triples consist of subject-predicate-object statements that describe the relationships between different entities in the data. By using RDF, the project can explicitly define and store relationships between objects, such as texts, collections, and images, in a structured and machine-readable format. This allows for efficient querying, retrieval, and integration of data objects based on their relationships, enabling the project to manage and work with a large, diverse, and evolving body of data effectively.  2014,"The Homer Multitext and RDF-Based Integration" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.5, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/blackwell-smith/.
column3: The project uses RDF (Resource Description Framework) to model data in terms of relationships between entities, properties, and classes. This is done by forming statements that consist of three parts: entity A has a relation or property B with entity or predicate C, where A, B, and C are explicitly referenced by identifiers (Gabriel Bodard, ISAW Papers 20.4, 2021). This structure allows for the capture of relationships between data objects. The project also uses inferencing to establish, leverage, and build upon existing relationships between cultural heritage data, which is essential for building context and connection between scholarly datasets (Hannah Scates Kettler, ISAW Papers 20.5, 2021).

column1: What is the mission of the library of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World?
column2: The mission of the library of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World is not only to acquire traditional paper-based scholarship but also to develop digital resources as a fundamental component of its collections. It aims to integrate the world’s oldest languages, scripts, and cultures with the newest technologies.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The mission of the library of the Institute for the Study of the Ancient World (ISAW) is to not only acquire traditional paper-based scholarship but also to develop digital resources as a fundamental component of its collections. This involves integrating the world's oldest languages, scripts, and cultures with the newest technologies. The library aims to bring a vast array of documents, databases, websites, and other digital resources within the reach of its faculty, students, and visiting scholars in an organized and useful manner, continuously updated. This is to facilitate scholarly work across many related sub-disciplines and increase discoverability of academic studies that mention specific subjects (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014; Acheson, ISAW Papers 7.2, 2014).

column1: How did Jones support the goal of making digital and digitized antiquity accessible through AWOL?
column2: Jones supported the goal of making digital and digitized antiquity accessible through AWOL by launching AWOL in 2009 as an extension to Abzu, a guide to networked open access data relevant to the study and public presentation of the Ancient Near East and the Ancient Mediterranean world. AWOL has become the primary source of information on digital and digitized antiquity, indexing and describing scholarly resources, open access serial publications, born digital projects, and repositories of digitized scholarship related to antiquity. It reaches its audience through a blog, email syndication, and social media outlets, making the information immediately available to a wide audience. Additionally, Jones proposed enhancements to AWOL to maintain core delivery mechanisms while adding additional publication channels and streamlining content capture and preparation through automation and structured databases.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: Jones supported the goal of making digital and digitized antiquity accessible through AWOL by identifying relevant web content and manually copying it into the AWOL blog, which is hosted by Google's Blogger service. He edited the content as necessary and then published it, making it immediately available to AWOL's blog audience over the World-Wide Web. Blogger then pushed summary information about each publishing update to Google's Feedburner service, which automatically published both an update feed and a daily email digest. AWOL reached its audience through the blog and via syndication of the news feed from the blog to email and social media outlets (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014).

column1: What are the proposed enhancements to AWOL mentioned in the article?
column2: The proposed enhancements to AWOL mentioned in the article include maintaining the core delivery mechanisms via the existing blog and Feedburner, adding additional publication channels via NYU library systems and OCLC Worldcat, streamlining and improving content capture and preparation through automation, and using a structured, collaborative web database designed for web and bibliographic citation. Additionally, the enhancements involve using the Zotero citation manager to capture snapshots of individual web resources, synchronize data with a free group account on the Zotero server, involve third-party collaborators and ISAW cataloging staff, and make the resulting data available in various formats suitable for further use online and in other citation management systems. These enhancements aim to create new dissemination channels for a broader set of audience use cases and incorporate and reuse AWOL content on ISAW's website and other digital publications.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The proposed enhancements to AWOL, as mentioned by Tom Elliott and Chuck Jones in "Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" (ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014), include maintaining the core delivery mechanisms via the existing blog and Feedburner, while adding additional publication channels via NYU library systems and OCLC Worldcat, as well as ISAW's own website. They also plan to streamline and improve content capture and preparation through automation and the use of a structured, collaborative web database designed for web and bibliographic citation. Instead of manually copying information about websites into the blog, the editor will use the free, open-source Zotero citation manager to capture snapshots of individual web resources and to annotate these with bibliographic information and categorical tags.

column1: How does the editor plan to streamline content capture and preparation for AWOL?
column2: The editor plans to streamline content capture and preparation for AWOL by using the free, open-source Zotero citation manager to capture snapshots of individual web resources, annotate them with bibliographic information and tags, and synchronize this data with a group account on the Zotero server. This will involve interested third-party collaborators and ISAW cataloging staff in capturing, refining, and updating data for publication. The resulting data will be made available in various formats suitable for online use and other citation management systems, creating a new dissemination channel for a broader audience. Additionally, the editor will use Zotero's API outputs to transform the AWOL bibliographic content into data suitable for submission to NYU's library catalog systems and to post new or updated content to the existing blog through Blogger's open API without manual intervention. This process will also allow ISAW's website and other digital publications to incorporate and reuse AWOL content as needed.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The editor plans to streamline content capture and preparation for AWOL by using the free, open-source Zotero citation manager to capture snapshots of individual web resources and annotate them with bibliographic information and categorical tags. This data will then be automatically synchronized with a free group account on the Zotero server, enabling the editor to involve interested third-party collaborators and the existing ISAW cataloging staff in capturing, refining, and updating data for publication. This information is from "Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" by Tom Elliott and Chuck Jones in ISAW Papers 7.6 (2014).

column1: How will the use of Zotero citation manager contribute to the dissemination of AWOL content?
column2: The use of Zotero citation manager will contribute to the dissemination of AWOL content by allowing the editor to capture snapshots of individual web resources, annotate them with bibliographic information and tags, and synchronize this data with a group account on the Zotero server. This will enable the editor to involve third-party collaborators and ISAW cataloging staff in capturing and updating data for publication. The data will be available in various formats suitable for online use and other citation management systems, expanding the dissemination channels for a broader audience. Additionally, the output from Zotero will be used to transform AWOL bibliographic content into data suitable for submission to NYU's library catalog systems and to post new or updated content to the existing blog through Blogger's open API, all without manual intervention. ISAW's website and other digital publications will also incorporate and reuse AWOL content using the Zotero API outputs.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The use of Zotero citation manager will contribute to the dissemination of AWOL content by automating the process of capturing, refining, and updating data for publication. The editor will use Zotero to capture snapshots of individual web resources and annotate these with bibliographic information and categorical tags. This data will be automatically synchronized with a free group account on the Zotero server, enabling the editor to involve interested third-party collaborators and the existing ISAW cataloging staff in the process. Zotero's open Application Programming Interface (API) will make the resulting data available in a variety of formats suitable for further use online and in other citation management systems, creating a new dissemination channel for a broader set of audience use cases (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014).

column1: What are some of the key statistics provided regarding the current audience reach of AWOL?
column2:
Some key statistics provided regarding the current audience reach of AWOL are:
- 6,096 current subscribers to the daily email syndication of the news feed.
- 277 persons connected to the Facebook syndication of the news feed.
- 585 persons connected to the Twitter syndication of the news feed.
- 184,795 unique visits to the blog page in the last six months, with 31,622 returning visits.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: AWOL, The Ancient World Online, has a significant audience reach. It has over five thousand subscribers to its daily update and more than 750 unique visitors daily over the past year (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014). In the last six months, the blog page has had 184,795 unique visits, averaging 1,200 per day, with 31,622 of these being returning visits (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014). AWOL also has 6,096 current subscribers to the daily email syndication of the news feed, 277 persons connected to the Facebook syndication of the news feed, and 585 persons connected to the Twitter syndication of the news feed (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014).

column1: How will the enhancements to AWOL involve NYU library systems, OCLC Worldcat, and ISAW's website?
column2: The proposed enhancements to AWOL will involve NYU library systems, OCLC Worldcat, and ISAW's website by adding additional publication channels through these platforms. The enhancements will streamline and improve content capture and preparation through automation and the use of a structured, collaborative web database designed for web and bibliographic citation. This will allow for the integration of AWOL content into these systems, making it more accessible to a broader audience. Additionally, the use of the Zotero citation manager will enable the capture and annotation of web resources, which will be synchronized with a group account on the Zotero server, involving interested third-party collaborators and ISAW cataloging staff in capturing, refining, and updating data for publication. The resulting data will be made available in various formats suitable for further use online and in other citation management systems, creating new dissemination channels for a broader set of audience use cases. The output formats from Zotero will provide the input for conversion programs that will transform AWOL bibliographic content into data suitable for submission to NYU's library catalog systems and for posting new or updated content to the existing blog without manual intervention using Blogger's open API. ISAW's website and other digital publications will also incorporate and reuse AWOL content using the Zotero API outputs as appropriate.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The proposed enhancements to AWOL will involve NYU library systems, OCLC Worldcat, and ISAW's website by adding additional publication channels through these platforms. The AWOL bibliographic content will be transformed into data suitable for submission to NYU's library catalog systems through a conversion program created by ISAW developers. This will also be used to post new or updated content to the existing blog without manual intervention. ISAW's website and other digital publications will incorporate and reuse AWOL content as appropriate. The Zotero server's open Application Programming Interface (API) will automatically make the resulting data available in a variety of formats suitable for further use online and in other citation management systems, thereby creating a new dissemination channel for a broader set of audience use cases (Elliott and Jones, ISAW Papers 7.6, 2014).

column1: How does the article address the tension between traditional library practices and the open web in relation to digital resources?
column2: The article addresses the tension between traditional library practices and the open web in relation to digital resources by highlighting the challenge of capturing and describing digital resources that appear on the open web, outside established library acquisition and cataloging channels. It emphasizes the need for an easy way to integrate digital resources from the open web with existing and emerging library systems, standard scholarly research management software, and public-facing websites. The proposed enhancements to the Ancient World Online (AWOL) aim to streamline content capture and preparation through automation and structured databases, allowing for a more organized and accessible approach to digital scholarly resources.  2014,"Moving the Ancient World Online Forward" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.6, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/elliott-jones.
column3: The articles discuss the tension between traditional library practices and the open web in relation to digital resources by highlighting the shift from one-way communication to a more interactive and global discussion. The authors of "Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" (ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014) note that traditional archaeological monographs do not link to external resources and the communication is one-way. However, they argue that placing these texts online allows for a more interactive experience, with the ability to link to open access data repositories and make the author's content discoverable globally. They also mention the use of social networking/commentary technology to open discussions to a global audience. The authors of "Prologue and Introduction" (ISAW Papers 7.1, 2014) also emphasize the importance of making digital resources available on the public internet and sharing well-conceived digital resources with all audiences.

column1: What is the main idea behind linked data on the web, as discussed in the article?
column2: The main idea behind linked data on the web, as discussed in the article, is to make data readily accessible, already linked to similar instances, or searchable in a way that completes larger scale groupings for analysis. This approach aims to make research faster, easier, and reduce duplication of effort by allowing computers to find and access similar data across many data stores, making research more powerful. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The main idea behind linked data on the web, as discussed in the articles, is to make data readily accessible, searchable, and linkable to similar instances for easier and faster research, reducing duplication of effort (Hafford, ISAW Papers 7.7, 2014). This concept, termed Linked Open Data (LOD), is when data is made available under a license that allows its reuse, and is linked to other data, making it easy to refer to or link to others' datasets from within your own (Hunnell Chen and Folsom, ISAW Papers 20.12, 2021). The data is published in self-defining schemas, related to other schemas wherever possible, allowing computers to make connections across different data stores (Heath and Bizer, 2011). This approach promotes professional recognition and opens new research opportunities (Open Context and Linked Data).

column1: How did Sir Leonard Woolley's excavation at the ancient city of Ur contribute to our understanding of the ancient world?
column2: Sir Leonard Woolley's excavation at the ancient city of Ur contributed significantly to our understanding of the ancient world by uncovering private housing, public buildings, religious, industrial, and funerary areas spanning over 5,000 years of occupation. The excavation produced a vast amount of data, including tens of thousands of artifacts, field catalogue cards, field photographs, and hand-written field notecards. This data provided valuable insights into the history, culture, and daily life of the people who lived in Ur over millennia. Additionally, the excavation led to the publication of extensive records and interpretations, which have long been considered the definitive record of Ur. The data from this excavation continues to be analyzed, reinterpreted, and made available in digital formats, contributing to ongoing research and understanding of the ancient Near East. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: Sir Leonard Woolley's excavation at the ancient city of Ur from 1922 to 1934 uncovered a vast amount of private housing, public buildings, and religious, industrial, and funerary areas from at least the Ubaid through the Persian periods, representing some 5,000 years of occupation. According to William B. Hafford in "Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project," these findings significantly contributed to our current understanding of the ancient Near East. The excavation also led to the creation of a large amount of data, including artifacts and field notes, which have been used for further analysis and reinterpretation, particularly with the advent of linked open data on the web.

column1: What are the driving concepts behind the Linked Ancient World Data Initiative, as mentioned in the text?
column2: The driving concepts behind the Linked Ancient World Data Initiative, as mentioned in the text, include making archaeological data, especially from early excavations, accessible and machine-readable in a linked and openly available manner. This initiative aims to reunite data from different museums and repositories related to ancient sites like Ur of the Chaldees, allowing for faster research, less duplication of effort, and new ways of analyzing and interpreting the data through linked open data on the web. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The Linked Ancient World Data Initiative is driven by the concept of using linked data principles to enhance the study of ancient world geography and history. This involves the creation of a scholarly community willing to implement period assertion URIs in their own datasets and contribute new period assertions to a gazetteer (Rabinowitz, ISAW Papers 7.22). The initiative also emphasizes the importance of integrating time in spatial approaches to history (Rabinowitz, ISAW Papers 7.22). Another key concept is the development of a comprehensive bibliography of scholarly literature in the field of ancient studies that is both open and follows the principles of linked data (Acheson, ISAW Papers 7.2). The initiative also encourages the use of RDF triples and open licensing to facilitate the creation of linked data (Horne, ISAW Papers 20.2).

column1: How did the looting of the Iraq National Museum in 2003 impact the preservation of cultural heritage?
column2: The looting of the Iraq National Museum in 2003 demonstrated the fragility of physical data preservation, even in the modern age. It highlighted the potential loss of cultural heritage due to theft or damage. The incident emphasized the importance of recording and preserving data in a virtual space to ensure researchable data for the future, even if physical artifacts are lost or damaged. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The looting of the Iraq National Museum in 2003 had a significant impact on the preservation of cultural heritage. As Hafford discusses in "Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project," the event demonstrated the fragility of physical data, even in the modern age. The loss of cultural heritage was tragic, but it also highlighted the importance of recording information in a virtual space to ensure researchable data remains for the future. The looting also prompted institutions like the British Museum and the Penn Museum to review their collections to assist Baghdad in understanding what may have been lost. The event underscored the need for careful recording of every object in the care of museums to mitigate loss and to demonstrate the importance of each piece.

column1: What were some of the challenges faced in the initial stages of the project to digitize and publish the data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation?
column2: Some of the challenges faced in the initial stages of the project to digitize and publish the data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation included the slow advancement of digital scholarship in 2003, limited funds for the project, and the scattered nature of the data across different institutions. Additionally, around 40% of the objects in each museum had no clear connection to their original field data, requiring a significant effort to reestablish these connections. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The initial stages of the Ur of the Chaldees Project faced several challenges. Funding was slow to come and insufficient, resulting in only sporadic material being gathered in the early years, such as medium resolution scans of field notes and photos from the British Museum and Penn Museum (Hafford, ISAW Papers 7.7). Additionally, the project had to determine the extent of Ur material outside of Iraq, its dispersion, and the time it would take to digitize it all. The archival documents were also relatively dispersed, making data gathering from all institutions a challenge. Furthermore, the project had to deal with the loss of physical data due to looting of the Iraq National Museum after the second Gulf War (Hafford, ISAW Papers 7.7).

column1: How is the data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation being made accessible and machine-readable for researchers?
column2: The data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation is being made accessible and machine-readable for researchers through the Linked Ancient World Data Initiative. The project aims to reunite the excavated portions of the city of Ur in a virtual space by digitizing and linking the data from the University of Pennsylvania Museum and the British Museum. This involves creating stable URIs and RDF/XML, JSON, or other machine-readable references, connected to ArchaeoML and/or CIDOC-CRM formats. The goal is to publish all the information online, making it searchable textually, visually, and spatially. The data will be open to all and linked to related sites, forming part of the overall linked data on the web for further connections and research possibilities. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation is being made accessible and machine-readable for researchers through a project that involves digitizing all of Woolley's 15,000 artifact cards and other relevant information into a database. This database will be a growing record and a research tool that provides ways of interlinking and presenting core data. It will be searchable textually, visually, and spatially, and will be published with stable URIs and RDF/XML, JSON and/or other machine-readable references, connected to some version of ArchaeoML and/or CIDOC-CRM wherever possible. The site will be open to all and linked to related sites, such as the online catalogues of relevant museums and the Cuneiform Digital Library Initiative (William B. Hafford, ISAW Papers 7.7, 2014).

column1: What are the potential benefits of aggregating and linking data from sites like Ur in a virtual space?
column2:
Aggregating and linking data from sites like Ur in a virtual space can have several potential benefits:

1. **Unification**: By gathering data from different institutions, the excavated portions of the city can be reunited in a virtual space. This helps in bringing together physically divided information.

2. **Protection**: In the event of physical loss or damage to artifacts due to looting, environmental conditions, or other factors, having the data recorded in a virtual space ensures that researchable data remains available for the future. This helps in safeguarding cultural heritage.

3. **Research Efficiency**: Researchers can access and analyze data more quickly and easily when it is linked and accessible in a machine-readable format. This reduces duplication of effort and allows for faster research into the ancient concepts or practices being investigated.

4. **New Visions and Interpretations**: The linked data allows for deconstruction of existing groupings and the creation of new ones. This enables newer interpretations or reanalysis of old data, leading to a better understanding of the site's history and significance.

5. **Continuous Learning and Publication**: The virtual space serves as a modern publication and research tool that provides ways of interlinking and presenting core data. This allows for continuous learning and publication about the site and its history, creating a growing record that expands over time.

6. **Interconnectedness**: The RDF that describes the data becomes part of the overall linked data on the web, enabling connections with other information published in linked open format. This opens up new ways of envisioning the data and assembling it with similar information from other sites, leading to more encompassing and complete understandings of the Ancient Near East as a whole. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: Aggregating and linking data from sites like Ur in a virtual space can have several benefits. According to William B. Hafford in "Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project", this approach can allow for new visions and also unite and protect the information. It can create a comprehensive record of everything from Ur, serving as a modern publication and a research tool that provides ways of interlinking and presenting core data. This can lead to continuous learning and publishing about the site and its history. The data can be searchable textually, visually, and spatially, making research into the data faster and easier. It can also reduce duplication of effort and make the data more accessible. Furthermore, it can facilitate the linking of similar data across many data stores, making research more powerful.

column1: How will the publication of the data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation contribute to the understanding of the Ancient Near East as a whole?
column2: The publication of the data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation will contribute to the understanding of the Ancient Near East as a whole by providing a comprehensive and interconnected dataset that can be accessed and analyzed by researchers. This linked open data will allow for new connections to be made with similar information from other sites, leading to more encompassing and complete understandings of the Ancient Near East. It will enable new ways of envisioning the data and assembling it with related information, ultimately enhancing the overall knowledge of the region's history and archaeology. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The publication of the data from the Ur of the Chaldees excavation will contribute to the understanding of the Ancient Near East as a whole by providing a comprehensive and interconnected record of the site and its history. According to William B. Hafford in "Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project", the data will be published in a linked open format, allowing it to be interlinked with similar information from other sites. This will enable new ways of envisioning and assembling the data, leading to more encompassing and complete understandings of the Ancient Near East. Furthermore, the publication will unite and protect the information, which is currently physically divided due to laws of the early 20th century. The data will also be searchable textually, visually, and spatially, providing a valuable research tool for further study and publication about the site.

column1: How does the article emphasize the importance of making archaeological data openly available for research and analysis?
column2: The article emphasizes the importance of making archaeological data openly available for research and analysis by highlighting the benefits of linked open data on the web. It discusses how accessible, machine-readable data can lead to faster research, easier analysis, and less duplication of effort among researchers. By making data openly available and linked in a self-defining schema, researchers can connect data across different sources, allowing for more powerful research capabilities. The article specifically mentions the Ur of the Chaldees Project as an example of how making archaeological data openly available in a linked format can facilitate research, protect cultural heritage, and lead to new interpretations and understandings of the ancient world. William B. Hafford 2014,"Linked Open Data and the Ur of the Chaldees Project" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.7, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/hafford/.
column3: The articles emphasize the importance of making archaeological data openly available for research and analysis in several ways. Seifried (ISAW Papers 7.26, 2014) highlights the benefits of publishing archaeological data in a linked, open way, allowing for connections and meaningful relationships to be made. Chen and Folsom (ISAW Papers 20.12, 2021) discuss the need to bring data from marginalized parts of the world into international conversations about the future of archaeological research. Kansa (ISAW Papers 7.10, 2014) notes that new rules from granting agencies and changing professional expectations are making data dissemination a regular aspect of scholarly communications. The articles also suggest that opening up the data can help make authors' arguments more objective and allow for independent reinterpretation of the data.

column1: What are the main goals of ISAW Papers as a digital scholarly journal?
column2: The main goals of ISAW Papers as a digital scholarly journal are to publish article-length scholarship that is available at no cost to readers, can be reused and redistributed under a Creative Commons license, and is stored in formats that are likely to be readable into the far future. Additionally, the journal aims to link to stable resources available on the public Internet to increase discoverability and utility for investigating the ancient world. Sebastian Heath 2014,"ISAW Papers: Towards a Journal as Linked Open Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.8, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/heath/.
column3: ISAW Papers, as a digital scholarly journal, has several main goals. According to Sebastian Heath in "ISAW Papers: Towards a Journal as Linked Open Data" (ISAW Papers 7.8, 2014), the journal aims to publish article-length scholarship that is freely available to readers, can be reused and redistributed under a Creative Commons license, and is stored in formats that are likely to be readable far into the future. The journal also aims to link to stable resources available on the public internet. Another goal is to distribute high-quality scholarship relevant to the Ancient World. The journal also seeks to balance the benefits of peer review for authors while ensuring it does not hinder new work or timely publication.

column1: How does ISAW Papers ensure the availability and accessibility of its articles to readers?
column2: ISAW Papers ensures the availability and accessibility of its articles to readers by publishing article-length scholarship that is available at no cost, can be reused and redistributed under a Creative Commons license, and is stored in formats that are likely to be readable into the far future. Additionally, articles in ISAW Papers link to stable resources available on the public Internet to increase discoverability and utility. The journal also collaborates with the NYU Library for initial public availability and long-term preservation, assigning Handles to each article for redirection and creating individual records in the NYU Bobcat library catalog and Worldcat. The use of Linked Open Data principles, such as RDFa and triples, further enhances the machine-readable aspects of the articles for automated agents to access and utilize the content effectively. Sebastian Heath 2014,"ISAW Papers: Towards a Journal as Linked Open Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.8, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/heath/.
column3: ISAW Papers ensures the availability and accessibility of its articles to readers by publishing them online at no cost.
