This approach enabled him to collect and organize data with like-minded scholars and relevant projects in mind (Byzantine Cappadocia: Small Data and the Dissertation. A. L. McMichael. ISAW Papers 7.14 (2014)).

column1: How does A. L. McMichael integrate small data sets into their dissertation research on Byzantine Cappadocia?
column2: A. L. McMichael integrates small data sets into their dissertation research on Byzantine Cappadocia by creating a database of Byzantine monuments using Dublin Core elements, controlled vocabularies, and stable URIs for each. This approach allows for the visualization and sharing of data, expanding the research into the wider range of ancient and medieval scholarship. A. L. McMichael 2014,"Byzantine Cappadocia: Small Data and the Dissertation" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.14, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/mcmichael/.
column3: A. L. McMichael integrates small data sets into their dissertation research on Byzantine Cappadocia by using Linked Data principles. They have built a database of Byzantine monuments using Dublin Core elements, controlled vocabularies, and stable URIs for each. The dissertation includes a bibliography, map of sites, and catalog of images, all of which are considered valuable data. McMichael also created a website, Documenting Cappadocia, which generates small data sets that are constructed to be reused and remixed. The website includes a bibliography, photos, and links to open access resources. McMichael's strategy aligns with Rufus Pollock's assertion that small data packages are scalable and solve problems, and Joris Pekel's suggestion that experts should work with the public to create and enrich small data sets (Pollock 2013, Pekel 2013).

column1: What benefits does A. L. McMichael mention in relation to structuring data for solo researchers or small teams using Linked Data principles?
column2: A. L. McMichael mentions several benefits in relation to structuring data for solo researchers or small teams using Linked Data principles. These benefits include providing precedents and parameters for the scope of work, encouraging the use of best practice guidelines, expanding collaboration possibilities by networking with similar projects, incorporating niche topics into wider scholarship and public knowledge, offering context, and identifying and widening the potential audience for the work. A. L. McMichael 2014,"Byzantine Cappadocia: Small Data and the Dissertation" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.14, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/mcmichael/.
column3: A. L. McMichael, in "Byzantine Cappadocia: Small Data and the Dissertation" (ISAW Papers 7.14, 2014), mentions several benefits of structuring data using Linked Data principles for solo researchers or small teams. First, the use of controlled vocabularies and metadata standards provides precedents and parameters for the scope of the work and encourages the use of best practice guidelines. Second, Linked Data expands the definition of collaboration by offering possibilities to network with projects of similar subject matter or scope. Lastly, the use of out-of-the-box content management systems with an emphasis on openness and stable URIs can have a profound effect on digital scholarship.

column1: What is the unique aspect of coinage as evidence for the ancient world, and how does it contribute to the understanding of the ancient economy?
column2: The unique aspect of coinage as evidence for the ancient world is that coins are monetary objects, providing a key element in reconstructing the workings of the ancient economy. Through processes like die-study, it is possible to quantify ancient monetary production by determining how many dies were used to strike a given coinage. This allows for the estimation of the size of production, attributing coins to specific rulers or cities, and comparing the monetary output of different regions. Additionally, coins have find spots, giving insight into economic circulation, connectivity, and movement. By mapping coins from their source to deposition, it is possible to understand regional histories and compare monetary profiles of different sites. Coins also offer information about the intentions of issuers and users through their designs and inscriptions, shedding light on areas from local religion to imperial economic policy. The iconographic and epigraphic repertoire of ancient coinage provides a valuable resource for studying various aspects of ancient societies.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: Coinage is unique as evidence for the ancient world because it is a monetary object that can be attributed to specific rulers or cities with some degree of certainty, according to Gruber and Meadows in "Numismatics and Linked Open Data" and "Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline". This allows for the quantification of ancient monetary production and the comparison of monetary output across different cities, kingdoms, and empires. Additionally, coins are also archaeological objects with find spots, providing evidence for movement, connectivity, and economic circulation. This information can be used to reconstruct the workings of the ancient economy and to understand the monetary profile of the site they are excavating.

column1: How do find spots of coins within archaeological contexts provide insight into the monetary profile of a site and regional history?
column2: Find spots of coins within archaeological contexts provide valuable insights into the monetary profile of a site and regional history by offering evidence of economic circulation, connectivity, and movement. By knowing where a coin was minted and where it was found, researchers can trace the trajectory of coins, revealing patterns of trade, economic relationships, and monetary interactions between different locations. This information can help in understanding the economic activities, trade networks, and monetary systems of a specific site or region, and comparing them with others to uncover regional economic histories.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: Coins within archaeological contexts can provide valuable insights into the monetary profile of the site they are excavating and the regional history. According to Reece (1982) as cited in Gruber and Meadows' "Numismatics and Linked Open Data", the find spots of coins can give them a trajectory, providing evidence for movement, connectivity, and economic circulation. If the origin and find spot of a coin are known, it can be mapped from source to deposition, providing a unique perspective on the economic and historical context of the region. This can help in comparing the site with others of similar or different types and a regional history may emerge from multiple sites.

column1: How has the advent of the metal detector impacted the recording of individual coin finds, and what new opportunities has it opened up for research?
column2: The advent of the metal detector has impacted the recording of individual coin finds by expanding the scope of recording beyond excavation materials. For example, the Portable Antiquities Scheme in the United Kingdom has recorded find spots for a large number of coins. This has led to new works of synthesis and has opened up opportunities for research by providing a substantial amount of data that can be used to address questions that were previously unanswerable through other source materials. The metal detector has allowed for the recording of individual coin finds outside of traditional excavation contexts, leading to a significant increase in available data for study.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: The advent of the metal detector has significantly increased the recording of individual coin finds, as it is no longer confined to excavation material. For instance, the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) in the United Kingdom has recorded find spots for over 412,000 coins, according to Pett (2014) as cited in Gruber and Meadows' "Numismatics and Linked Open Data" (ISAW Papers 20.6, 2021). This has led to new works of synthesis and the growth of material is not showing signs of abatement. Furthermore, the ability to map coins from their source to deposition provides evidence for movement, connectivity, and economic circulation, offering new opportunities for research.

column1: In what ways can the iconographic and epigraphic repertoire of ancient coinage be used to study various aspects of ancient society and administration?
column2: The iconographic and epigraphic repertoire of ancient coinage can be used to study various aspects of ancient society and administration by examining the intentions of the issuers of the coins and the preconceptions of the users. This can provide insights into areas such as local religion, imperial economic policy, individual political ambition, and communal statements of identity. By analyzing the iconography and inscriptions on coins, researchers can uncover patterns of administration that may not be visible through other sources.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: The iconographic and epigraphic repertoire of ancient coinage can be used to study various aspects of ancient society and administration in several ways. It can be used to examine areas from local religion to imperial economic policy and from individual political ambition to communal statements of identity. The evidence from the findspots of these coins can be combined with the iconography of the objects to expose patterns of administration that are invisible from other sources. This approach has been demonstrated in recent work by Kemmers (2006) and von Kaenel and Kemmers (2009). Furthermore, the process of die-study can be used to determine how many dies were used to strike a given coinage, providing a way to quantify ancient monetary production (Gruber and Meadows, ISAW Papers 20.6, 2021).

column1: What are some of the challenges in exploiting numismatic data for research, particularly in terms of data volume and diversity of descriptions?
column2: Some of the challenges in exploiting numismatic data for research include the sheer volume of data available, as there are millions of coins across various collections and sources. Additionally, the diversity of descriptions poses a challenge as coins are described in different systems, formats, standards, and languages, making it difficult to integrate and analyze the data effectively.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: Exploiting numismatic data for research presents several challenges, particularly in terms of the sheer volume of data and the diversity of descriptions. Many coins are described online, but they are described in different systems, formats, standards, and languages, making it difficult to consolidate and analyze the data (Meadows and Gruber, ISAW Papers 7.15). Additionally, the data is located in a variety of institutional and non-institutional settings, adding another layer of complexity to its exploitation (Gruber and Meadows, ISAW Papers 20.6). Furthermore, many finds of Roman-era coinage are known but are described in only vague terms often without detail even on the exact number of coins which were found, making it very difficult to perform any usable analysis on the material (Hoyer, ISAW Papers 13, 2018).

column1: How has the Linked Data approach been applied to Roman numismatics, and what are the benefits of this approach for the field?
column2: The Linked Data approach has been applied to Roman numismatics through projects like nomisma.org, which provide stable URIs for numismatic concepts and enable the linking of numismatic data within Roman numismatics and beyond. By using discipline-specific terms and common identifiers, such as Pleiades URIs and Wikipedia links, the integration of numismatic data into broader fields of study is facilitated. This approach allows for the creation of a graph of Roman coin data that is interconnected and can be linked to other resources. The benefits of this approach include improved data integration, easier access to reusable information, and the ability to create interactive tools for analysis and representation of numismatic data, such as timelines and maps. Additionally, the use of Linked Data simplifies the updating and management of data, making it easier to incorporate new collections and information into the system.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: The Linked Data approach has been applied to Roman numismatics through the development of infrastructure for creating linked Roman numismatic data, a process initiated by the American Numismatic Society in 2011 in collaboration with strategic partners (ISAW Papers 7.15, Andrew Meadows and Ethan Gruber). This approach allows for enhanced analysis not only of the physical characteristics of the specimens but also their findspots through mapping. The Linked Data model is well-suited to the publication of collections, finds, and reference works in the field of numismatics (ISAW Papers 20.6, Gruber and Meadows). Existing projects with well-developed databases do not need to change their recording practices or software, making the cost of admission to the Linked Data community for Roman numismatics low. This approach benefits the field by allowing all to benefit at little or no cost without the need to surrender their own working practices (ISAW Papers 7.15, Andrew Meadows and Ethan Gruber).

column1: How does the creation of a type corpus like Online Coins of the Roman Empire (OCRE) enhance research possibilities in Roman numismatics?
column2: The creation of a type corpus like Online Coins of the Roman Empire (OCRE) enhances research possibilities in Roman numismatics by allowing for the linking of multiple examples of a given coin type from various contexts. This capability opens up new avenues for research as researchers can now access and analyze a broader range of examples of a specific coin type. Additionally, OCRE's Linked Data approach enables the integration of data from various projects, such as collections and hoards, enriching the information available for study and analysis. The multilingual interface and the ability to link to individual specimens in public collections further enhance the depth and breadth of research possibilities in Roman numismatics.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: The creation of a type corpus like the Online Coins of the Roman Empire (OCRE) enhances research possibilities in Roman numismatics by providing a multilingual interface that supports 17 languages, and by linking to multiple examples of a given type from various contexts. This allows for a broader and more diverse examination of coin types. The Linked Data approach used in the creation of OCRE also enables the aggregation of specimens from an international range of museum and archaeological databases, making them accessible through OCRE. This approach opens up new possibilities for research, including the visualization of changes in average weight of denarii between the late Roman Republic and early Empire, and the mapping of the distribution of findspots for specific types directly within OCRE and CRRO. The OCRE project, as described by Gruber and Meadows in "Numismatics and Linked Open Data", also facilitates the creation of similar projects in the future, expanding the potential for research in the field of numismatics.

column1: How are stable URIs and discipline-specific vocabularies used in the Linked Data approach to numismatics, and how do they facilitate data integration and analysis?
column2:
Stable URIs and discipline-specific vocabularies are used in the Linked Data approach to numismatics to provide unique identifiers for numismatic concepts and terms. These URIs allow for the creation of a graph of Roman coin data that is linked within Roman numismatics and can also be linked to broader datasets in the ancient world. By using discipline-specific terms and common identifiers, such as Pleiades URIs or Wikipedia links, data integration across different fields of study becomes possible.

These stable URIs and vocabularies facilitate data integration and analysis by ensuring that numismatic data can be linked and interconnected within the field of Roman numismatics and beyond. This allows for the seamless exchange of data between different projects and databases, enabling researchers to analyze and synthesize information from various sources. The use of Linked Data architecture, RDF databases, and SPARQL endpoints further enhances the ability to query and analyze numismatic data, making it easier to manage and update datasets for improved research outcomes.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: Stable URIs and discipline-specific vocabularies are key elements in the Linked Data approach to numismatics. They are used to describe numismatic concepts and provide digital representations of these concepts. According to Meadows and Gruber in "Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" and "Numismatics and Linked Open Data", they harnessed a project called Nomisma to provide these stable URIs. This allows for the creation of a graph of Roman coin data that is linked within Roman numismatics by the use of discipline-specific terms. It also facilitates joining the broader graph of ancient world data through the use of common identifiers. This approach enables the integration of data from various sources, such as different collections or archaeological datasets, and facilitates analysis by providing stable connections between objects and typological records that describe them.

column1: What are the advantages of linking type corpus records to hoards and collections in numismatic research, and how does this interconnectedness benefit the field?
column2: Linking type corpus records to hoards and collections in numismatic research allows for a more comprehensive understanding of the context and distribution of coins. By establishing these connections, researchers can enrich databases with detailed descriptions of coin types, find spots, and individual specimens. This interconnectedness benefits the field by enabling researchers to analyze the characteristics of individual types or coins issued in specific locations or by particular rulers. It also allows for comparative studies, such as examining the frequency of certain depictions on coinages of different emperors. Additionally, this linkage facilitates the creation of tools for analyzing the characteristics of coins and types, enhancing research capabilities within the field of numismatics.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: Linking type corpus records to individual specimens in collections and hoards enhances the distribution and accessibility of numismatic data, according to Meadows and Gruber in their ISAW Papers. This practice, recommended by the International Council of Museums and adopted by major collections, allows for stable connections between objects and the typological records that describe them. The Linked Data approach enables the Online Coins of the Roman Empire (OCRE) to link to multiple examples of a given type from various contexts, opening up new research possibilities. The integration of numismatic data not only benefits the field of Roman numismatics but also permeates into other fields of study. Furthermore, the implementation of the Linked Data model for the publication of collections, finds, and reference works is well-suited to numismatics, offering benefits at little or no cost without the need to surrender existing working practices.

column1: How does the use of RDF databases and SPARQL endpoints enhance the technical aspects of maintaining relationships between coin types, specimens, and hoards in numismatic research?
column2: The use of RDF databases and SPARQL endpoints enhances the technical aspects of maintaining relationships between coin types, specimens, and hoards in numismatic research by providing a structured and linked data model. This allows for efficient querying and retrieval of information, enabling the connection between coin types and individual specimens or hoards. The RDF database facilitates the association of numismatic concepts and attributes, such as measurements, images, and metadata, making it easier to analyze and visualize data. SPARQL queries can be used to extract specific information, such as average weights of coin types or findspots, and display them in charts, graphs, or maps. This approach streamlines the process of updating and managing data, ensuring that new collections, images, and measurements can be easily integrated into the system without the need to update existing records in OCRE.  2014,"Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.15, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meadows-gruber/.
column3: The use of RDF databases and SPARQL endpoints significantly enhances the technical aspects of maintaining relationships between coin types, specimens, and hoards in numismatic research. According to Gruber and Meadows in "Numismatics and Linked Open Data" and "Coinage and Numismatic Methods. A Case Study of Linking a Discipline", these tools allow for efficient maintenance of relationships between coin types and their associated coins and hoards. The Numishare platform, for example, directly queries the endpoint to deliver some types of services. In other cases, it interacts with REST APIs offered by Nomisma, which conduct more complicated SPARQL queries in the background. This system is particularly valuable for partners who may lack the technical personnel or expertise to build these data exports directly into their own database systems.

column1: What is the main argument presented by Katy M. Meyers in the article "Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome"?
column2: The main argument presented by Katy M. Meyers in the article "Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" is that mortuary archaeology, specifically focusing on Roman Imperial burial practices, would greatly benefit from the implementation of Linked Open Data (LOD). Meyers argues that using LOD would increase data sharing, improve connections between archaeologists, and enhance the study of mortuary practices within the discipline at a faster pace. Katy M. Meyers 2014,"Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.16, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meyers/.
column3: Katy M. Meyers argues in "Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" that the field of mortuary archaeology, specifically studies of Roman Imperial burial practices, would greatly benefit from the implementation of Linked Open Data (LOD). She asserts that LOD would enhance the sharing of data, improve connections between archaeologists, and accelerate study within the discipline. Meyers uses the example of Roman Imperial burial practices to illustrate how the adoption of LOD could help answer questions about the differential acceptance or rejection of Roman Imperial identity by various provinces and the evolution of these practices over time. She also highlights the current challenges in synthesizing data due to the lack of a standard method for classifying cemeteries and the limited accessibility of data in digital or print formats (Roberts and Mays 2010, Berners-Lee 2007).

column1: How did burial practices in the Roman Empire change over time, specifically in relation to cremation and inhumation?
column2: Burial practices in the Roman Empire changed over time in relation to cremation and inhumation. Initially, cremation was the most popular form of burial during the early Roman Empire, with inhumation being a secondary option. However, by the mid-2nd century, the frequencies between cremation and inhumation had reversed. By the 4th century, cremation had become a rare practice in the Roman Empire. This shift in burial practices over time reflects changes in societal norms, beliefs, and cultural influences within the Roman Empire. Katy M. Meyers 2014,"Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.16, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meyers/.
column3: During the Roman occupation, burial practices varied greatly based on factors such as region, citizen status, social rank, family beliefs, and religious cult affiliation. At the start of the Roman Empire, cremation was the most common form of burial, with inhumation being a secondary option. However, by the mid-2nd century, the popularity of these two forms had reversed. By the 4th century, cremation had become a rare practice (Nock 1932). Despite the strong Roman cultural influence, there was a great diversity in the types of burials throughout the empire due to imperial tolerance, which did not mandate a specific type of burial (Toynbee 1996). The only stipulation was that burials must take place outside the city walls, but the choice between cremation or inhumation was left to the mourning community (Meyers, ISAW Papers 7.16, 2014).

column1: What factors influenced the variation in burial practices across different regions of the Roman Empire?
column2: The variation in burial practices across different regions of the Roman Empire was influenced by factors such as region, citizen status, social rank, family beliefs, and religious cult affiliation. These factors played a role in determining whether cremation or inhumation was preferred, the types of tombs used, the funerary rites performed, and the overall diversity in burial practices observed throughout the empire. Katy M. Meyers 2014,"Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.16, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meyers/.
column3: Burial practices across different regions of the Roman Empire varied based on several factors. These included the region, citizen status, social rank, family beliefs, and religious cult affiliation (Meyers, ISAW Papers 7.16, 2014). The extent of adoption of the Roman identity in their various territories also played a role, with some provinces changing with Roman invasion, some forms of hybrid mortuary programs and others maintaining their ancestral ways (Webster 2001). The state did not mandate burial type due to imperial tolerance, and the only stipulation was that the burial itself must take place outside the walls of the city. The types of tombs, the funerary rites, and the choice to cremate or inhume was left to the mourning community, resulting in a great diversity in burial types (Toynbee 1996).

column1: What challenges exist in synthesizing data on Roman Imperial mortuary practices, according to the article?
column2: The challenges in synthesizing data on Roman Imperial mortuary practices, according to the article, include the lack of a standard method for classifying cemeteries for direct comparison, as well as the limited availability of this data in accessible formats digitally or in print. Katy M. Meyers 2014,"Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.16, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meyers/.
column3: According to the article by Katy M. Meyers in ISAW Papers 7.16 (2014), there are two primary challenges in synthesizing data on Roman Imperial mortuary practices. The first challenge is the lack of a standard method for classifying cemeteries, which would allow for direct comparison of the mortuary sites. The second challenge is that the data is rarely found in accessible formats, either digitally or in print.

column1: How can the implementation of Linked Open Data (LOD) benefit the field of mortuary archaeology, as discussed in the text?
column2: The implementation of Linked Open Data (LOD) can benefit the field of mortuary archaeology by increasing the sharing of data, improving links between archaeologists, and furthering study within the discipline at an increased rate. LOD allows for stable uniform resource identifiers (URIs) that uniquely identify objects, making them easily accessible online. This approach provides useful metadata created using universal standards, enabling individuals to access information about mortuary sites more efficiently. By linking different pieces of data, LOD helps build an interconnected digital network that facilitates access to physical remains and interpretations freely. This interconnected network can lead to more nuanced interpretations, reduce sampling bias, and potentially reveal new patterns in mortuary practices. Katy M. Meyers 2014,"Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.16, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meyers/.
column3: The implementation of Linked Open Data (LOD) can greatly benefit the field of mortuary archaeology by increasing the sharing of data, improving links between archaeologists, and accelerating the rate of study within the discipline. For instance, using Roman Imperial burial practices as an example, Katy M. Meyers in "Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" argues that the concept of LOD provides an opportunity to gain access to the physical remains and interpretations freely through interconnected digital networks. This could aid in building upon the works of others, which is a requirement for the progress of archaeological work. Furthermore, the introduction of LOD could make specific burial sites easily referenced and accessed online.

column1: How does the availability of primary data online contribute to the advancement of research in bioarchaeology and archaeology, as mentioned in the article?
column2: The availability of primary data online contributes to the advancement of research in bioarchaeology and archaeology by increasing data sharing, improving links between researchers, and facilitating further study within the discipline at an increased rate. It allows for more nuanced interpretations, reduces sampling bias, and potentially reveals new patterns. Additionally, open access to data enables researchers to build upon existing work, leading to more comprehensive and insightful analyses. Katy M. Meyers 2014,"Exploring an Opportunity to Link the Dead in Ancient Rome" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.16, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/meyers/.
column3: The availability of primary data online significantly contributes to the advancement of research in bioarchaeology and archaeology. As Meyers (2014) notes, increased access to and improved connections between datasets can reduce sampling bias and potentially reveal new patterns. The data that has been placed online is shared more, utilized more, and has led to more nuanced interpretations due to its high availability (Roberts and Mays 2011). Furthermore, online platforms like Open Context, Archaeology Data Service, and the Museum of London's Centre for Bioarchaeology are making primary data from mortuary sites accessible, allowing other researchers to build upon existing work. However, the transition to digital technologies also presents challenges, such as dealing with proprietary and closed digital formats, and ensuring participation from historically marginalized parts of the world (Hunnell Chen and Folsom, 2021). Despite these challenges, the shift to digital data collection and sharing is seen as a practical step for capturing data at the highest resolution possible and dealing with issues of data fragmentation (Hunnell Chen and Folsom, 2021).

column1: What was the significance of the discovery of the so-called Athlit ram in 1980 near Haifa, Israel?
column2: The significance of the discovery of the Athlit ram in 1980 near Haifa, Israel was that it was the first authentic large-scale warship ram to be pulled from the sea. This discovery led to an increasing number of similar artifacts being found in various contexts, contributing to our understanding of ancient naval warfare and ship design. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: The discovery of the so-called Athlit ram in 1980 near Haifa, Israel was significant as it was the first authentic large-scale warship ram to be found (Murray, ISAW Papers 7.17, 2014). Since its discovery, an increasing number of these artifacts have been found, providing unique insights into ancient warships. These rams are the only securely identifiable parts of ancient warships that survive in multiple numbers from antiquity. They are important for their ability to help address questions about the physical sizes and weights of different kinds of warships, the forces generated during ancient naval battles, regional and chronological differences in warship design, and the technologies utilized in the production of these rams (Murray, ISAW Papers 7.17, 2014).

column1: How many authentic warship rams have been added to the collection as a result of the recent discovery of the battle zone between Rome and Carthage?
column2: As a result of the recent discovery of the battle zone between Rome and Carthage, 12 new authentic warship rams have been added to the collection. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: The recent discovery of the battle zone where Rome and Carthage waged the last naval battle of the First Punic War has led to the addition of 12 new rams to the collection, as mentioned by Tusa and Royal in their 2012 discussion of seven of these weapons (ISAW Papers 7.17, 2014).

column1: What are some of the important questions that the study of authentic rams can help address in relation to ancient naval history?
column2:
The study of authentic rams can help address important questions in ancient naval history such as:

1) What were the physical sizes and approximate weights of different kinds of warships?
2) What forces were generated during ancient naval battles when one ship purposefully collided with another?
3) What were important regional and chronological differences in warship design?
4) Were different technologies utilized in the production of these rams, and if so, why? William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: The study of authentic rams can help address several important questions in relation to ancient naval history. These include understanding the physical sizes and approximate weights of different kinds of warships, the forces generated during ancient naval battles when one ship purposefully collided with another, important regional and chronological differences in warship design, and the different technologies utilized in the production of these rams (William Murray, ISAW Papers 7.17, 2014).

column1: What is the purpose of the web portal called RAM3D at the University of South Florida?
column2: The purpose of the web portal called RAM3D at the University of South Florida is to assist researchers in studying authentic rams from ancient warships. The portal aims to be a repository for various types of graphic evidence, such as detailed study photos, 3D models of authentic rams, and useful comparanda. It also plans to include a detailed descriptive vocabulary in multiple languages to help researchers analyze and understand these ancient artifacts. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: The RAM3D web portal at the University of South Florida, developed by William Murray, is designed to assist researchers in the study of ancient warship rams. The portal aims to serve as a repository for different kinds of graphic evidence, such as detailed study photos, 3D models of authentic rams, and large-scale 3D representations of warships. It also plans to include a detailed descriptive vocabulary in multiple languages. The portal is envisioned as a place to demonstrate the methodology used to create these weapons and to explore how best to present the results. Ultimately, the goal is to promote the study of ancient Mediterranean warships by providing a platform where researchers can share and exchange information (ISAW Papers 7.17, 2014, William Murray).

column1: How are "virtual rams" created and what evidence do they provide about ancient warships?
column2: "Virtual rams" are created through a process of reverse engineering based on sockets or complex holes found in a retaining wall that once held the back ends of authentic rams used in ancient naval battles. These computer-generated rams provide evidence about the shapes and sizes of the original rams, which can help researchers understand the design and construction of ancient warships. The details recovered from these sockets allow for the recreation of the rams' shapes, offering insights into the technology and craftsmanship involved in creating these naval weapons. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: "Virtual rams" are created by reverse engineering from sockets or complex holes in a retaining wall that once held the back ends of authentic rams used in ancient naval battles, such as the Battle of Actium in 31 BCE. These computer-generated 3D models provide evidence about the physical sizes, approximate weights, and design differences of ancient warships. They also help in understanding the forces generated during ancient naval battles when one ship purposefully collided with another. Furthermore, they provide insights into the different technologies utilized in the production of these rams. This information is crucial as no securely identifiable part of an ancient warship survives in multiple numbers from antiquity (William Murray, ISAW Papers 7.17, 2014).

column1: How does the author envision the RAM3D portal serving as a useful node for researchers studying ancient Mediterranean warships?
column2: The author envisions the RAM3D portal serving as a useful node where researchers can share and exchange various kinds of information with one another to promote the study of ancient Mediterranean warships. The portal will provide a repository for graphic evidence, detailed study photos, 3D models of authentic rams, and useful comparanda. Additionally, the portal will include a detailed descriptive vocabulary with equivalent terms in multiple languages to assist researchers in their studies. The online nature of the database will allow for expansion as new artifacts are found and new terms are developed. The author also plans to demonstrate the methodology used to create these weapons and explore how best to present the results in a traditional 2D print format. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: The author, William Murray, envisions the RAM3D portal as a useful node for researchers studying ancient Mediterranean warships by serving as a repository for various kinds of graphic evidence, such as detailed study photos, 3D models of authentic rams, and large-scale 3D representations of warships and their bow structures. The portal is also expected to include a detailed descriptive vocabulary with equivalent terms in multiple languages. The online nature of the database will allow for expansion as new artifacts are found and new terms are developed to describe them. The portal is intended to assist researchers in studying the weapons used on these warships and in answering important questions related to ancient naval history and naval architecture.

column1: What resources are being sought to develop and maintain the RAM3D web portal?
column2: The necessary resources being sought to develop and maintain the RAM3D web portal include funding and support to ensure the continued development and upkeep of the site. The author mentions seeking resources to code the site efficiently and link its vocabularies and references to others studying the ancient world. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: William Murray, the author of ISAW Papers 7.17 (2014), is seeking resources that will allow for the development and maintenance of the RAM3D web portal. He plans to draw on his connections with the LAWDI community to code the site in ways that will most efficiently link its vocabularies and site references to others studying the ancient world.

column1: How can researchers access the RAM3D web portal and what is the URL for the site?
column2: Researchers can access the RAM3D web portal by visiting the following URL: http://aist.usf.edu/ram3d/. William Murray 2014,"RAM 3D Web Portal" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.17, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/murray/.
column3: Researchers can access the RAM3D web portal, which is currently hosted at the University of South Florida. The URL for the site is http://aist.usf.edu/ram3d/, as mentioned in the ISAW Papers 7.17 (2014) by William Murray.

column1: What is the main focus of the article "Assessing the Suitability of Existing OWL Ontologies for the Representation of Narrative Structures in Sumerian Literature" by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller?
column2: The main focus of the article "Assessing the Suitability of Existing OWL Ontologies for the Representation of Narrative Structures in Sumerian Literature" by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller is to evaluate the suitability of existing OWL ontologies, specifically the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CIDOC CRM) and Ontomedia (OM), for representing narrative structures in Sumerian literature. The article discusses the creation of a new ontology called mORSuL (the multi-Ontology Representing Sumerian Literature) by combining elements from these existing ontologies to represent the ambiguous, incomplete, and unknown literary narratives found in Sumerian compositions. Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: The main focus of the article "Assessing the Suitability of Existing OWL Ontologies for the Representation of Narrative Structures in Sumerian Literature" by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller is to evaluate the effectiveness of existing tools for representing the ambiguous and often incomplete narratives found in Sumerian literature. The research project involved a review and evaluation of two OWL ontologies, the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CIDOC CRM) and Ontomedia (OM), which were thought to be suitable for representing cultural heritage data and narrative structures. The project resulted in the creation of mORSuL (the multi-Ontology Representing Sumerian Literature), a combination of the CIDOC CRM and OM, along with some additional elements. The ontology was then tested with a case-study example, the Sumerian composition "Three Ox-drivers of Adab".

column1: How does the author describe the role of ontologies in organizing knowledge and enabling automated inference?
column2: The author describes ontologies as formalized structures used for organizing knowledge in Computer Science. Together with a knowledge base and a reasoner, ontologies form an expert system that enables automated inference over a given dataset. By publishing data in machine-readable, non-proprietary formats with clear URIs, systems can share knowledge effectively. The linking of datasets through ontologies allows for enriched datasets by accessing relevant information from external data streams across the Web. Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: Ontologies play a significant role in organizing knowledge and enabling automated inference, as described by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller in ISAW Papers 7.18 (2014). In the realm of computer science, ontologies refer to a formalized structure used for organizing knowledge. When combined with a knowledge base (a triple store) and a reasoner (software), an ontological structure forms an expert system that enables automated inference over a given dataset. This system can function without publication via the web, but doing so allows the system to access an enriched dataset as more relevant information becomes available from separate external data-streams across the web.

column1: What are the two OWL ontologies identified by the author as suitable for representing cultural heritage data and narrative structures?
column2: The two OWL ontologies identified by the author as suitable for representing cultural heritage data and narrative structures are the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CIDOC CRM) and Ontomedia (OM). Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: The author, Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller, identified two OWL ontologies as suitable for representing cultural heritage data and narrative structures in her research project. These are the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CIDOC CRM) and Ontomedia (OM). The CIDOC CRM is an event-based reference model designed for linking cross-domain cultural heritage data and has been used by institutions with large cuneiform collections. OM, on the other hand, is designed for the representation of narrative and is designed to link to the CIDOC CRM. It consists of several interlinking sub-ontologies and is considered a domain-specific upper-level ontology (ISAW Papers 7.18, 2014).

column1: How was the ontology "mORSuL" created and what specific elements were added to it?
column2: The ontology "mORSuL" was created by combining the CIDOC CRM and Ontomedia (OM) and adding specific elements deemed necessary for representing Sumerian literature. Some of the specific elements added to mORSuL include the mapping of bibliographical data as published by the ETCSL, the representation of literary tools such as similes, metaphors, and analogies, and the reduction of the structure to contain only classes and properties that match the data available from the ETCSL. Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: The ontology "mORSuL" was created by combining the CIDOC CRM and OM ontologies, along with the addition of several specific elements deemed necessary. The CIDOC CRM is an event-based reference model designed for linking cross-domain cultural heritage data, while OM is an ontology designed for the representation of narrative. These were chosen due to their suitability for representing cultural heritage data and narrative structures. The specific elements added to mORSuL were not detailed in the provided context. This information is from the paper "Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller, published in ISAW Papers 7.18 (2014).

column1: Can you provide an example case study mentioned in the article that tests the ontological representation of Sumerian literature narratives?
column2: One example case study mentioned in the article is the composition "Three Ox-drivers of Adab." This composition is considered to be humorous and has a narrative structure with repetitive patterns within a frame story. The representation of this narrative was limited to the first 35 lines due to the incomplete nature of the latter part of the piece. The story involves three friends from Adab who seek justice from the king after a dispute. They are ox-drivers, each owning different animals, and face a dilemma regarding the ownership of a calf born in their absence. The king seeks the advice of a "cloistered lady" to solve the riddle, but the composition remains fractured and incomplete, leaving the audience in suspense without closure. Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: The article mentions a case study that tests the ontological representation of Sumerian literature narratives, specifically the composition "Three Ox-drivers of Adab". This composition is thought to be humorous and has a narrative structure with repetitive patterns within a frame story. Due to the incomplete nature of the latter part of the piece, the representation was limited to the first 35 lines only. This composition was used to test mORSuL, a tool for representing Sumerian narratives (Nurmikko-Fuller, ISAW Papers 7.18, 2014).

column1: What are some of the challenges and decisions that arise when representing the narrative content of Sumerian literature through ontological structures?
column2:
Some of the challenges and decisions that arise when representing the narrative content of Sumerian literature through ontological structures include:

1. Deciding on the level of realism: Determining how to represent the narrative content realistically within the ontological structure, considering that the events are fictional but set in a historical context like the city of Adab.

2. Character representation: Defining fictional characters as instances of a specific class (e.g., omb:Character) and attributing them with unique qualities and relationships, such as alliances and enmities.

3. Complex events representation: Handling complex narrative events, such as the ox-drivers' decision to seek justice, and deciding whether to treat them as instances of a specific subclass (e.g., ome:Social) within the ontological structure.

4. Focalized storytelling: Addressing the issue of focalized storytelling, where the narrative is based on the memories and retelling of events by characters like the ox-drivers and the king, leading to the concept of "composite memory."

These are just a few examples of the challenges and decisions that need to be considered when representing the narrative content of Sumerian literature through ontological structures. Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: Representing the narrative content of Sumerian literature through ontological structures presents several challenges and decisions. Firstly, the narrative events, although fictional, are set in historical contexts, such as the city of Adab, and adhere to the natural laws of our reality, requiring no suspension of disbelief from the reader. This necessitates careful decision-making in the representation of the narrative and the fabula (Bal, 2009). Secondly, the narrative may be a composite of several accounts, requiring amalgamation in the representation. The project also involves issues of Knowledge Representation, Description Logic, Coreference, and uses tools like SPARQL, RDF, URIs and OWL. Two OWL ontologies, the CIDOC Conceptual Reference Model (CIDOC CRM) and Ontomedia (OM), were evaluated for their suitability in representing cultural heritage data and narrative structures. The large and complex structure resulting from this process needs to be reduced to match the data available from the ETCSL. The ontology is also to be extended to allow for the mapping of bibliographical data and the representation of literary tools such as similes, metaphors and analogies (Nurmikko-Fuller, ISAW Papers 7.18, 2014).

column1: What are the next stages of the research project mentioned in the article, regarding the representation of Sumerian literary narratives using OWL ontologies?
column2: The next stages of the research project mentioned in the article include the extension and reduction of mORSuL, the addition of data from other Sumerian literary compositions, and querying the structure in terms of intertextuality, recurring motifs, and possible instances of literary allusions. Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller 2014,"Assessing the suitability of existing OWL ontologies for the representation of narrative structures in Sumerian literature" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.18, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/nurmikko/.
column3: The next stages of the research project on the representation of Sumerian literary narratives using OWL ontologies, as described by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller in ISAW Papers 7.18 (2014), include the extension and reduction of mORSuL, an ontology used in the project. Additionally, data from other Sumerian literary compositions will be added to the structure. This will allow for queries in terms of intertextuality, reoccurring motifs, and possible instances of literary allusions.

column1: What is Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) and what is its purpose?
column2: Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) is an interactive tool-kit designed for analyzing and visualizing prosopographical datasets. It provides software tools for name disambiguation, curation, collaboration, social network analysis, and graph visualization. BPS aims to assist researchers from various disciplines in working with prosopographical data derived from different text sources and formats. The main purpose of BPS is to facilitate prosopographical research by offering a comprehensive set of tools to manage and analyze complex datasets related to individuals mentioned in historical texts.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) is a comprehensive toolkit for analyzing and visualizing prosopographical datasets, developed by Laurie Pearce and Patrick Schmitz at the University of California Berkeley. The purpose of BPS is to facilitate prosopographical research by providing a suite of digital tools that can handle data from a variety of text sources and formats. These tools include a disambiguation engine for associating names with persons, an assertion model for researcher curation, social network analysis and graph visualization tools for understanding social relations, and a workspace model for research and collaboration. BPS is unique in its formalization and integration of probabilistic heuristics that prosopographers naturally apply in their research (ISAW Papers 7.19, 2014).

column1: What are some of the key features and tools provided by BPS for prosopographical research?
column2:
Some key features and tools provided by Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) for prosopographical research include:

1. Functionality to import TEI documents and convert them to the BPS data model.
2. A disambiguation engine to associate names with persons based on configurable heuristic rules.
3. An assertion model that supports flexible researcher curation and tracks provenance.
4. Social network analysis and graph visualization tools to analyze and understand social relations.
5. A workspace model supporting exploratory research and collaboration.

These tools help researchers analyze and visualize prosopographical datasets from various text sources and formats.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) provides a comprehensive suite of tools for prosopographical research, as detailed by Laurie Pearce and Patrick Schmitz in ISAW Papers 7.19 (2014). The BPS toolkit includes functionality to import TEI documents and convert them to a specific data model, a disambiguation engine that associates names to persons based on configurable heuristic rules, and an assertion model that supports flexible researcher curation and tracks provenance. It also offers social network analysis and graph visualization tools to analyze and understand social relations, and a workspace model that supports exploratory research and collaboration. The BPS model allows individual or collaborating researchers to approach a single corpus with different assertions, which can result in variant disambiguations. However, the assignment of unique identifiers to disambiguated individuals poses a challenge for BPS, which continues to investigate the application of unique identifiers to the results the tools generate.

column1: How does the BPS disambiguation model work in determining real-world person correspondences to name instances?
column2: The BPS disambiguation model works by positing a unique person for each name instance in each document and then attempting to collapse persons into one another based on user-configured rules that operate on various features of each original person. These features include filiation, activity, roles, and dates of activities. The rules of the model can shift weight from one person to another, boost the effect of applied shift rules, or discount the effect of applied shift rules. The end result is a set of probabilities for each name instance, indicating the set of real-world persons to which that name instance may correspond. Researchers can configure their confidence in each rule and review the results in the UI, deciding to confirm or discard the model's outcomes. Additionally, researchers can make assertions to override the computed results, specifying that a given name-citation is or is not the same person as another name-citation.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: The BPS disambiguation model works by initially positing a unique person for each name instance in each document. The model then attempts to collapse these persons into one another, such that the persons posited for name instances that refer to a given real-world person are collapsed into a single person in the model. The model produces weighted probabilities for each name-instance in a document, which researchers can review and decide to confirm or discard. The model also allows for the application of rules that provide additional evidence for a match or counter-indication. These rules can be applied within a document (intra-document rules) or across the corpus (inter-document rules). The results of the disambiguation process may vary as it reflects the computation of an algorithm defined by each user (Pearce and Schmitz, ISAW Papers 7.19, 2014).

column1: What are the three functions of the rules in the BPS disambiguation model?
column2:
The three functions of the rules in the BPS disambiguation model are:
1. Shift rules: These rules shift weight from one person to another.
2. Boost rules: These rules magnify the effect of applied shift rules.
3. Discount rules: These rules reduce the effect of applied shift rules.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: The rules in the BPS disambiguation model serve three main functions. Firstly, they are used to provide evidence for a match between name instances, which is modeled as a boost. This often leverages features like location or activity. Secondly, they provide evidence of counter-indication, which is modeled as a discount. This includes date rules that consider the typical lifespan and span of activity, along with the dates of respective activities. Lastly, the rules can apply to person/names within a document (intra-document rules), or to persons across the corpus (inter-document rules) (Berkeley Prosopography Services. Laurie Pearce and Patrick Schmitz. ISAW Papers 7.19 (2014)).

column1: How do researchers interact with the disambiguation model in BPS to confirm or discard results?
column2: Researchers interact with the disambiguation model in BPS by reviewing the weighted probabilities produced for each name-instance in a document in the user interface. They can then decide to confirm or discard the results of the model by making assertions. These assertions are modeled as actions that can override the computed results, similar to a boost or discount. Researchers can also set a confidence level on each assertion, allowing them to control how the heuristic proceeds and explore different scenarios.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: Researchers interact with the disambiguation model in BPS by reviewing the weighted probabilities for each name-instance in a document that the model has produced. They can then decide to confirm or discard the results of the model. These decisions are modeled as an action that the model can take to override the computed results, operating like a boost or discount. The user can optionally set a confidence on each assertion, so it may be more of a hint than a conclusion on their part. Other researchers working with the same corpus can accept selected assertions from a peer and apply them in their own workspace, and reject or ignore those with which they do not agree (Berkeley Prosopography Services. Laurie Pearce and Patrick Schmitz. ISAW Papers 7.19 (2014)).

column1: What is the challenge faced by BPS in implementing Linked Open Data (LOD) and how are researchers addressing this challenge?
column2: The challenge faced by BPS in implementing Linked Open Data (LOD) is related to assigning unique identifiers to disambiguated individuals due to the mutability of results generated by the probabilistic tools. Researchers are addressing this challenge by investigating the application of unique identifiers to the results generated by the tools in order to make use of Linked Open Data effectively.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: The Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) faces a challenge in implementing Linked Open Data (LOD) due to the assertion model, which complicates the assignment of unique identifiers. This is mentioned in the paper "Berkeley Prosopography Services" by Laurie Pearce and Patrick Schmitz (ISAW Papers 7.19, 2014). The context does not provide specific strategies that BPS is using to address this challenge. However, it is mentioned in "Origins and Antidotes of Omission: Southeastern European Archaeology, Linked Open Data, and the Possibilities for Archaeological Integration" by Hunnell Chen and Folsom (ISAW Papers 20.12, 2021) that researchers in data-intensive fields are developing and discussing practical solutions to common challenges of Linked Data, including maintaining and sharing datasets and creating connections between differently-developed and separately-maintained datasets.

column1: How does BPS differ from other prosopography tools and projects in terms of handling probabilistic heuristics and individual researcher assertions?
column2: BPS differs from other prosopography tools and projects by formalizing and integrating the probabilistic heuristics that prosopographers naturally apply in their research. It provides a workspace environment where individual or collaborating researchers can approach a single corpus with different assertions. Each modification may result in variant disambiguations, which the researcher can explore and either accept or reject. This flexibility in handling probabilistic heuristics and individual researcher assertions sets BPS apart from other tools and projects in the field of prosopography.  2014,"Berkeley Prosopography Services" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.19, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pearce-Schmitz/.
column3: Berkeley Prosopography Services (BPS) differs from other prosopography tools and projects in its approach to probabilistic heuristics and individual researcher assertions. BPS formalizes and integrates the probabilistic heuristics that prosopographers naturally apply in their research, which is a unique feature not found in other tools. Additionally, BPS provides a workspace environment where individual or collaborating researchers can approach a single corpus with different assertions. This allows for a more flexible and customizable research process, as researchers can accept, reject, or ignore assertions made by their peers, leading to potentially different results for each user (Pearce and Schmitz, ISAW Papers 7.19, 2014).

column1: What is the focus of the article "Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" by Daniel E.J. Pett?
column2: The focus of the article "Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" by Daniel E.J. Pett is on discussing the impact of the LAWDI events on the digital work and output of the United Kingdom's Portable Antiquities Scheme, specifically in terms of developing the Scheme's online presence towards Berners-Lee's 5 Stars of Linked data. The article also gives examples of Linked Data principles being utilized by the Portable Antiquities Scheme website. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The article "Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" by Daniel E.J. Pett focuses on the impact of the LAWDI events on the digital work and output of the United Kingdom's Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS), which is based at the British Museum, London. The author discusses the progress of his work in developing the Scheme's online presence towards Berners-Lee's 5 Stars of Linked data following the two iterations of the LAWDI programme in 2012 and 2013. The article also provides examples of Linked Data principles being utilized by the PAS website. The PAS is a government-funded project that promotes the voluntary recording of archaeological objects found by members of the public in England and Wales. The data from these objects have been placed online within a dynamic database that is updated in real-time. The author explores the opportunities for implementing linked data techniques and collaborating with many of the attending projects.

column1: What is the Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) and what is its purpose?
column2: The Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) is a government-funded project in the United Kingdom that encourages the voluntary recording of archaeological objects found by the public in England and Wales. The PAS administers the Treasure Act process and maintains a database of archaeological objects ranging from the Prehistoric to Post-Medieval periods, with a focus on objects from the Roman Empire, particularly coins. The purpose of the PAS is to promote the recording and preservation of archaeological finds discovered by members of the public. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The Portable Antiquities Scheme (PAS) is a government-funded project in the United Kingdom that encourages the public to voluntarily record archaeological objects they find in England and Wales. The PAS also administers the Treasure Act process. The objects recorded on the PAS database range from the Prehistoric to Post-Medieval periods, with a large portion of the material attributed to the Roman Empire, the majority of which are coins. The PAS has recorded findspots for approximately 412,000 coins. The scheme has led to new works of synthesis and has been integrated into the Pelagios ecosystem, a digital project that connects online resources related to the ancient world (Pett, 2014; Gruber and Meadows, 2021).

column1: How has the PAS website evolved in terms of implementing Linked Data principles?
column2: The PAS website has evolved in terms of implementing Linked Data principles by integrating resources from English Heritage, the Ordnance Survey, Nomisma, VIAF, dbPedia, and the British Museum in a more structured manner. The website now produces RDF using XSLT on XML returned from SOLR indexes, following a model similar to the British Museum's representation of the CIDOC-CRM model. The PAS has also integrated with external identifiers, such as Nomisma and Pleiades, to enrich its data. Additionally, efforts have been made to enable a SPARQL endpoint to a self-hosted triple store, allowing for wider use of PAS data in applications within the LAWDI family and other LOD projects. The website has also aimed to increase the amount of structured data available via xhtml+rdfa pages and to forge partnerships for further resources. The PAS has received funding for projects related to crowd-sourcing, crowd-funding, and 3D visualization, which will contribute to the evolution of the website's Linked Data implementation. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The PAS website has evolved in its implementation of Linked Data principles by integrating with resources provided by English Heritage, the Ordnance Survey, Nomisma, VIAF, dbPedia and the British Museum. This integration was done in a more regimented fashion throughout the records of objects held within the database (Pett 2013). The website also began producing RDF by using XSLT on XML returned from the SOLR indexes that power PAS pages. This RDF was modeled in the same manner as the British Museum's representation of the CIDOC-CRM model. The PAS database is updated in real-time and the RDF is regenerated nightly through a scheduled cronjob that transforms the SOLR XML and saves it to the server. The website also integrated external identifiers into the PAS database schema to improve the enrichment of resources (Pett 2014).

column1: How did the LAWDI events in 2012 and 2013 impact the development of the PAS website?
column2: The LAWDI events in 2012 and 2013 had a significant impact on the development of the PAS website. Efforts were made to bring the PAS into the Pelagios family, integrating with resources like Pleiades identifiers. Data from the PAS database was used for visualizations and collaborations. Structured data implementation was enhanced with the use of Schema.org, Facebook's OpenGraph metadata tags, and Twitter cards. The PAS also aimed to link authority lists to external ones like VIAF and dbPedia. Post-2013, there was a focus on further developing the LOD capabilities of the PAS website, integrating with various resources like English Heritage, Nomisma, VIAF, and the British Museum. Plans included enabling a SPARQL endpoint and increasing the amount of structured data available on the website. Funding was secured for projects related to linked data production and consumption. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The LAWDI events in 2012 and 2013 significantly influenced the development of the PAS website. Following the 2013 event at Drew University, the author, Daniel E.J. Pett, began to further develop the Linked Open Data (LOD) capabilities of the PAS website. A decision was made to integrate with resources provided by English Heritage, the Ordnance Survey, Nomisma, VIAF, dbPedia and the British Museum in a more systematic way throughout the records of objects held within the database. Additionally, after the 2012 event at ISAW, efforts were made to bring the PAS into the Pelagios family, which was facilitated by the PAS database already using Pleiades identifiers within its schema. This led to the integration of PAS data into the Pelagios ecosystem. The author also intends to develop the LOD capabilities of the PAS further, with work currently underway to enable a SPARQL endpoint to a self-hosted triple store. (Source: Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web. Daniel E.J. Pett. ISAW Papers 7.20 (2014))

column1: What future developments are planned for the PAS website in terms of LOD capabilities and content negotiation?
column2: The future developments planned for the PAS website include enabling a SPARQL endpoint to a self-hosted triple store through software like Apache Marmotta or Fuseki. This is intended to allow PAS data to be used in more applications within the LAWDI family and potentially feed into other LOD projects. Additionally, efforts are being made to modify the Zend Framework based PAS system to allow for full content negotiation and potentially replace the 'Share-Alike' Creative Commons license with a simpler CC-BY version. The goal is to increase the amount of structured data available via the xhtml+rdfa pages of the website and database, seek out further resources to link to, and forge partnerships to enhance the PAS website's capabilities. Funding from the Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) is supporting projects related to crowd-sourcing, crowd-funding, 3D visualization, and visualizations with Tracemedia, with results expected to be published in print and online in the coming years. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: Future developments for the PAS website include enhancing its Linked Open Data (LOD) capabilities and modifying the Zend Framework based PAS system to allow for full content negotiation. The LOD capabilities are being developed through the evaluation of software such as Apache Marmotta and Fuseki, with the aim of enabling a SPARQL endpoint to a self-hosted triple store. This is expected to allow PAS data to be used in more applications within the LAWDI family. The content negotiation aspect involves the potential modification of the Zend Framework based PAS system, ideally leading to the removal of the 'Share-Alike Creative Commons licence and its replacement with a simpler CC-BY version. The goal is to increase the amount of structured data available via the xhtml+rdfa pages of the website and database. Further resources to link to will be sought out and partnerships forged (Daniel E.J. Pett. ISAW Papers 7.20 (2014)).

column1: How has the PAS website utilized structured data and metadata tags for enrichment of resources?
column2: The PAS website has utilized structured data and metadata tags for the enrichment of resources in various ways. They have implemented microformats, RDFa, FOAF standards, Schema.org, and Facebook's OpenGraph metadata tags extensively within their HTML templates. Additionally, they have used Twitter cards for concise previews of content. By incorporating these structured data elements, they have enriched their website with dynamic data drawn directly from their database, providing aggregated biographical pages and enriching coin guides with additional information. The PAS has also linked external identifiers to their vocabulary and authority lists, allowing for a more comprehensive enrichment of resources. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The PAS website has utilized structured data and metadata tags for the enrichment of resources in several ways. The author of the website has integrated external identifiers into the PAS database schema, which has improved the enrichment of resources. The website has also implemented more structured data within HTML templates, such as the use of Schema.org and Facebook's OpenGraph metadata tags. An example of this is the author's implementation of Twitter cards, where meta-tags are added to the head section of an HTML document, allowing Twitter user-interfaces to parse a concise preview of the content. Efforts were also made to reconcile the authority lists used for recording coins to external authority lists using OpenRefine against VIAF and dbPedia (Pett, 2014).

column1: How has the PAS website collaborated with other projects and institutions to enhance its linked data capabilities?
column2: The PAS website has collaborated with various projects and institutions to enhance its linked data capabilities. Some of the collaborations include integrating resources from English Heritage, the Ordnance Survey, Nomisma, VIAF, dbPedia, and the British Museum into the records of objects held within the database. The PAS has also integrated with the Pelagios ecosystem, hosted a mirror tile store of maps created by Johan Åhfeldt, and used the Pelagios widget, Nomisma, and Pleiades identifiers. Additionally, efforts have been made to reconcile terms against VIAF and dbPedia, and to align Roman mints with Pleiades identifiers. These collaborations have enriched the PAS website's resources and enabled further resource discovery and collaboration. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The PAS website has collaborated with other projects and institutions to enhance its linked data capabilities by integrating with resources provided by English Heritage, the Ordnance Survey, Nomisma, Virtual Identity Authorities Files (VIAF), dbPedia and the British Museum. This integration was done in a more regimented fashion throughout the records of objects held within the database. The website also links to external resources such as the Encyclopaedia of Life, as shown by Kansa in his 2013 presentations. Furthermore, the website has collaborated with many projects that were beginning their adventure into the world of Linked and Open Data (LOD), which could provide data that the PAS software could consume and use for enrichment of its own website (Pett 2010b, Gruber et al. 2012).

column1: What funding and projects are in place to further develop the PAS website's capabilities in linked data and resource enrichment?
column2: Funding has been provided by the Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) for two projects aimed at enhancing the production and consumption of linked data within the PAS website. One project focuses on crowd-sourcing, crowd-funding, and 3D visualization in collaboration with UCL, receiving £318,000 in funding. The other project is a visualization project with Tracemedia, receiving £5,000 in funding. The results of these projects are expected to be published in print and online during 2014 and the first quarter of 2015.
