Additionally, efforts are being made to enable a SPARQL endpoint to a self-hosted triple store through software evaluation, such as Apache Marmotta and Fuseki, to allow PAS data to be used in more applications within the LAWDI family and other LOD projects. The goal is to reach the 5 stars level of linked data by quarter one of 2014. Daniel E.J. Pett 2014,"Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.20, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/pett/.
column3: The PAS website has received funding from the Arts and Humanities Research Council (AHRC) for two projects aimed at enhancing its capabilities in linked data and resource enrichment. One project, in collaboration with UCL, is focused on crowd-sourcing, crowd-funding, and 3D visualisation, and has been granted £318,000. The other is a visualisation project with Tracemedia, which has received £5,000. These projects are expected to improve the production and consumption of linked data on the PAS website (Linking Portable Antiquities to a Wider Web. Daniel E.J. Pett. ISAW Papers 7.20, 2014).

column1: What challenges are faced by scholars studying the ancient city of Pompeii, according to the article?
column2: According to the article, scholars studying the ancient city of Pompeii face challenges related to the vast and uneven archive of scholarship. Information about Pompeii has been ignored, neglected, destroyed, and left unreported and unpublished. The excavation and scholarship of Pompeii prove to be difficult due to the scattered nature of published materials across various libraries and archives, making it challenging to discover relevant sources. Additionally, the high cost and limited distribution of important publications like the Nova Bibliotheca Pompeiana have hindered the study of Pompeii. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: According to Eric Poehler in ISAW Papers 7.21, scholars studying the ancient city of Pompeii face numerous challenges. The vast and uneven archive of scholarship is spread across the world in hundreds of libraries and archives, hidden in obscure and defunct journals, travel diaries, monographs, and illustrations. The excavation and scholarship of Pompeii prove a nightmare of omissions and disasters, with each generation discovering the extent to which information has been ignored, neglected, destroyed, and left unreported and unpublished. Additionally, the high cost of books and their physical format limit the organization and wide distribution of its contents. Furthermore, there is a perennial problem of poor quality, lack of standardization, and differing interpretations of space in published maps.

column1: How did the Nova Bibliotheca Pompeiana (NBP) attempt to address the challenges in studying Pompeii's scholarship?
column2: The Nova Bibliotheca Pompeiana (NBP) attempted to address the challenges in studying Pompeii's scholarship by compiling 14,596 annotated citations into a single compendium. This effort aimed to bring together scattered titles from various sources, making it easier for scholars to access relevant information about Pompeii. However, the high cost of the book limited its distribution, and being a physical book restricted the organization of its contents to a single format. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The Nova Bibliotheca Pompeiana (NBP), published by Laurentino Garcia y Garcia in 1998, attempted to address the challenges in studying Pompeii's scholarship by compiling an extensive compendium of 14,596 annotated citations. This brought together a wide range of titles relevant to Pompeii for the first time, making it easier for researchers to discover relevant sources. However, the NBP's impact was limited due to its high cost and physical format, which prevented wide distribution and limited the organization of its contents to a single format (ISAW Papers 7.21, Eric Poehler).

column1: What are the three main components of the Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR)?
column2:
The three main components of the Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) are:

1. Bibliographic Database and Full-Text Document Repository
2. Geographical Information System (GIS)
3. User Interface Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) is composed of three main components. These include a Bibliographic Database and Full-Text Document Repository, a Geographical Information System (GIS), and a User Interface. This information is provided by Eric Poehler in the ISAW Papers 7.21.

column1: How does the PBMR aim to revolutionize research on Pompeii?
column2: The PBMR aims to revolutionize research on Pompeii by providing a comprehensive subject repository searchable through a GIS map. It allows users to easily navigate Pompeii's landscape, access extensive information about locations, conduct exhaustive searches on multiple subjects, and produce comprehensive bibliographies and maps illustrating spatial relationships. This tool saves time and effort that would otherwise be spent on conducting exhaustive searches or mapping results, making research on Pompeii more efficient and effective. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) aims to revolutionize research on Pompeii by providing a comprehensive, searchable bibliography and an up-to-date map of the ancient city. The PBMR, as described by Eric Poehler in ISAW Papers 7.21, is a web-based research tool that allows users to navigate Pompeii's landscape and discover extensive information about specific locations. It also includes a Geographical Information System (GIS) component that can generate custom maps for diverse user groups. Furthermore, the PBMR serves as an analysis tool, enabling users to ask a series of questions and receive data-rich answers. It also provides a location for users to upload and maintain files they generate, thereby continually improving the carto-bibliography of the ancient city.

column1: How can the GIS component of the PBMR be utilized by students, researchers, and visitors to Pompeii?
column2:
The GIS component of the PBMR can be utilized by students, researchers, and visitors to Pompeii in several ways:

1. **Students**: Students working on a particular building can create both overview and detailed maps to illustrate their study based on information provided by the PBMR. This allows them to have a visual representation of their research and study areas.

2. **Researchers**: Researchers can use the map via mobile devices to navigate the actual ruins of Pompeii. This is particularly valuable considering the regular shortages of paper maps available to visitors at the site. Researchers can also benefit from the spatial analysis tools provided by the GIS component to refine their research based on the landscape of the city.

3. **Visitors**: Visitors to Pompeii can also use the map via mobile devices to navigate the ruins. This can enhance their experience and understanding of the site. Additionally, the GIS component can help visitors explore the spatial relationships within Pompeii, providing a richer context for their visit.

Overall, the GIS component of the PBMR serves as a powerful mapping tool that can generate custom maps for diverse user groups, enabling students, researchers, and visitors to Pompeii to access and interact with information in a more visual and interactive way. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The Geographical Information System (GIS) component of the Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) provides a powerful mapping tool that can generate custom maps for diverse user groups. Students can use it to create both overview and detailed maps to illustrate their studies, based on information provided by the PMBR as a research tool (Poehler, ISAW Papers 7.21). Researchers can use the GIS to conduct exhaustive searches on multiple subjects, simultaneously producing comprehensive bibliographies for each location and maps illustrating their spatial relationships in the landscape of Pompeii (Poehler, ISAW Papers 7.21). Visitors to Pompeii can use the map via mobile devices to navigate the actual ruins of Pompeii, overcoming the regular shortages of paper maps available at the site (Poehler, ISAW Papers 7.21).

column1: How does the PBMR combine bibliographic analysis tools with spatial analysis tools to enhance research capabilities?
column2: The PBMR combines bibliographic analysis tools with spatial analysis tools to enhance research capabilities by allowing users to vacillate between spatial analysis tools and bibliographic analysis tools. This process produces results that are impossible to achieve through any other method. Users can conduct multilingual searches for specific terms, such as "House / Casa / Haus / Maison," and receive hundreds of citations along with highlighted locations on the map. By filtering these results spatially, users can refine their search based on specific criteria, such as the area each house occupied. This combination of spatial and bibliographic analysis tools allows for nuanced and data-rich results in a matter of minutes, providing extensive documentation for specific research inquiries. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) enhances research capabilities by combining bibliographic analysis tools with spatial analysis tools. According to Eric Poehler in ISAW Papers 7.21, the PBMR allows users to navigate Pompeii's landscape and discover extensive information about a location, including its name, type, images, size, and bibliography. The Geographical Information System (GIS) component of the PBMR provides a powerful mapping tool that can generate custom maps for diverse user groups. The combination of the bibliographic database and GIS allows the user to switch between spatial analysis tools and bibliographic analysis tools, a process that produces results impossible to achieve in any other method. For example, a multilingual search for "House" in the PBMR would yield hundreds of citations along with hundreds of locations highlighted on the map. The PBMR also provides a location to upload, maintain, and serve the files generated by users, allowing the carto-bibliography of the ancient city to continually improve.

column1: In what ways can the model created by the PBMR be applied to other subjects or disciplines in the humanities?
column2: The model created by the PBMR can be applied to other subjects or disciplines in the humanities by populating the shell with bibliographic and spatial data and building connections between them. For example, other large archaeological sites like Teotihuacan in Mexico or Angkor Wat in Cambodia could benefit from this system. It can also be applied to broader geographies, historical mapping of the bibliography of the crusades, or mapping literary landscapes of important genres in English or other modern languages. The visualization of spatial relationships among texts and locations within them can lead to new ways of thinking about various subjects. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The model created by the Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) can be applied to other subjects or disciplines in the humanities by populating the shell with bibliographic and spatial data and building the connections between them. This could be beneficial for other large, densely occupied archaeological sites such as Teotihuacan in Mexico or Angkor Wat in Cambodia. Moreover, the model could be used for historical mapping of the bibliography of the crusades or for mapping the literary landscapes of important genres in English or other modern languages. This could include naturalists of the Romantic period, Victorian era London, or the diffusion and impact of early Buddhist texts (Eric Poehler, ISAW Papers 7.21).

column1: How does the PBMR aim to facilitate new ways of thinking about various subjects through visualization of spatial relationships among texts and locations?
column2: The PBMR aims to facilitate new ways of thinking about various subjects through visualization of spatial relationships among texts and locations by providing a powerful mapping tool that can generate custom maps for diverse user groups. By populating the shell with bibliographic and spatial data and building connections between them, users can apply the model created by the PBMR to other subjects or disciplines in the humanities. For example, users can map the literary landscapes of important genres, historical mapping of the bibliography of the crusades, or even broader geographies like other archaeological sites such as Teotihuacan in Mexico or Angkor Wat in Cambodia. This visualization of spatial relationships among texts and locations can lead to new insights and perspectives on the subjects being studied. Eric Poehler 2014,"Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.21, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/poehler/.
column3: The Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource (PBMR) aims to facilitate new ways of thinking about various subjects through the visualization of spatial relationships among texts and locations by combining a bibliographic database with a Geographic Information System (GIS). This combination allows users to switch between spatial analysis tools and bibliographic analysis tools, generating results that would be impossible to achieve through any other method. For example, a multilingual search for "House" in the PBMR would yield hundreds of citations along with hundreds of locations highlighted on the map. The PBMR model could also be applied to other subjects or disciplines in the humanities by populating the shell with bibliographic and spatial data and building connections between them. This could lead to new ways of thinking about subjects such as the historical mapping of the bibliography of the crusades or the literary landscapes of important genres in English or other modern languages (Pompeii Bibliography and Mapping Resource. Eric Poehler. ISAW Papers 7.21).

column1: What challenges do students face when trying to conceptualize time in the past, according to the article?
column2: Students face challenges when trying to conceptualize time in the past, especially when it comes to the conventional temporal divisions or "periods" used to group and categorize the art, archaeological remains, and historical events of the ancient world. The article mentions that students sometimes struggle to place objects within a historical, archaeological, or art-historical period and to assign corresponding date ranges. The article also notes that students may feel like they are picking terms and dates at random when asked to do so. This difficulty in understanding ancient time is attributed to the fact that developments that took place over centuries appear to have happened all at once, creating a sense of confusion and a flattening of ancient time. Additionally, the article highlights that the idea of "periods" is essentially arbitrary conventions about which scholars disagree, making it challenging for students to grasp the periodization of the ancient world. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: According to Adam Rabinowitz in "It's about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" (ISAW Papers 7.22, 2014), students face several challenges when trying to conceptualize time in the past. One of the main difficulties is the arbitrary nature of periods, which can lead to confusion and the belief that the periodization of the ancient world is impossible to learn. The conventional temporal divisions or periods used to categorize the art, archaeological remains, and historical events of the ancient world can be hard to grasp. The situation is further complicated by the imprecise dates of historical periods, especially as one moves further back in time. The boundaries and names of these periods can differ from culture to culture and from scholar to scholar, and can also change over time as new evidence is collected or new historical paradigms are adopted.

column1: How has the Linked Ancient World Data environment utilized conceptual entities like people, places, and texts?
column2: The Linked Ancient World Data environment has utilized conceptual entities like people, places, and texts as the foundations for a growing infrastructure that makes it easier to discover semantically-related information. Authoritative spatial gazetteers like the Pleiades platform have enabled the extraction of maps from texts by matching place names to geographic coordinates. This has facilitated initiatives like the Pelagios Project to bring together material associated with the same site in different databases. The use of Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) for people, places, and things has helped in overcoming barriers to discovery created by different metadata schemata, vocabularies, or languages. This approach has enhanced the ability to link information across various datasets and sources in the Linked Ancient World Data environment. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The Linked Ancient World Data environment has utilized conceptual entities like people, places, and texts as foundations for its growing infrastructure. It uses Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) for these entities to sidestep barriers to discovery created by different metadata schemata, vocabularies, or languages. This requires a general agreement about the identity of the underlying entity. For instance, different names for Athens must refer to the same socio-political unit located at the same geographic coordinates. Authoritative spatial gazetteers like the Pleiades platform have made it possible to extract maps from texts by matching place names to geographic coordinates. They have also provided a conceptual connection that initiatives such as the Pelagios Project have used to bring together material associated with the same site in different databases (Rabinowitz, ISAW Papers 7.22, 2014).

column1: Why have periods proven to work poorly with Linked Data principles, according to the article?
column2: Periods have proven to work poorly with Linked Data principles because individual periods are considered concepts of convenience, often invented by a single scholar and then modified and debated over time. They are deliberately left vague in temporal terms to protect their usefulness for relative chronologies. This lack of objective existence and the varying definitions of periods by different scholars make it challenging to establish well-defined entities for linking, which is a requirement for Linked Data principles. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: According to Adam Rabinowitz in "It's about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data," periods have proven to work poorly with Linked Data principles because they are not well-defined entities. Periods are conceptual divisions created to organize information, often after the fact, and are deliberately left vague in temporal terms to maintain their usefulness for relative chronologies. They also have spatial boundaries and are often bounded by events, adding to their complexity. This complexity and lack of objective existence make periods difficult to reconcile in different datasets and to represent as structured data in Linked Data models.

column1: How did the development of GeoDia lead to the realization of the need for a different approach to periodization?
column2: The development of GeoDia led to the realization of the need for a different approach to periodization because the original design of GeoDia focused on archaeological and art-historical periodization. However, problems arose when attempting to use a generic periodization approach, as it led to conflicts between the date ranges of periods and the history of specific sites. For example, the case of Pompeii, which existed during the "Flavian period" but was abruptly ended by the eruption of Vesuvius in AD 79, highlighted the limitations of a generic periodization model. This led to the development of a data model where the basic unit was the "site period," representing a local manifestation with a site-specific date range of a more general period concept. This shift in approach highlighted the complexities and idiosyncrasies of periodization, prompting the need for a more flexible and site-specific method of defining periods. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: During the development of GeoDia, an interactive spatial timeline of ancient Mediterranean history and archaeology, Adam Rabinowitz encountered the problem of periodization. He found that using a generic periodization could lead to sites being represented with periods that were not used to describe them in the literature. For example, though Pompeii exists during the more general Flavian period, that site ends abruptly in AD 79, in the middle of that period, with the eruption of Vesuvius. This led to the realization that a different approach to periodization was needed, one that recognizes the fact that different scholars can conceptualize the same time range or cultural phenomenon quite differently, while others use the same terms to describe time ranges or cultural phenomena that differ to varying degrees. This led to a data-model in which the basic unit was the site period, in most cases a local manifestation, with a site-specific date range, of a more general period concept. (ISAW Papers 7.22 (2014), Adam Rabinowitz)

column1: What is the PeriodO project, and what is its goal in relation to period assertions?
column2: The PeriodO project is a Linked Data gazetteer of period assertions that aims to provide stable references for what authorities say about periods, rather than imposing consensus about what periods are. Its goal is to accommodate conflicting or changing definitions for periods, provide structured period assertions in a JSON-LD schema, include terms used to refer to periods, coordinates describing them in time and space, and provide references to the sources from which those coordinates were derived. The project also plans to create a community of contributors to the gazetteer and offer a visualization interface to make it easier to find periods, compare different temporal definitions, and eventually build a reconciliation service and a SPARQL endpoint for easier implementation and reuse of the dataset. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The PeriodO project, as described by Adam Rabinowitz in "It's about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" and "Time for Linked Open Data", is a bottom-up Linked Data gazetteer of period assertions. Its goal is to provide a set of stable references for what authorities say about periods, rather than imposing a consensus about what periods are. The project aims to house a repository of period assertions, each defined by temporal and spatial boundaries according to a particular authoritative source. These period assertions can be contributed by users, allowing for the addition of new periods to existing authorities or the creation of new authorities. The project also plans to make these period assertions machine-readable and resolvable through the use of DOIs.

column1: How does the article propose to address the diverse ways in which scholars understand and use periodization in their research?
column2: The article proposes the creation of a bottom-up Linked Data gazetteer of period assertions called PeriodO. This gazetteer aims to provide stable references for what authorities say about periods, rather than imposing a consensus on what periods are. It will include terms used to refer to periods, coordinates describing them in time and space, and references to the sources from which those coordinates were derived. This approach allows for accommodating conflicting or changing definitions for periods, mirroring the diverse ways scholars use and understand periodization in their research. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The article proposes addressing the diverse ways in which scholars understand and use periodization in their research through the Periods, Organized (PeriodO) project. This project, as described by Adam Rabinowitz in "It's about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data", aims to create a bottom-up Linked Data gazetteer of period assertions. This would provide stable references for what authorities say about periods, rather than attempting to impose a consensus about what periods are. The PeriodO project also focuses on tracking derivative relationships across definitions in different authorities and developing visualization tools to compare the spatiotemporal extents assigned to the same term by different scholars at different times. This approach is intended to mirror scholarly practice in the description of periods as Linked Data.

column1: Why does the article argue against the development of a consensus-based gazetteer for globally-recognized period concepts?
column2: The article argues against the development of a consensus-based gazetteer for globally-recognized period concepts because it states that even if such a vocabulary could be developed and adopted by data managers, it would not be able to retroactively deal with the diversity of period definitions already present in existing print and digital resources without losing significant information. Additionally, the article mentions that it is not desirable to smooth out scholarly disagreements and differences regarding the definition of periods, as these discussions are seen as a fundamental part of the rich history of scholarship on the ancient world. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The article argues against the development of a consensus-based gazetteer for globally-recognized period concepts because it would not adequately accommodate the diversity of period definitions already present in existing resources. The author, Adam Rabinowitz, believes that such a gazetteer would result in a significant loss of information and would not be able to handle scholarly disagreements and differences regarding the definition of periods. He asserts that these disagreements are a fundamental part of the rich history of scholarship on the ancient world, and a solution must take into account the diverse ways in which scholars use and understand periodization.

column1: How does the article suggest mirroring scholarly practice in the description of periods as Linked Data?
column2: The article suggests mirroring scholarly practice in the description of periods as Linked Data by creating a bottom-up Linked Data gazetteer of period assertions. This approach involves providing stable references for what authorities say about periods, rather than imposing a consensus about what periods are. The Periods, Organized (PeriodO) project aims to present period assertions in a JSON-LD schema that includes the term or label used by the source, a date range expressed in Julian Days, an associated geographic entity, and an authoritative source linked to a URI. This method allows for the accommodation of conflicting or changing definitions for periods, reflecting the diverse ways in which scholars use and understand periodization in their scholarship. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The article suggests that mirroring scholarly practice in the description of periods as Linked Data involves using precise but idiosyncratic definitions that best fit the material at hand, while also citing the sources of those definitions. This approach aims to maintain the specificity that is a basic tenet of scholarly communication. Furthermore, a Linked Data resource for periods should include both the terms used to refer to periods and the coordinates used to describe them in time and space, as well as references to the source(s) from which those coordinates were derived. This is according to Adam Rabinowitz in "It's about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" (ISAW Papers 7.22, 2014).

column1: What are some of the key features of the PeriodO data model for period assertions?
column2:
Some key features of the PeriodO data model for period assertions include:
1. The model includes the term or label used by the source for the period.
2. It provides a date range expressed in Julian Days in scientific notation, with the number of significant digits indicating the degree of precision of the start and end dates.
3. An associated geographic entity (country, region, or site) from a Linked Data gazetteer (Pleiades, Wikidata, GeoNames, etc.).
4. An authoritative source linked to a URI, e.g., from VIAF, wherever possible. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The PeriodO data model for period assertions, as described by Adam Rabinowitz in "It's about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" and "Time for Linked Open Data", is built around two basic datatypes. The first datatype includes statements that identify temporal and spatial boundaries for a period term according to a particular authoritative source, which were initially called definitions but are now labeled periods. The second datatype consists of sets of definitions expressed by the same authoritative source, initially called collections but now referred to as authorities. The model allows users to contribute new periods to existing authorities or to contribute new authorities. The data interface has been redesigned to improve spatial and temporal visualizations, searching and browsing, and to facilitate the creation of new authorities and periods by users. The period assertions are presented in a JSON-LD schema that includes the term or label used by the source, a date range expressed in Julian Days in scientific notation, an associated geographic entity from a Linked Data gazetteer, and an authoritative source linked to a URI.

column1: How does the article propose to build a community of contributors to the PeriodO gazetteer?
column2: The article proposes to build a community of contributors to the PeriodO gazetteer by using Github to house the repository initially. It will provide user-management tools to allow authoritative users to add their own URIs for period definitions they prefer. This approach aims to encourage contributions from scholars and users to the gazetteer, fostering a community of practice around period assertions. Adam Rabinowitz 2014,"It’s about time: historical periodization and Linked Ancient World Data" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.22, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/rabinowitz.
column3: The article proposes to build a community of contributors to the PeriodO gazetteer by providing user-management tools through Github. This will allow authoritative users to add their own period definitions if they cannot find a suitable URI for their preferred definition. The project also incorporates a specific workflow for the addition of data by the user community. The success of this initiative will depend on the development of a scholarly community of practice, with members willing to implement period assertion URIs in their own datasets and contribute new period assertions to the gazetteer. This approach is seen as a grassroots starting point to explore possibilities (Adam Rabinowitz, ISAW Papers 7.22 (2014) and ISAW Papers 20.3 (2021)).

column1: How is the American School of Classical Studies (ASCSA) adapting to digital editions while still maintaining traditional print publications?
column2: The American School of Classical Studies (ASCSA) is adapting to digital editions by publishing digital issues ahead of print with their quarterly journal Hesperia. They also offer print+digital bundles for customers who prefer content in that format. Additionally, ASCSA encourages authors to submit stable URIs to multimedia and data sets cited in their manuscripts, and they are seeing an increase in that material upon final submission. The ASCSA has also been trending towards Open Access, making content freely available online. They are working on policy changes to make digital editions of monographs available for free download three years after publication. Overall, ASCSA is embracing digital formats while still supporting traditional print publications. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The American School of Classical Studies (ASCSA) is adapting to digital editions by publishing digital issues ahead of print with their quarterly journal Hesperia. They also offer print+digital bundles to satisfy readers who prefer both formats. They encourage authors to submit stable URIs to multimedia and data sets cited or linked within their manuscripts. The ASCSA is also moving towards Open Access, making content freely available for download and sharing via their website. Despite these digital advancements, they reassure their traditional readers that they are not abandoning print publications. They have also proposed a policy change to make digital editions of monographs available for free download three years after publication, further bridging the gap between print and digital. (Source: Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability.ISAW Papers 7.23 (2014))

column1: What steps has the ASCSA taken towards Open Access dissemination of content, as mentioned in the text?
column2: The ASCSA has taken steps towards Open Access dissemination of content by making Hesperia largely Open Access outside of JSTOR's 3-year moving wall, with over 1,500 articles now freely available for download and sharing via the ASCSA's website. Additionally, the Publications Committee of the ASCSA was set to vote on a policy change in January 2014 to make digital editions of monographs available for free download three years after publication. The ASCSA has also provided PDFs for free upon request and negotiated with JSTOR to receive metadata and files for hosted content, enabling linking from scanned excavation notebooks to specific published pages. These efforts align with the goal of making content easily discoverable and immediately accessible in an open fashion. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The American School of Classical Studies (ASCSA) has taken several steps towards Open Access dissemination of content. They have been repurposing content for use on the Web and other platforms using Adobe InDesign. The ASCSA has been trending towards Open Access and has made Hesperia largely Open Access outside of JSTOR's 3-year moving wall, with over 1,500 articles now freely available for download and sharing via the ASCSA's website (Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability.ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014). The Publications Committee of the ASCSA also planned to vote on a policy change in January 2014 to make digital editions of monographs available for free download three years after publication. They have also been giving away PDFs for free upon request. They have negotiated with JSTOR to receive all metadata and files at the page-level for all of their hosted content and have provided this data to the Athenian Agora (Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability.ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014). They have also created a Zotero account to actively publish citation data for all new ASCSA publications and uploaded legacy citation data for their backlist of monographs and articles published from 1932-2010 (Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability.ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014).

column1: How does the author suggest making archaeological publications "four-dimensional"?
column2: The author suggests making archaeological publications "four-dimensional" by incorporating time into the three-dimensional aspects of the publication. This means allowing the content to evolve and change over time, reflecting the dynamic nature of archaeological data and interpretations. By enabling updates, corrections, and additions to the text, the publication becomes more interactive and responsive to ongoing research and discussions. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The author suggests making archaeological publications "four-dimensional" by incorporating text, 2- and 3-D imagery, interactive 2- and 3-D maps, interactive data sets, and omni-directional links to content and context managed by others in an open, online environment. This approach allows for the representation of three-dimensional artifacts in four-dimensional space-time, reflecting the nature of archaeological work. The author also suggests that these publications should be open to criticism, dialogue, and growth over time, further adding the dimension of time to the publications. This is discussed in "Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" in ISAW Papers 7.23 (2014).

column1: What potential benefits are highlighted in the text for incorporating interactive elements like 3D reconstructions and data sets in online archaeological publications?
column2:
The potential benefits highlighted in the text for incorporating interactive elements like 3D reconstructions and data sets in online archaeological publications include:
1. Enhancing the reader's experience by providing a more robust and multi-dimensional view of the archaeological findings.
2. Allowing for a more interactive and engaging presentation of the data, which can aid in understanding complex archaeological information.
3. Enabling readers to explore artifacts in a more immersive way, such as being able to print out 3D copies of pots and bones featured in the publications.
4. Creating study collections that can be shared and utilized for educational purposes.
5. Facilitating the linking of data to external resources, promoting discoverability and accessibility of content.
6. Encouraging dialogue and scrutiny of the data and interpretations presented in the publications, leading to more objective arguments and potential for growth over time. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The text highlights several potential benefits of incorporating interactive elements like 3D reconstructions and data sets in online archaeological publications. These include the creation of study collections and the ability to print out 3D copies of artifacts, which could enhance understanding and engagement with the material (ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014). The use of such technology could also result in a more interactive experience with artifacts, allowing both researchers and the public digital access to archaeological collections (ISAW Papers 22.8, 2024). Furthermore, the integration of 3D models and computer animation in the field of cultural heritage has been recognized as an effective means of communication (ISAW Papers 21, 2021). Finally, the creation of online-only publications that incorporate these interactive elements could drive discussion and standardize publications of this type (ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014).

column1: What are the author's plans for future online publications in collaboration with other individuals?
column2: The author plans to partner with Bill Caraher, Kostis Kourelis, and others to create a new kind of online publication that publishes archaeological work as-it-happens while also discussing trends in archaeology. This publication aims to go beyond a traditional blog format. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The author plans to collaborate with Bill Caraher, Kostis Kourelis, and others to create a new kind of online publication that publishes archaeological work as it happens, while also writing about trends in archaeology. This new publication aims to go beyond a traditional blog format. The author also plans to link Hesperia articles and monographs to the data of others, including Pleiades, a promise they have yet to fulfill. These plans are mentioned in the paper "Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" (ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014).

column1: What are the two major issues that all publishers of archaeology are urged to address according to the text?
column2:
The two major issues that all publishers of archaeology are urged to address according to the text are:

1) How to publish archaeology online, moving away from a traditional, two-dimensional, print-informed model, toward a multi-dimensional, interactive one that accepts that archaeological data is messy and continues to grow and change over time.

2) How to publish archaeology in an open fashion that makes content easily discoverable and immediately accessible, promoting linking from external sources while linking itself to other open online resources. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: According to the ISAW Papers 7.23 (2014), the two major issues that all publishers of archaeology must address are: 1) how to publish archaeology online, transitioning from a traditional, two-dimensional, print-informed model to a multi-dimensional, interactive one that acknowledges that archaeological data is complex and continues to evolve over time, and 2) how to publish archaeology in an open manner that makes content easily discoverable and immediately accessible, promoting linking from external sources while linking itself to other open online resources.

column1: How does the author describe the role of the editor in the publication process, as mentioned in the text?
column2: The author describes the role of the editor as applying standards and style, fact-checking, cleaning up inconsistencies, verifying and standardizing notes and bibliography. The editor's role is to prepare the publication for publication, after which it can be handed over to the crowd for post-publication peer review. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The author describes the role of the editor in the publication process as one of ensuring quality and consistency. The editor should apply standards and style, fact-check, clean up inconsistencies, and verify and standardize notes and bibliography. Once these tasks are completed, the work can be published and handed over for post-publication peer review. This is part of the process of moving towards a more interactive, multi-dimensional model of publishing archaeology online, as discussed in "Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" (ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014).

column1: What policy changes are being worked on by the author in relation to the American School of Classical Studies at Athens (ASCSA)?
column2: The author is working on policy changes related to making digital editions of monographs available for free download three years after publication, providing PDFs for free upon request, and actively publishing citation data for all new ASCSA publications. Additionally, the author is working on ensuring a healthy, sustainable, and open future for the journal and books of the ASCSA through policy changes. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The author mentions that the Publications Committee of the American School of Classical Studies at Athens (ASCSA) is working on a policy change to make digital editions of monographs available for free download three years after publication. This is mentioned in the context of the author's efforts to increase the accessibility of ASCSA's publications, which include negotiating with JSTOR to receive all metadata and files at the page-level for all of their hosted content and providing this data to the Athenian Agora. The author also mentions working on a born-digital, online-only monograph that will incorporate various interactive and linked data elements, which is driving discussion in various committees as the ASCSA decides how peer review of online-only material will be conducted, how it will be published, and how it will be archived and preserved. These details are mentioned in "Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability.ISAW Papers 7.23 (2014)".

column1: How does the author envision the future of archaeological publications in terms of openness, accessibility, and interactivity?
column2: The author envisions the future of archaeological publications to be multi-dimensional, interactive, and open. They advocate for moving away from traditional, two-dimensional print models towards online publications that incorporate text, 2- and 3-D imagery, interactive maps, data sets, and links to external resources. The goal is to make content easily discoverable, immediately accessible, and open to dialogue and scrutiny. The author emphasizes the importance of providing stable URIs, embedding links, and utilizing widgets to enhance the reader's experience and facilitate access to underlying data for fact-checking and alternate interpretations. Overall, the future of archaeological publications is seen as dynamic, evolving, and inclusive of diverse perspectives. Andrew Reinhard 2014,"Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.23, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/reinhard/.
column3: The author envisions the future of archaeological publications as being more open, accessible, and interactive. They believe that new publications should incorporate elements such as text, 2- and 3-D imagery, interactive 2- and 3-D maps, interactive data sets, and omni-directional links to content and context managed by others. This would create a record and interpretation of discoveries that is open to criticism, dialogue, and growth over time. The author also suggests that readers should be able to print out 3D copies of artifacts featured in articles and monographs, creating study collections. They also express a desire to create a new kind of online publication that publishes archaeological work as it happens, while also discussing trends in archaeology. The author emphasizes the need for archaeological publications to be completely Open Access, following the new Diamond level of Open Access as described by Christian Fuchs and Marisol Sandoval in their September 2013 article published in tripleC. (Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability.ISAW Papers 7.23 (2014))

column1: What is the main goal of the project discussed in the article "Mining Citations, Linking Texts" by Matteo Romanello?
column2: The main goal of the project discussed in the article "Mining Citations, Linking Texts" by Matteo Romanello is to develop an expert system that can automatically capture canonical citations from ancient texts and establish their meaning. This system aims to track how and how often ancient texts are studied over time, providing essential information for data-driven studies of the discipline of Classics and its evolution. Additionally, the project aims to create an enhanced virtual reading environment for specific sections of ancient texts, such as Thucydides' Histories, by automatically mining related bibliographic references and linking them to the full text of journal articles and the cited passages in digital libraries. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: The main goal of the project discussed in the article "Mining Citations, Linking Texts" by Matteo Romanello is to develop an expert system that can automatically capture canonical citations and their meanings from primary sources in Classics. The system aims to track how and how often texts were studied over time, which is essential for a data-driven study of the discipline and its evolution. Another use of the system is to display related bibliographic references within a reading environment for ancient texts. The project also aims to create an enhanced virtual reading environment for a specific section of Thucydides Histories, the Pentecontaetia (Romanello and Thomas 2012).

column1: How are canonical citations defined in the context of Classics, and why are they important for scholars in the field?
column2: Canonical citations in the context of Classics are the standard way of citing primary sources, which are ancient texts. They are essential for scholars in the field because they provide a precise and interoperable way of referring to texts. This accuracy is crucial for scholarly discourse about texts, as it allows scholars to refer to specific sections of texts without being concerned about variations in pagination or layout across different editions or translations. Canonical citations are designed to link the citing text with the cited text, making them important artifacts that establish clear connections between different sources. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: Canonical citations are the standard way of citing primary sources, such as ancient texts, in the field of Classics. They are designed to refer to texts in a precise and interoperable way, allowing scholars to refer to specific sections of texts without concern for variations in pagination or layout across different editions and translations. This precision is crucial because texts are the fundamental object of philological research, and scholarly discourse about these texts requires an accurate way of referring to them. Canonical citations also serve as a way of linking the citing text and the cited text, making explicit links that already exist in the text. These citations are important for scholars as they allow for the tracking of how and how often texts were studied over time, providing essential information for a data-driven study of the discipline and its evolution (Romanello, ISAW Papers 7.24, 2014).

column1: How does the author approach the extraction of citations from texts, and what are the key entities identified in the process?
column2: The author approaches the extraction of citations from texts by performing two tasks: Named Entity Recognition (extraction) and Named Entity Disambiguation. In this process, the author identifies four key entities: aauthor, awork, refauwork, and refscope. These entities help in capturing the different components of a citation and any mention of ancient authors and works occurring in the context surrounding the citation itself. The goal is to establish a relation between these entities to accurately extract and understand the citations from the texts. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: The author, Matteo Romanello, approaches the extraction of citations from texts by using state-of-the-art Named Entity Recognition (NER) techniques, adapted to the new domain of citation extraction. This process involves two steps: capturing the strings that constitute the citation and establishing the specific section of text to which the citation refers, also known as Named Entity Disambiguation. Instead of only considering the usual named entities such as names of people, places, and organizations, Romanello treats the different components of a citation as named entities. Four distinct entities are identified in this process: aauthor, awork, refauwork, and refscope. A citation is defined as a relation between any two of these entities, where one is always the indication of the citation's scope (refscope) and the other can be any of the other entities. Once captured, citations are disambiguated by assigning to each citation its corresponding CTS URN (Romanello, 2013; ISAW Papers 7.24, 2014).

column1: What is the significance of disambiguating citations by assigning them corresponding CTS URNs?
column2: The significance of disambiguating citations by assigning them corresponding CTS URNs lies in the ability to create a standardized and unique identifier for each citation. This process allows for precise identification and retrieval of digital representations of texts, making it easier to link and reference specific sections of texts across different editions and translations. By using CTS URNs, citations become interoperable and can be resolved to the correct portion of text in any available edition or translation, ensuring accuracy and consistency in scholarly references. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: The significance of disambiguating citations by assigning them corresponding CTS URNs lies in their ability to serve as unique, persistent, and location-independent identifiers for textual data. As explained by Thomas Koentges et al. in "The CITE Architecture: Q & A Regarding CTS and CITE", these identifiers can be used to reference specific passages of text, allowing for precise citation in both print and digital formats. This system facilitates the work of annotators, commentary writers, and readers, who can use these identifiers without needing to know about each other. Furthermore, as Matteo Romanello explains in "Mining Citations, Linking Texts", CTS URNs are designed to be the digital equivalent of canonical citations, making it possible to identify and retrieve digital representations of texts.

column1: How is a knowledge base of canonical texts utilized to validate automatically extracted citations and prevent errors?
column2: A knowledge base of canonical texts is utilized to validate automatically extracted citations and prevent errors by storing detailed information about the citable structures of each text. This information includes all possible abbreviations of the name of an author or the title of a work, as well as structural details like the number of books or chapters in a specific text. By querying this knowledge base, researchers can validate the automatically extracted citations and identify errors. For example, if a citation includes an incorrect number of hierarchical levels, the knowledge base can help flag it as an invalid citation. This process helps ensure the accuracy of extracted citations and prevents common errors that may occur when working with OCR texts lacking structural markup. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: A knowledge base of canonical texts is utilized to validate automatically extracted citations by storing detailed information about the citable structures of each text, such as the number of books in a work or the number of chapters in a book. This allows for the identification and correction of citations that are not valid, such as those that reference a non-existent section of a work. For example, a citation that appears to reference a fourth hierarchical level in Thucydides Histories, which only has three levels, would be identified as incorrect. This system is particularly useful when working with OCRed texts, where structural markup may be lacking and errors in citation are common (ISAW Papers 7.24, 2014).

column1: How are extracted citations published as Linked Open Data, and what is the role of annotations in this process?
column2: Extracted citations are published as Linked Open Data by representing them as annotations using the Open Annotation Data Model. Each extracted citation is created as a new annotation where the string containing the citation becomes its label, and the citing and cited texts become its target and body, respectively. The annotations clarify the reason for creating them, which is typically for identifying the object (i.e., text section) identified by a given citation. Annotations play a crucial role in making the links between the citing text and the cited text explicit and interoperable within the Linked Open Data framework. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: Extracted citations are published as Linked Open Data by representing them as annotations, as defined by the Open Annotation Data Model. This approach was largely inspired by the Pelagios Project. For each extracted citation, a new annotation is created where the string containing the citation becomes its label, and the citing and cited texts become its target and body, respectively. These relationships are expressed by the oac:hasTarget and oac:hasBody properties (ISAW Papers 7.24, 2014).

column1: How does the author address the issue of making canonical citations interoperable in a digital environment?
column2: The author addresses the issue of making canonical citations interoperable in a digital environment by assigning each citation its corresponding CTS URN. This practice allows for the identification and retrieval of digital representations of texts. The CTS URNs are identifiers that follow the Uniform Resource Name standard and were developed within the Multitext Homer project as part of the CITE architecture. This approach aims to establish a digital equivalent of canonical citations, enabling the linking of citations to digital texts effectively. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: The authors address the issue of making canonical citations interoperable in a digital environment by transforming them into hyperlinks or resolvable pointers that can be resolved to a given portion of text in any available edition or translation. This is done through the use of the CITE architecture, which assigns unique identifiers to work-group, work, version, and each part of a text, making it canonically citable. The authors also mention the use of a knowledge base to support the disambiguation of canonical citations, which contains detailed information about the citable structures of each text. This information is then stored and published online as Linked Open Data (Heath and Bizer 2011). (ISAW Papers 7.24 (2014), ISAW Papers 20.8 (2021))

column1: What role do ontologies such as CIDOC-CRM and FRBRoo play in structuring the knowledge base for canonical texts?
column2: Ontologies like CIDOC-CRM and FRBRoo play a crucial role in structuring the knowledge base for canonical texts. They provide a framework for modeling information related to classical texts, including canonical citations. These ontologies help in organizing data about authors, works, citations, and other relevant entities in a structured and standardized manner. Additionally, when the existing ontologies do not fully meet the requirements, extensions like the HuCit ontology are created to enhance the modeling of data specific to the domain of canonical texts. Overall, these ontologies ensure consistency, interoperability, and accuracy in representing and querying information within the knowledge base. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: Ontologies like CIDOC-CRM and FRBRoo play a significant role in structuring the knowledge base for canonical texts. The CIDOC-CRM, for instance, is used as a standard for organizing data in cultural heritage information systems and is often used in the publication of archaeological data. It is also used in the representation of cultural heritage data and narrative structures, as mentioned in the research project by Terhi Nurmikko-Fuller (ISAW Papers 7.18, 2014). The FRBRoo ontology, on the other hand, is suitable for modeling information related to Classical (canonical) texts, as it has influenced the design of the CTS protocol (ISAW Papers 7.24, 2014).

column1: How are extracted citations linked to digital representations of texts in the Perseus Digital Library and the Classical Works Knowledge Base (CWKB) resolution service?
column2: Extracted citations are linked to digital representations of texts in the Perseus Digital Library and the Classical Works Knowledge Base (CWKB) resolution service through an intermediate object called "hucit:TextElement." This abstract object identifies a citable element within the hierarchical structure of a text and is linked via the "hucit:resolves_to" property to digital representations of the cited passage. These digital representations include editions and translations available in the Perseus Digital Library and via the Classical Works Knowledge Base resolution service. The URIs of these digital representations are not strictly LOD-compliant as they do not resolve to an RDF representation of the resource identified by the URI. However, linking to these resources is considered the first necessary step towards LOD compliance, with the hope that the underlying technology will eventually align with LOD principles. Matteo Romanello 2014,"Mining Citations, Linking Texts" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.24, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/romanello/.
column3: The Perseus Digital Library uses a system of Uniform Resource Identifiers (URIs) to link extracted citations to digital representations of texts. These URIs leverage Canonical Text Services (CTS) URNs, which allows the library to take advantage of the CTS data model while still supporting Linked Data standards. Individual passage citations can be retrieved at URIs which adhere to a specific syntax. However, it is noted that these URIs do not yet resolve to an RDF representation of the resource identified by the URI, which is not strictly LOD-compliant (ISAW Papers 7.3 (2014), Bridget Almas, Alison Babeu, and Anna Krohn; ISAW Papers 7.24 (2014)).

column1: What was the aim of the SAWS Project, and how was it funded?
column2: The aim of the SAWS Project was to explore the tradition of Greek and Arabic wisdom literatures by examining Greek and Arabic collections of 'sayings' and relating them to their sources, to each other, and to texts that used them. The project aimed to create links between these sayings to form the core of the project. The SAWS Project was funded by HERA (Humanities in the European Research Area) under a call to explore Cultural Dynamics.  2014,"Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.25, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/roueche-lawrence-lawrence/.
column3: The SAWS Project, Sharing Ancient Wisdoms: Exploring the Tradition of Greek and Arabic Wisdom Literatures, aimed to examine Greek and Arabic collections of 'sayings', and relate them both to their sources (largely in Greek and Arabic literature), to one another, and to texts which made use of them with these links making up the core of the project. The project was funded by HERA (Humanities in the European Research Area) under a call to explore Cultural Dynamics (Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom, ISAW Papers 7.25, 2014, Charlotte Rouechu00e9, Keith Lawrence, and Faith Lawrence).

column1: Why was the linked data approach important in the study of Greek and Arabic collections of 'sayings'?
column2: The linked data approach was important in the study of Greek and Arabic collections of 'sayings' because the authoring scribe of these collections was free to modify them, resulting in similar but distinct variations. By using linked data, researchers could relate these sayings to their sources, to each other, and to texts that made use of them, providing insights into philosophical traditions and cultural interactions represented in these collections.  2014,"Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.25, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/roueche-lawrence-lawrence/.
column3: The linked data approach was important in the study of Greek and Arabic collections of 'sayings' because it allowed for the examination of these collections in relation to their sources, to one another, and to texts that utilized them. This approach was used in the SAWS Project, Sharing Ancient Wisdoms, which was funded by HERA (Humanities in the European Research Area) to explore Cultural Dynamics. The project aimed to explore the philosophical traditions and cultural interactions represented in these collections, which were often modified by the authoring scribe, resulting in similar but distinct variations (ISAW Papers 7.25, 2014, "Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" by Charlotte Roueché, Keith Lawrence, and Faith Lawrence).

column1: What constraints did the researchers face when linking to sources, and how did they enrich their texts with other linked data?
column2: The researchers faced constraints in linking to sources because they were limited by what was available at the time. They were able to extensively use texts in Perseus but identified many items for which there was no text available to link to. They had hoped to link to items in the TLG canon, but this was not yet possible. To enrich their texts with other linked data, they included links to the new Perseus catalog or VIAF for authors, used Pleiades for places, linked to the Prosopography of the Byzantine World and the Paregorios list of Roman emperors for people named as actors, and added as many links as possible to online versions of the materials cited in the bibliography.  2014,"Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.25, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/roueche-lawrence-lawrence/.
column3: The researchers faced several constraints when linking to sources. For instance, they hoped to link to items in the TLG canon, but found it was not yet possible (ISAW Papers 7.25, 2014). Despite these challenges, they were able to enrich their texts with other kinds of linked data. They included links to the new Perseus catalog or to VIAF for authors. For places, they used Pleiades and were able to add some new locations, which allowed them to join Pelagios (ISAW Papers 7.25, 2014).

column1: How did the researchers aim to balance the use of machine-readable links with a welcoming environment for human readers?
column2: The researchers aimed to balance the use of machine-readable links with a welcoming environment for human readers by enriching their texts with various kinds of linked data. They included links to resources like the Perseus catalog, VIAF, Pleiades, Prosopography of the Byzantine World, and Paregorios list of Roman emperors. Additionally, they tried to enrich the bibliography with links to online versions of the materials being cited. The goal was to make the fullest possible use of links in machine-readable form while ensuring a user-friendly environment for human readers.  2014,"Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.25, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/roueche-lawrence-lawrence/.
column3: The researchers aimed to balance the use of machine-readable links with a welcoming environment for human readers by embedding links and reading tools that are easy to implement from an author's or publisher's perspective. They also aimed to create a multi-dimensional text that adds practical improvements to the printed word, delivering more robust content more quickly to the reader. They stressed the importance of keeping the general reader in mind, who should be able to find and use online data and its underlying relationships without a second thought of how it all came to be. They also tried to enrich their bibliography with as many links as possible to online versions of the materials being cited, while also creating an environment that is welcoming for human readers (ISAW Papers 7.23 (2014), ISAW Papers 7.25 (2014)).

column1: How did the researchers address incorrect or mistaken references through the use of linked data?
column2: The researchers addressed incorrect or mistaken references through the use of linked data by working in a way that allowed them to go directly to the text being referenced. This direct linking to the source text could reveal incorrect or mistaken references, leading to a slow and steady improvement in accuracy.  2014,"Linked Data and Ancient Wisdom" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.25, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/roueche-lawrence-lawrence/.
column3: The researchers addressed incorrect or mistaken references through the use of linked data by transforming citations into hyperlinks. This process allows for direct access to the text being referenced, making it easier to identify and correct any inaccuracies. Additionally, the use of linked data can lead to a slow, steady improvement in accuracy as it enables the linking of data, which can highlight incorrect or mistaken references (ISAW Papers 7.25, 2014). However, it's important to note that this method may lead to a misrepresentation of the nature of citations, as they are designed to be interoperable and should not be tied to a specific edition or translation (ISAW Papers 7.24, 2014).

column1: What are some of the challenges faced by scholars who are unfamiliar with linked open data when it comes to publishing archaeological data online?
column2: Some of the challenges faced by scholars unfamiliar with linked open data when it comes to publishing archaeological data online include violating best practice guidelines for born-digital data, not structuring datasets for individual record metadata, and struggling with the technical aspects of coding RDF triples or using web languages like HTML or SPARQL. Additionally, there may be difficulties in understanding how to connect data to the semantic web and making data accessible and meaningful to a broader audience. Rebecca M. Seifried 2014,"Linked Open Data for the Uninitiated" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.26, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/seifried/.
column3: Scholars who are unfamiliar with linked open data face several challenges when it comes to publishing archaeological data online. According to Rebecca M. Seifried in "Linked Open Data for the Uninitiated" (ISAW Papers 7.26, 2014), one of the main difficulties is the technical aspect of creating and managing linked open data, especially for those who do not have a background in web languages like HTML or SPARQL. Additionally, there is the issue of adhering to best practice guidelines for born-digital data. Seifried also mentions the challenge of understanding the basic premises of linked open data and structuring datasets in a way that can be easily converted into this format by specialists. Furthermore, the "Publishing Archaeological Linked Open Data: From Steampunk to Sustainability" (ISAW Papers 7.23, 2014) paper highlights the need for education about the potential of new media and existing technology in documenting archaeological work.

column1: How does the author suggest that uninitiated archaeologists prepare their data for online publication, even if they are not familiar with coding RDF triples?
column2: The author suggests that even if uninitiated archaeologists are not familiar with coding RDF triples, they should prepare their data to be archived in an online, open-access format. This involves structuring datasets so that specialists can later convert them into linked open data in a relatively easy process. By following best practice guidelines for data acquisition and compilation, uninitiated archaeologists can make their data accessible for online publication, even without coding RDF triples themselves. Rebecca M. Seifried 2014,"Linked Open Data for the Uninitiated" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.26, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/seifried/.
column3: The author suggests that uninitiated archaeologists prepare their data for online publication by understanding the basic premises of linked open data and structuring their datasets in a way that specialists can later create linked open data in a relatively easy and painless process. The author also emphasizes the importance of determining which specific types of data will be relevant to a broader audience and preparing for data to be archived in an online, open-access format. The author further recommends that authors of preliminary excavation reports or final reports provide their readers with links to complete data sets, which can be used as a reference and checked for errors (Rebecca M. Seifried, ISAW Papers 7.26 (2014)).

column1: What are the two alternatives the author considers for achieving the "5 stars" of Berners-Lee's Linked Open Data guidelines for publishing their own dissertation research online?
column2: The author considers two alternatives for achieving the "5 stars" of Berners-Lee's Linked Open Data guidelines for publishing their own dissertation research online. The first alternative is to use a data depository like OpenContext.org that issues individual URIs for each item within a dataset. The second alternative is to create their own website using RDF triples and cool URIs. Rebecca M. Seifried 2014,"Linked Open Data for the Uninitiated" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.26, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/seifried/.
column3: The author, Rebecca M. Seifried, in her paper "Linked Open Data for the Uninitiated" (ISAW Papers 7.26, 2014), considers two alternatives for achieving the "5 stars" of Berners-Lee's Linked Open Data guidelines for publishing her own dissertation research online. The first alternative is to use a data depository, like OpenContext.org, that issues individual URIs for each item within a dataset. This option would allow a technical expert to help her get her data online in a meaningful way. The second alternative is to create her own website using RDF triples and cool URIs, as demonstrated by individuals at the 2013 LAWDI gathering.

column1: What is the goal of the Pelagios initiative?
column2: The goal of the Pelagios initiative is to facilitate better linking between online resources documenting the past based on the places they refer to. It aims to help digital humanists make their data more discoverable and empower users to find information about ancient places and visualize it in meaningful ways.  2014,"Pelagios" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.27, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/simon-barker-desoto-isaksen/.
column3: The goal of the Pelagios initiative, as described by Rainer Simon, Elton Barker, Pau de Soto, and Leif Isaksen in ISAW Papers 7.27 (2014), is to facilitate better linking between online resources documenting the past, based on the places that they refer to. It aims to make data more discoverable for digital humanists and empower users, including scholars and the general public, to find information about particular ancient places and visualize it in meaningful ways. The initiative is open to online content of any type and format, connecting diverse data such as text corpora, image archives, archaeological databases, museum collections, publication series, and online resources produced by specific research projects.

column1: How does Pelagios facilitate better linking between online resources documenting the past?
column2: Pelagios facilitates better linking between online resources documenting the past by using a common vocabulary when referring to places and by establishing lightweight conventions on how to publish these place references as Linked Data. The common vocabulary is based on the Pleiades Gazetteer of the Ancient World, which provides unique URI identifiers for places in the Greco-Roman world. By using these identifiers, Pelagios ensures that references to specific places are unique and not confused with other locations. Additionally, Pelagios partners publish annotations as RDF according to the Open Annotation ontology, making the data available under an open license. This approach allows for the aggregation of place references from diverse datasets and enables users to search for information about ancient places in a meaningful way.  2014,"Pelagios" ISAW Papers, vol. 7.27, http://dlib.nyu.edu/awdl/isaw/isaw-papers/7/simon-barker-desoto-isaksen/.
column3: Pelagios is a community-driven initiative that aims to facilitate better linking between online resources documenting the past, based on the places that they refer to. It is open to online content of any type and format, connecting data as diverse as text corpora, image archives, archaeological databases, museum collections, publication series, and online resources produced by specific research projects (Simon, Barker, de Soto, and Isaksen, ISAW Papers 7.27, 2014). The project uses references to spatial gazetteers shared across various datasets to link, aggregate, and visualize spatial data in those datasets (Isaksen et al. 2014; Simon, Barker, and Isaksen 2012, ISAW Papers 20.3, 2021).
